review_title: Great, smart people in a rapidly evolving culture
job_title: Senior Director Marketing in Bethesda, MD
pros: The people are always the first thing that is recognized as a positive when working at MI. Some of the brightest, most innovative and resilient people work at the company, all with incredible passion for the brands and the travel space. As a marketer, the work is progressive, exciting and consistently challenging creatively. Benefits are average for a large company, but not exceptional. Travel benefits are great to have and are very flexible to obtain. The work experience is strong and reputation by association is positive upon departure.
cons: The culture is evolving and the company that it once was with a much smaller portfolio of brands is in the rearview mirror. New outside talent appears to be able to join the organization more easily than past when internal hiring was more heavily leveraged. Leadership skills are not as sought after or bred within - which is one of the largest negatives. The "associate first" value does not present itself in the ways it did 5-10+ years ago, which is likely due to the sheer size of the organization now since its acquisition of Starwood. Not a "hall pass" just a reality to be aware of. The passion is still there, but the internal longevity, opportunities, and the loyalty is not as it had been historically.

cons: There aren't very many things I can think of that are downsides of Marriott.  If I had to say one thing it might be that they were too lenient on their employees. review_title: "Take care of the associates, and they'll take care of our customers" - feel-good B.S.
pros: The company is worldwide, with much opportunity for internal development, promotion, training,  and transfer-- if you're willing to stick around and deal with all the "cons", that is.
cons:
Salaried associates are shamelessly exploited-- if a manager/supervisor can be forced to do the work of an hourly associate (or two) on top of their own, you can expect it will become the norm sooner or later. Trimming the fat is one thing, but Marriott will trim the meat and bone at the slightest budgetary shortfall, and never allow it to heal.

Meanwhile, hourly associates are not compensated fairly for their hard work. Wages are determined by local market wage surveys-- but most, if not all, of the properties surveyed are apt to be Marriott, as well, in a convenient catch-22. The bottom line is, positions are not compensated as well as their counterparts in other companies-- though this is true for Hospitality in general.

Corporate S.O.P. and the short-term bottom line trump all logic and nuance of property- or department- level decision-making. Local management cares more about looking good to Top Brass and making their numbers by any means necessary than truly making wise long-term decisions for the customers, associates, or company.

review_title: Working for this franchise was a waste of time for me.
job_title: Home Reservations Agent in Miami, FL
pros: Marriott Corporation has had an overall long tradition of good quality of service to customers and its employees as well. Every Marriott location is a franchise of the Marriott Corporation which headquarters are located in Bethesda, Maryland. Marriott franchises are located nation and worldwide which means that there is the opportunity to work and live in other places across the United States and out of it as well.
cons: The fact that every Marriott location is a franchise means that there could be some variations in management styles, organizational behavior, and quality of service. In the specific case of the Global Reservation Center in Miami, I found that Miami has a high cost of living (compared to other places in Florida) and the hourly rate offered, in my case, was not a competitive hourly rate. After training, the hourly rate would increase to fifty cents more per hour which I think is not enough incentive. Apparently their financial situation is not so good since they were cutting hours, and hiring mostly certain "targeted groups" due to the incentives and credits the government gives to them for every recruitment of this kind.

review_title: Great company to work for as long as you are in the right department
pros: This company is definitely the place to work if you are looking for growth. There are so many departments you can work in and so many different locations. Once you get hired and have worked six months in a position, you have the chance to apply within the company (worldwide) for another job. And already being an employee of the Marriott, you get to view the available jobs before they are opened to the public.
cons: It really sucks that depending on what department you work in, you aren't always guaranteed hours. Working in the events department can be fun and busy at times, but then not busy at all when it comes to holiday seasons. I have pretty much for the past 4 months hardly had any hours of work. I'm not sure how they expect their employees to survive without hours. No hours, no pay.

review_title: Not a career unless you are okay with low income, but lots of time off
pros:
Little micro-management, lots of time off, and plenty of free time on the job. 

Pretty lenient with time-off requests.
cons:
With lots of time off, comes low income because it's an hourly position for both full time and part time AV technicians. Making 35k would be a good year. It's seasonal work, so you can expect no work during the summer, or during Christmas holidays, including full timers. The only busy portion of the year is from September to November. You can expect some work from January to June, but it fluctuates greatly from week to week. 

Very cheap company that will often understaff at the expense of the workload of the technicians scheduled, the income of the workers, and the equipment, which is often broken or outdated. 

Very little room for growth. You can move from part time to full time if a full-timer leaves, but that's all the growth you can expect.

pros: Great perks. Discounts at any Marriott hotel in the world. Also management is flexible with your schedule and willing to make exceptions when you need time off. Also, the a fun work environment not at all cut throat or vindictive like some other hotel industries may be. review_title: Great Company to work for...but Sales is tough...
job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Miami, FL
pros: Marriott is recognizable in many ways. Training, learning, growth, benefits, perks, etc. Spent 10 years with this company in many roles and it will always be home. Marriott's flexibility has improved as far as remote capabilities (mostly for Sales teams) but it shows they are listening to the trends. Employee perks are unmatched.
cons: Sales goals are extremely high and difficult to achieve. Too many metrics to meet. Sales is stressful in general but with unattainable goals, it gets to a point where it feels impossible to do your job well. Nothing will change due to the size of the company and how everything goes through Corporate but I wish this would be readjusted starting with the Sales Offices.  Also, bonus structure is terrible compared to what it used to be. They have changed it year-over-year and now they equate to nearly nothing. There is no incentive to work so hard meeting your goals other than to keep your job. Sales Managers are not incentivized any longer.

pros: Beautiful properties, opportunity for internal career development, dedicated employees
cons: Benefits are the same for entry level vs leadership level, regardless of extensive experience and higher education. No benefits or PTO for the first 90 days of employment, forcing you to go without healthcare, taking COBRA from your prior job at an outrageous cost, or going on a spouse’s plan. After working 3 months without any benefits, you are eligible for healthcare, etc. and your PTO begins to accrue but only up to 16 days, with no separate sick time. So essentially, you have two weeks vacation because you need to reserve 5-6 days annually for sick incidents. This accrual doesn’t increase for 5 years. You also can only carry over PTO until June 1 the next year so you can never have additional PTO for use in the summer months. In addition, it is MANDATORY for all managers to work 10 hour days—every day. Most managers worked well over 10 hours back to back. No work/life balance so even though you get discounts at properties people feel that they never get enough time with for to enjoy that benefit.

At the end of the day you will be replaced as though you meant nothing, think if this is truly worth that kind of headache.

review_title: Marriott is a great place to work
job_title: Senior Sales Manager in Houston, TX
pros:
Economical

Hotel stay awards include breakfast for two persons, taxes and gratuities with no hidden extras with our incentive award programs 
Incentives cater to every budget, with a choice of brands and different levels of awards throughout the world 
This corporate incentive program is an ideal way to thank loyal customers by offering non-face value awards with a highly perceived value 

Flexible

Flexibility of last room availability 365 days a year, giving you confidence that the award will be used 
Valid at over 2,900 properties worldwide, giving you flexibility and choice 
Toll-free reservations number provides easy booking 
Tailor-made packages suit individual needs
cons: We challenge you to find someone who doesn't get excited about a vacation. Or someone who doesn't start marking off their calendar weeks in advance. You'll be amazed at how hard people work when each sale translates into another round of golf, or when reaching that service goal means a second honeymoon. Individual travel incentives let people decide when and where they go ... and offer a long-lasting benefit that neither cash nor other incentives can achieve. With Individual Incentives, these powerful employee incentive programs are easy to put into action: Once the award is in their hands, they make their selection and book directly with us. It’s that simple!

pros:
*Travel benefits (hotel discounts!) -awesome!
*Paid time off
*Getting paid by the number of rooms is awesome! Much better than being paid hourly.
*Get to meet lots of great people from all walks of life
*Free breakfast every morning
cons:
*The pay sucks. I could be making much more doing a job that requires me to sit on my ass.
*Some supervisors are just straight up MEAN.
*Too many temporary workers in the housekeeping department and none of them speak English.
*Be prepared to work every weekend and some holidays.
*Lots of gossip and even some bullying going on.
*No recognition for doing an exceptional job.
*Being thrown in front of the bus in front of everyone.
*Hideous uniforms
*VERY hard work! Very strenuous physical labor.
*Some people are NASTY! You wouldn't believe some of the things I have had to clean up (and you wouldn't want to! lol)
*Nit-picking supervisors. No matter how clean the rooms are they will always find SOMETHING.

pros: Usually, there are allot of extra's including free food and free gym membership. Also moving up isn't too difficult because of the global size of the Marriott and the huge changeover in staff.  Stay for at least a year and your probably almost 100% guaranteed to move up in the ranks somehow. or change to another Marriott where a better position does exist.
cons: Below market level pay (especially when considering night shift where I believe there should be a greater level of difference in pay as the night workers sacrifice allot). Also, management love to play the blame game, Marriott will get you to sign anything so they don't have to take any liability and when something does go down, it's your fault because Marriott gave you training on it for 60 sec, therefore, you now are responsible. Low holiday pay, I think I have 20 holiday days a year (don't know how that relates to more or less the norm for holidays in the UK), which just doesn't seem allot for the amount of work every day.

pros: Very friendly and very good pay. I think that more people should come to the marriot to work because if you ask me, i think that it is very good pay and also that you should spend more nights there for the amazing service. The staff is friendly which makes it very easy to make friends while working at the marriot. i would like to work there for a while given the fact that i have friends there and my boss is a very nice and highly educated person which whom i love working with. i love working there a lot! ! ! !
cons: People can be very  mean. When people are rude, man that really upsets me. I try to be nice to them and not lose my cool but sometimes I just can not help it. Although taking yoga can really calm me donw. I feel that sometimes my boss can be a little cheap like for instance with the amount of break we get and the vacation we get... but overall this is a very good place and I do not have much to complain about at all really. I plan on working there for a while, very good service and industry.

review_title: Decent job but will always be reminded of why it's ONLY decent
pros: The starting pay is alright, and you will be reminded that there is good in the world with this job. You learn how to deal with people and discover exactly how far your "limit" is. It helps you learn how to multitask and trains you to work in a fast-paced environment...
cons: ... At the same time, there will always be something or someone who reminds you that working with people is a hassle in itself. It may make you re-think ever working in customer service or with people, in general. Pay doesn't quite match up with the work you're required to do, but it's a job nonetheless. Associates complain endlessly about upper management and how we can't do anything about the way they run the hotel (incompetent).

review_title: Not the worst, definitely not the best.
job_title: Guest Service Agent in Tysons Corner
pros:
weekly pay. 
Culture is very diverse.
Teams and co-workers are usually great to work with.
No shortage of hours, and in the event that there is, there are often many hotels that are in need of temporary staff and you are welcomed to help them.
Communication between hotel properties is great. No matter what time, if you call a sister property, they will most certainly respond in a timely manner.
Donation efforts.
cons:
Company growth- Not good, been here over 4 years and missed many holidays, birthdays, anniversaries working doubles, overtime, etc. with no recognition. I've applied to over 30 transfers within the company and have yet to even land an interview, only automatic emails of rejection, the majority of the positions were lateral moves too.
Tuition Reimbursement- only applies to particular courses.
Discounts- Often unavailable.
work/life balance- non-existent unless you are in management.
pay- Not capable of living off unless you are in management.
management- When they leave for the day, that's it, they are gone, almost as if they forgot they even work here. Same goes for the weekends, Friday mid afternoon, (maybe) late afternoon comes, they are gone till Monday.
working alone- very difficult with no maintenance/houseman/housekeepers.

It is who you know, not what you know. Remember this If you plan to go up the latter.

review_title: Marriott is a great company to work for because it offers career growth in a variety of different job types.
pros: PTO, Benefits, and Room Rate Discounts are nice.  The culture is centered on treating associates well so that they will in turn treat the guest well.  There are numerous ways to grow your career if you are able to learn new skills and adapt to changes.
cons: The corporate work environment (HQ) does not always follow the same ideals as the hotel (Field) environment of treating associates well.  By this I mean that the customer is not in view and the corporate structure can be disconnected from the business of hospitality.  As with most companies post recession Marriott is trying to do more with less and many corporate workers are overwhelmed and can not keep pace with work demands.

review_title: While every company, including Marriott, has it's problems, Marriott is truly the best company to work for!
pros: Marriott is all about the people - recognition for a job well done is core to the Marriott philosophy. People respect each other, and upper management respects the associates. Marriott truly respects work life balance, and the company as a whole tries to enable associates to work a family friendly schedule. Telecommuting is becoming the fastest trend in the IT field, making my current position fantastic for my family.  If you work hard, you will be rewarded with not only a promotion, but merit increases. And, the room rate discount is fantastic!
cons: People don't work at Marriott for the money. People work at Marriott for the management style and the other people. Anyone could easily go to another hotel company and make more money.  The benefits are good, but they could be better, specifically the health insurance.

pros: Connecting and networking with surrounding businesses and organizations.
cons: No work/life balance. Low pay. Long hours. Breaks are sometimes. Employee appreciation week essentially consists of whoever is there between normal business hours because that is all that management works, so they expect you to come in on your time off. Staff usually consists of half uneducated, quarter unreliable, other quarter Marriott brown nosing hotel nerds. No push for company to promote from within. Benefits are so-so. Room discounts are a joke, you could save $1 or you could catch a deal for next to nothing, if you are willing to stay in the middle of nowhere where their idea of convenience is having a 7-11 3 miles away. Very outdated technology and for as large as the company is, it must have the least innovative solutions ever. The amount of paper that is wasted annually is a joke if anyone would ever take the time to do the math. Many inappropriate relationships between co-workers, managers-employees, employees-guests. Training regularly consists of people showing you something once and then them just expecting you to figure it out with time. The vendors that Marriott uses are questionable, supposedly used to save money... Google will tell you otherwise with the lawsuits. I wouldn't wish hotel life on anyone. ENJOY!

job_title: Event Supervisor in San Juan, PR
pros: Marriott is very well structured
cons: Pay should be better for all you have to do and deal with.

job_title: Assistant Banquet Manager in Toronto, ON
pros: Room Discounts, Cultural Exposure, Diversity,
cons: Unionized Job, Long Hours, Low Pay

job_title: Front Office Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros:
The company offers a healthy compensation & benefit package in addition to a strong philosphy of "doing the right thing" which, I feel, is even more important than a strong pay scale. 
Treating employees with trust, honesty, respect, & integrity sometimes seem to be virtues of a bygone era but the message stays strong within our company.
Promoting from within is highly encouraged and opportunities for growth and learning are ever present- at least as long as you seek them.
A strong community exists within our brand and we look out for each other as much as possible while still welcoming newcomers with freah eyes and perspectives
cons: Doing more with less seems to be the mantra of the day. Many leadership positions have been eliminated while salaries stay flat. A hotel with 60 managers in 2008 is now running with 20-25 in 2012 but the salaries have not compensated for the increase of responsibilty. An ever-growing focus on profit and productivity have taken the graciousness and delight out of the service- many are struggling to stay afloat and motivated. So much of the talent pool has been depleted either by job elimination or burn out, I worry for the future of the brand.

review_title: Great Place to develop a career
pros: There is not much to dislike about this company, so long as you understand that it is a business and not everything is going to go in your favor. If you are objective, it is a great place to pursue a career. Many opportunities for advancement, all over the world. Nice travel perks as well, with great room discounts.
cons: Know that there are Marriott franchises (which aren't owned by Marriott), and Marriott owned properties. The franchises don't always play by the same guidelines as corporate. The corporate owned facilities are well run, and maintained. There is a lot of attention paid to payroll, and staffing levels. If you are one who likes to get paid to do nothing, not a great place. Also, I am not a rah rah person, and there are maybe a few too many dollars spent on employee "moral builders". Not saying that that is bad for all. Overall, there aren't many things to not like, especially if you enjoy traveling, and you have to factor that into your wage, as they aren't the highest paying company on the planet.

review_title: I give myself the personal satisfaction of the job I do.
pros:
health insurance, 401K, discounts on rooms, restaurants, shops within Marriott, paid time off
chance to transfer to other properties all over the world, able to change positions and cross train, the more crosstraining makes you more valuable, paid for time worked, you don't have to fight to get your pay that is owed
chance to meet really nice people
cons:
Discounts on rooms are great, but you don't have the time to take advantage, sadly short staffed in all or most departments, associates have to use their paid time off by the end of the year, or they'll lose it, but again, when the department is short staffed, how can you go on a vacation?
Advancement is limited at property, one has to leave the property to advance.  Poor quality associates are hired, while quality associates leave.  Management has double standards and are not consistant with policies.

pros: The benifits are great. I absolutly love the discounted rooms across the world! Management is very competent and knows how to communicate with managers and assistants alike. There is plenty of room for growth, and the internal training is top notch! You could go into this job knowing nothing, but in five weeks, you know enough to sell mulitple hotels.
cons: As a sales organization, I wonder if it is getting caught up in its own bureacracy...we all work in an office, far away from the customer and the hotels. The idea is to be more customer forcused, offering availability of more hotels through "One point of contact"...but in reality: it is a cost cutting method to decrease the number of managers in the company to generate more revenue with fewer managers. Apparently the strategy is working...however, it translates into long hours and less pay in comparison to industry standards.

review_title: Great corporate location, nice corporate culture, below average pay
pros: Wonderful company events for corporate employees (such as cultural heritage day, birthday celebration for Mr. Marriott, etc.). Very polite corporate culture. Corporate facilities were nice, including a good cafeteria. Best structure of any company I've worked for -- each person had very specific roles on the team, meaning there was little confusion about who did what. Lots of internal opportunities for movement. Bethesda location was great and you can easily live on the metro line and go into DC regularly if desired. Overall, I would take the below average pay to work here again because the pros of working for such an established company are great.
cons: Company pays less than most people prefer. This is only a problem if you want a nice place in Bethesda, but many surrounding cities are cheaper. Some corporate business units can be workaholic. 60 hours a week is the norm on some teams. Some teams do allow working from home, flex time (come early, leave early), and that sort of thing.

review_title: A job with no career prospect. A place where people are used and thrown away as management pleases
job_title: Front Desk Agent in Copenhagen, Capital Region
pros: International and diverse working atmosphere. Days are not the same. Pride for delivering the best possible service to our guests.
cons: Poor salary and working conditions. Little space for professional development. Extremely hierarchic. Terrible communication. Very inhuman treatment of employees when these need time of either for their own illness or when a family member falls ill. Employees are encourage to work while feeling sick, in fear of getting fired, reprehended or victim of other repercussions once they get back to work.

pros: Our team is great, the hotel itself is really nice, the managers are very supportive and helpful and work a lot of hours to help out.
cons: Last month our hotel became Marriott managed instead of what we were which was a franchise. The new HR department is creating a hostile work environment. They  spy on the employees and then asks questions about what they hear us talking about. Here is a bit of advice for them. When I am on my "unpaid" break in the cafeteria it is ny business what I talk about. Stop trying to get us to throw our managers under the bus. We won't do it. We actually like our managers and they work hard and do a great job. They support us. .Stop looking for problems when there aren't any and maybe instead find people to hire so that people can get days off. Please recruit and get us people. This hotel's work environment has become unbearable and no one at corporate cares as the HR people are their  friends . Some of the HR people only got their jobs because they are friends with the corporate people and they do not even have any experience to be in their jobs.

pros:
Travel benefits
Flexible shifts
Diverse company culture
cons:
Long hours
Upper management doesn’t care

job_title: Director, Human Resources in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Easy to apply for a job.
cons: No able to grow within the company.

review_title: Great place to work especially if you have a family
pros: I work at a sales office.  The environment is great, my leaders are very understanding especially if it involves your family.  They also try their best to make their employees happy, even if it's just free breakfast, or cake, or ice cream you could see their efforts.  The training at Marriott is also great.  I know that other hotel companies seek out Marriott trained people
cons: The hours are long.  It is 10 hours, sometimes even 11 hours.  We are constantly busy and sometimes understaffed.  I live close by so I can still be home by 6-6:30pm.  But they have been good to me and I work with great people and that for me compensates.  The pay is a little bit lower than other hotel chains but then again you need to think of what your priorities are.  If money is your goal, then you might want to seek other hotel chains.

pros: Marriott owned or managed properties are typically of higher quality than some of the other hotel brands. They have good medical benefits.
cons: They promise many things during interviews that never come to fruition after employment. Just to mention a few: career advancement - after working below my skill set for over a year, I was not allowed to move to the day shift and position I was promised. I was talso old there was a myriad of management training resources available, but my supervisors could never get around to getting me set up in the system to take advantage of them.  I was also told during interviews there is a bonus program, but when the details were made clear upon my insistence (after I took the job) my manager had to admit the the metrics to qualify for bonus were next to impossible to meet.

review_title: Fact finding conversation using my applilcation and their interviews with former employers and friends.
job_title: Coordinators Residents, Public Rellations in Elk Grove, CA
pros:
Good company, well organized at the top.  Beautiful upscale property, fine fellow employees. Most
employees well qualified for their job.
cons:
Some employees not well quallified for the hands on type of work they did. They tended to cheat
on some tests (the employees in question told me this) and this created problems in their work. Most of them learned to do better and did preform better or were asked to leave after their 3 notices.
Some of the hands on employees did not know how to read or write. That was also changed. It ran
well after the first six months.

review_title: Courtyard by Marriott Front Desk Agent- DFW
pros: I absolutely loved the people I worked with, which was the only reason I stayed as long as i did. I typically did the AM shift so I was done by 3pm which was nice because I felt like I had the whole day open. The job duties are not super complex or difficult.
cons: I have nothing negative to say about the company itself or even the people who run it. However, the actual job itself was more than what I bargained for. Not that the job duties were difficult, but the constant dealing with complaints got old really quickly. There is always something for the guests to complain about, and most of the time it was about things we had no control over. Sometimes I would be working the PM shift (3-11pm) and would be the only employee in the building which made it hard to accommodate guest needs when you had to watch the front desk as well.

pros: I joined marriott as fresher, my joining experience was amazing, I worked at concierge, after 5-6 months I felt like I should change my department to service, I went to my departmental head spoke to him about the same, he was absolutely fine with the decision I made. I was a confirmed employee there, I had spent 5 months in the concierge, later I resigned , then I went to HR, they told me that I can give you a inter departmental interchange. But I was actually wishing from inside to move out of the hotel and join some other hotel. But HR didn't give up, He offered me a job in Service at some other marriott, that was amazing ....! He also told me that my experience at concierge will get accumulated with current experience in service.....!, as marriott is huge brand, worlds biggest hotel chain, there is a great exposure to find job....!
cons: To be honest I didn't fine any cons , but one I would put that marriott pays little less comparing other companies what they pay in india...!

review_title: Good pay/benefits, but don't go here for learning/development/advancement
pros:
Compensation (good pay, benefits, time off)
Discounted hotels.
cons:
Good ole boys corporate culture and resulting structure.
Compensation (leaving you in golden handcuffs/hard to make a move).
Lack of learning and advancement opportunities.
Very siloed professional development, generating a very specialized skill-set unique to the corporate Marriott systems (ie. Very little translatable skills. Value increases within company, but not in the overall job market, which makes it very tough to find another job when your time comes).

review_title: Doesn't like training or giving people chances
job_title: Front Desk Agent in Chicago, IL
pros: I have no pros for this company!
cons: This company is a disgrace to any workplace.. they deny everyone who applies to them who don't have the direct experience with the job that they are applying for. Marriott you do understand that people get into positions in the first place with someone believing and training a person to do the job correctly. If you don't have an extensive resume they deny you through email don't even give you the chance to interview. My friend had front Desk on his background & they hired him. I feel that's not fair because everyone has to start somewhere. I'll make sure none of my friends never stay at a Marriott owned hotel & I never will as well.

review_title: Enjoy the job, hate the management
pros: The job is relatively easy, and you get to meet a lot of interesting characters! I genuinely enjoy the job, it fits my outgoing personality a lot!
cons:
Schedules for the weeks, which start on Saturday, don't come out until the Wednesday beforehand! That gives you three (or less - sometimes it doesn't come til Thursday) days to know whether or not you can make plans for the weekend. This is the NUMBER ONE thing that if it changed - working here would be SO much more enjoyable.

Not to mention, the SEVERE hours cut. I was hired at full-time. I should stay at full time. Instead, during the winter months, I'm barely getting 30 hours a week! I had to get a second job to make up for it! I was never told that I was working seasonally when I was hired, so I shouldn't be treated as such!

job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Medford, MA
pros:
- Great weekly stand-up meetings  with regional team and leadership
- Employee discounts at select Marriott hotels (discount based on hotel room availability)
- Ability to shadow peers
- Open door policy with managers
- Networking opportunities with Marriott employees in other states
- Strong training program
cons:
- Mandated 50 hour work weeks
- Poor PTO flexibility 
- High quarterly revenue goals with little room to earn bonuses (no commission available either)
- Outdated corporate ideals in upper leadership
- Very high-pressure sales environment ("3 strikes and you're out" type deal- even in slower seasons)
- Very little work/life balance
- Upper management did not seem to care about employee well-being- everything seemed to be about hitting revenue goals
- Poor compensation considering Sales Managers were required to work 50 hours of week (sometimes more during busy season)

job_title: Front Desk Agent in London, England
pros:
The culture at the Marriott is next to nothing you'll experience.
They provide you with a free dinner, lunch or breakfast depending on your shift.
If you finished finished after your shift and tubes had stopped working they covered most of your taxi cost. 
You got good perks like big discounts of other Marriott hotels.
You could get a lot of experience for an entry level role into finance, sales & marketing and HR. You would never get that sort of experience at another starter level job.
cons:
The hours are are anti-social and you have to really like serving the guest and being in hospitality.
The Marriott rewards system means that guests can be even more confrontational with you, especially if they are gold or above.

review_title: It's not Mr Marriott's Marriott anymore
pros: It WAS a great company to work for.  We all gladly worked ourselves to death for the company that held it's employees on a pedestal.  They wanted to do things right and that is what we did.  Past tense.
cons: Now that Mr Marriott is no longer at the helm that is all gone.  The current management is risking driving the company into the ground, everything is being outsourced.  I know this sound like a disgruntled employee rambling but it not just that (I am still an employee).  We worked hard for this company and took great pride in it and now that is being just thrown away.  The current direction puts the company at great risk as they will be just another hotel mgmt company except a lot more expensive.  In the current era of "Insourcing" and after countless failed outsourcing attempts by other companies the current mgmt thinks they can do it better.  I hope I'm wrong as I've put my heart and soul into this company but I have to say I'm concerned over Marriott's future.

job_title: Guest Service Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: A healthy, supportive culture that offers strong training resources for employees and encouraging incentives for more rewarding experiences - both for the guest and the employee as a member of the team.
cons: This company did not succeed in keeping their word on the work-life balance front and did not inform me of this fact at the time they were obliged to. As a consequence, I felt lied to, although management had changed between the time when the promise was made and the time when it affected my life outside of hospitality work. While I might describe this experience as more of a misunderstanding, it was a direct reflection of the company's priorities, its limited regard for its employees' needs and a lack of adequate resources devoted toward new hiring and scheduling concerns.

pros: always loved  and valued my guest  !!  12 years of previous experience so I almost could walk in and do all... but pos systems vary  and having to learn 1,000 new wines ,liquor and beers plus menu (all  is learned in work related experience
cons: supervisor,outlet managers talk down to you even if you are the best-hardworking employee.  No time for any real time training and employees are always wrong even if we proved otherwise.   HR is never in office to take disagreements- dispute, and you need to have proof other wise managers are correct regardless...  they work you like a dog , never hardly have time to break for bathroom..and managers are always out of pocket  to help.. This was the worst managers  over my 12 year experience..no inspiration  and I was spoken to with direct rude personal perception  on the 1st day !!   RECORD ALL CONVERSATIONS  for PROOF... it may save your job ! Bar staff was arrogant and rude also.   As a server you had to walk approximately 40 feet round trip to get guest water and sodas because bartenders were not required to fill those orders. never any glasses or  very few, stations left  messy from morning shift  and I felt targeted.

pros:
- Compensation and benefits were pretty good (considering an entry level position - this is not the case for all Marriott hotels)
- If you are well-liked and respectable, people will help you along the way
- Lots of job opportunities in the same hotel and across all Marriott hotels
- Willing to teach you from scratch regardless of experience
cons:
- Claims there is mobility but not really (based on the hotel I worked at: if you are not the manager's favorite you don't have a chance, you may be given "opportunities" to apply for positions that has difficulty being filled). Most of the time, they seem to open up positions with the intention of hiring a specific candidate
- You usually need connections to get in
- Senior staff, and others well-liked by managers can get away with things that should be disciplined with a written warning or worse
- If you are new, you have no say in your schedule. What's worse, if you are not well-liked, you may get the least popular shifts

review_title: Not a great place to work.
job_title: Front Desk Agent in Grapevine, TX
pros: The only thing that I enjoyed about being a front desk agent for Marriott Springhill Suites was greeting and interacting with the guests.
cons: Training was lacking, co worker relations were crappy,  and the pay was peanuts. No one that I came into contact with besides the GM had been there over six months. You get no breaks, and scheduling is terrible. I inquired about meal breaks and was told that there are none, told by the GM if you need to eat for medical reasons pop something in your mouth and keep working. During days of inclement weather the try to force you to stay over to work. I stayed with Marriott all of 1 week. I have a CS and PR  background but since having a baby I have stayed home. I was looking for something to bring in extra cash for holiday traveling.  Fortunately, I was in a position to say "no thanks" to working in a place that cares so little for the employees.

job_title: Front Desk Agent in Kennesaw, GA
pros: Pretty fun, but management made it stressful
cons: Guests were difficult to deal with

pros: There are opportunities to work remote part time.  Most of the people are good to work with.  Decent benefits, but, those are being cut back.  Nice discounts on hotel rooms, when they're available.
cons: Outsourcing has destroyed moral.  Sr management is not in touch with employees below them.  The company is now being run by finance managers, from the CEO down.  It's all about the bottom line and wall street.  Cutting benefits, rising costs to associates.   They've lost the family core value management they used to advocate.

review_title: Not as Advertised; But don't complain it may cost you your Career.
pros:
Health Insurance including vision and dental
Hotel Discounts/Company Store
Self Assigned Online Training
Accumulate about 2.1 hours of PTO per week
cons:
Understaffed/Underpaid
Management speaks poorly about Company & Bosses. 
No Career Advancement 
No corrective discipline
High levels of Favoritism 
No appreciation
No more than a 3% Yearly Salary increase even for Hard workers
No merit increases
Associate Appreciation Week is only held for good scores on the Associate Engagement Survey that rates/ranks management & company 
Clock out for Breaks but still required to work due to no coverage 
No management on duty in the evenings; need to rely on one Supervisor who works all departments plus their own work/Guest issues at the same time
Management Delegates their jobs/work to Lower Level underpaid associates and then brag about it 
People threatening to quit constantly
Won't provide Discipline to hide turnover rates
HR is not on your side, & Not anonymous.  
Managers make their own schedules come and go whenever they want but get paid more than who's actually doing the work 
A lot of pressure

review_title: Used to be a people company, now the focus is all $$$ for corporate and executives
pros: Marriott was a company founded on an understanding of taking care of it's people so they would take care the customers. For many decades that was the case and may still be the case in some areas, but the tides have been changing since J.W. Marriott Jr. stepped down as CEO.
cons: A lot of senior leadership have risen to their positions based on tenure at the company, not necessarily based on expertise in their fields. This lack of expertise of people in powerful positions can and has lead to poor judgement and decisions on strategic directions, which in turn can and will have business ramifications far into the future.

pros: This company is excellent to interact with guest and your fellow employees.  You get the chance to build incredible relationships and learn a lot about yourself as you grow in this industry.  The founders guidance to "take care of the associate and they will take care of the guest" is paramount in getting people wanting to work for Marriott.
cons: A lot of who you know advance in the company; knowing this going in is great for those that are really into networking.  This is an excellent career choice, but you trade your chance to develop personal relationships with family, friends, and community to make it ahead.

pros: The best thing about this company is that if you're willing to be patient and put in your time and have ambition, you WILL be able to make a career with consistent promotions.  The work is busy, as with many positions in the hospitality industry, but it is fast and most days fly by.
cons: With this position, the hours can be pretty terrible and long.  You are paid hourly, and are considered an entry level manager without any previous experience.  You will no doubt be working a majority of the holidays (christmas, july 4th, new years eve) and have to work many Friday and Saturday night shifts which are the most difficult in terms of customer base.  Make sure to befriend your bosses boss, as he/she will be the one to propel you to another position after your program is over.

review_title: Employees all do their best to work together.
pros: Easy to move from one hotel to another within the company. With many of the locations in the US being corporate ran the transfer ability is simple and for managers they even pay for the moves up to $4000 in some cases and more for longer range moves.
cons: Hiring process seems to be a little skewed at times. There used to be a birage of interviews to go through and now if someone likes an applicant it only takes a nod from the general manager to push that candidate through. With the general manager not being fully aware of the persons qualifications, it can be a detriment to establishment when they are waived through the process.

review_title: Demeaning and Disrespectful management/High employee Turn over
job_title: Front Desk Associate in El Paso, TX
pros: Provided employee lunches, made sure you took your lunch.
cons: High turn over rate, Terrible management,

job_title: Front Office Associate in Palm Springs, CA
pros:
Discounts on hotel rooms.
Schedule flexibility
fun atmosphere
cons:
Low pay.  Most employees in tipped positions have never gotten a raise so a person with fifteen years experience is worth the same to the company as someone just off the street.
No room for advancement unless you move.  It is very hard to stay in one place and advance.  The company required you change locations about every two years in order to climb the corporate ladder.
incompetent middle management
little attention paid to feedback.  Every year they have this thing called the Associate Opinion Survey.  Every year we tell management the same issues and every year nothing changes
no loyalty.  If they need to cut costs, you're gone.  They've got to keep management happy
weak benefits, and expensive
There is definitely a lord vs. serfs mentality here.  The management rules the roost in all aspects of the business and if you get a poor manager you just have to suffer through it.  Fortunately, since they require you to move to grow, you only have to suffer for a couple of years.

pros: The overall benefits are the best thing about Marriott.  Flexibility on work location (at the office or at home) is a plus.
cons:
There are some nice people but finding ones you can honestly trust is difficult.  Many of the employees have been at Marriott for over 20 years and they don't care for many of the new employees.  Marriott states they need "fresh blood" to help bring them up to date compared to other industries, but when the "fresh blood" speak up, they're ignored and told "that's not how we do things here."  Well, isn't that why you wanted new hires, to NOT keep doing things the way they've always been done?

BEWARE OF THE PASSIVE AGGRESSIVE LONG TERM EMPLOYEES AND MANAGERS!

review_title: Traditional corporate, consensus driven environment currently focused on rapid growth
job_title: Senior Director, Marketing in Bethesda, MD
pros: Very busy - always, with good opportunity to get exposure to cross-functional areas.  Employees are supportive (not competitive) and helpful - always willing to give advice and opinions.  Long-tenured staff and highly networked with each other. Diverse. Good travel bene's. Good place to work when raising a family.
cons: Slow to change and reluctance of sr leaders to make decisions.  Very narrow definition of what successful people look like - creativity not always valued.  Growth opportunities slow down greatly after Director level.  Dilution of empl benefits in the last 5 years.  Major emphasis on growth at the expense of guest/customer satisfaction.  Not enough investment in modernizing legacy systems.

review_title: Del Rey didn't deliver on core values
job_title: Banquet Server in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
I loved Marriotts core values, "Success is never final" and "take care of your people, they will take care of you."  My experience at this hotel was poor even though I worked hard but I would give company another try.
The pay was good
cons:
The management didn't know anything about employees how people work.  I found it didn't matter how hard I worked the manager sided with the other staff because they were there longer.
If you didn't know Spanish employees won't like you, everyone there speaks it.  
There was no room for advancement or other training, as outlined in core values.
Other areas of the hotel could order food, manager wouldn't allow it.

review_title: Awesome experience, taught me that I can be better and expect more of myself, great people.
job_title: Customer Care and Sales Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Marriott gives great benefits. 
Starting wage is usually between 9 & 12 dollars/hr.
Always has some sort of benefit/fundraiser going on to help the community.
Maintains new opportunities for growth.
If you have issues with someone they have an open door policy. 
Paid training
Perks
Discounts
Total Compensation at high value
cons:
Can get repetitive
Can get boring if you don't stay active
long hours 
You have to bid for your schedule
If you have a change in school schedule, they don't change your schedule immediately (even with proof of school-work conflict) ; it cost me my job and it didn't matter the length I was there 1-2 yrs, or my review status of Satisfactory Performer, or the fact that I always took overtime to help the company. ((Still a good company))

pros: Marriott is a large company, and if you are a full time employee there are a lot of benefits including tuition reimbursement for students, 401k/401k match, health insurance, fun company events and amazing hotel discounts that will make you want to take vacations or staycations often. It is also very easy to transfer jobs to a different hotel if you would like to live in a different location or be a part of a different type of Marriott brand. It was also easy to become cross-trained and have a variety of different roles. Being around hotel guests was a rewarding experience and forced to me to develop a lot of valuable interpersonal and problem solving skills.
cons: In non-management positions there seemed to be a lot of transient workers (students, people looking for different careers, etc.) and not everyone took their job seriously. The pay was also not great, but tips in addition to wages made a difference. Hotels are always open, so you can not escape working on holidays. I was also often called on my off-days to try to fill in shifts. In my experience, management was a bit hands-off and not great at resolving conflict.

review_title: Get Rid of the Good Ol Boy Network
job_title: Director of Event Planning and Operations in Washington, DC
pros: Benefits package, tuition reimbursement, work locations, coworkers. As a new employee there are a lot of opportunities to grow and develop. Once you pass through the Department Head level positions there become more barriers to growth and development. There are great relationships with the peers that you work with on a day to day basis.
cons: There is a good ol boy network. Once you reach a certain level the unbiased job posting system is replaced by the picking and choosing of AGMs and Dir Ops for positions rather than by those within the hotels directly. Rather than picking someone with experience they move someone's friend from one hotel to another. The annual review process is a sham. Hotel leadership teams all get great reviews and increases while those below get a marginal 3% annual increase at best.

review_title: Marriott- They take care of their associates
pros: Marriott has many avenues within the company that one can pursue. I have encountered many dedicated & supportive people. This started as a job to get me through college and here I am 9 years later. You will work hard, long hours but in the end you are compensated. What keeps me is the flexibility I have with my schedule, and the people. Every place has its pros/cons but I strongly feel that the pros out weigh the cons at Marriott.
cons: It is a big company, politics, communication gets lost, sometimes you feel like you are just a number. It is your job to stick it out and make something of yourself. No free rides here. Long hours, especially if you work in one of the hotels- hotels are open 24hrs a day/ 7 days a week/ 365 days a year- weekends, holidays they are all just another day.

pros: Plenty of room for advancement! Open communication with my managers at all times. Family-oriented company. Diverse team!
cons: Not enough pay for certain positions and locations. People don't mind working their tails off to ensure ultimate guest satisfaction, but it wouldn't hurt to let your associates know that they are appreciated often. Don't wait until April or May to say 'thank you'. It's the little things that count!

review_title: I spent 7+ year drinking the Marriott Kool-Aid.  Recently left and I have never been happier.
pros: Marriott and Ritz-Carlton hotel discounts.  But unfortunately this benefit loses its luster when you are hardly making enough money to pay your bills and insurance but you are expected to work 50 hours plus per week.
cons: As a manager you are required to work 50 hours a week but are paid for 40.  Senior management and hourly employees get paid well but if you are a salaried manager your pay is way under market and there is no work/life balance.  The expectation is that you are to be available 24/7, work 50 hours a week - meaning 10 hours a day is the expectation.  This makes sense when there is work to be done but when you are finished with your work and are just sitting at your desk waiting for your 10 hours to be over this is totally crazy.  The benefits are more expensive for managers meaning that as a manager you work more and get paid less the those you are managing.  There are no bonuses or increases based off performance you are lucky if you even get a 3% increase a year.  The corporate office managers from afar and has no idea what is happening on property.

review_title: The brand itself is about giving each guests a personalized experience.
job_title: Staff Accountant in New York, NY
pros: Having the employee discount for all existing and future properties, discounts at local and majority department stores. Get to meet celebrities. Great salary, but it does depend on the location and the property's budget on exactly what your salary is. You get to meet and see very interesting guests from all walks of life.
cons: Training associates is limited. Hiring those who could actually benefit the property and brand is limited as well. For a giving open position there could be 20 applicants and yet the most inexperienced and questionable applicant is hired. The inaccuracy of their knowledge and training can add to a property already struggling. Hospitality is about hiring within and encouraging employees to reach for higher positions, however being able to be promoted in ones own property is looked over causing many of employees to stay in their position in a career that is not progressing. This will lower ones moral and work ethics. At a few properties the staff is not appreciated.

review_title: Great Company...would love to get back
job_title: Director of Project Development in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Benefits.  This company did a great job of managing costs of benefits and providing choices to working families.  They are LGBTQ friendly and have always been.  I worked there for 20 years prior to being laid off due to my division being closed.  Stay/Travel benefits are good and if you're able to relocate, the possibilities are endless with respect to your growth.  I had responsibility, accountability, was an individual contributor and managed people.  You can have any type of role that suits your career goals
cons:
the size of the organization can be an impediment to implement change.  Be it an operational change that affects the guest or even a business process change behind the scenes.  Change can be slow.

Annual Engagement Survey can come across as coercive and even though it's anonymous, mgmt reaction can be directed at individuals vs. addressing a root problem or cause.

job_title: Front Desk Associate in Fairfield, CA
pros: The opportunity to work for an elite and highly respected brand in the Hospitality industry. The ability to form relationships with frequenting guests and bonding with my co-workers, a good training program (although certain areas can be improved). The Manager in Training program would have been comprehensive, although I chose to seek employment elsewhere. Healthcare offered,  but when I waved it I was not compensated more in return.
cons: Barely above minimum wage pay for a stressful environment with above-average liability. Non-negotiable hourly salary. Guests can at times be a pain, but that is to be expected in any customer service environment. Managers had WAY too much stress for their salary in relation to their expected hours, I often felt bad for them.

review_title: Marriott the company is wonderful...management not so much
pros:
Full-time hours...
Decent benefits
Paid sick days
Employee room discounts great
Co-workers are wonderful to work with
Attempts of management to raise moral and make it fun appreciated...
cons: Low pay for the amount of responsibility required, two tiered staff the upper management and the  others...would comment further but will not use profanity, the rules are always changing I feel to suit which ever manager you happen to speak with, lack of respect from management to staff, I am a long time employee of 5 plus years, the daily JUNK mail that we receive in our mail box is not very green or socially responsible, pep talk prior to the yearly employee survey is laughable..very shallow, feel that management needs to be refreshed to improve employee moral, any large corporation that I have been involved in replaces management to keep the positive image of the corporation.  Our management team is very stale and needs new faces to improve the overall company image, and experience

job_title: Front Office Trainer in Little Rock, AR
pros: It allows you to have a great interim step between associate level and operations. It shows what taking on true responsibility is and how much you've truly grown since you've started. You start to see the things that you used to mess up on in other associates and it brings you great joy to not only be able to solve the issue, but also to be able to teach a new associate how things work. Do good, feel good definitely.
cons: Being in a leader/supervisor position isn't as rewarding as operations is. Most of the stuff the AFOM or FOM don't want to do just gets passed onto you. It's a great intermediate step between associate and management but there's that awkward feeling between you and your co-workers on where you stand in position of power.

review_title: Beware!!  This is as bad as it gets for an IT organization.
pros: You can work remotely with reasonable notice to coworkers.  On the other hand, you will be working seven days a week.
cons: Astoundingly inept project management in applicatoin development groups and shared services departments.  Zero lateral movement within the organization.  Once you are nailed into a position, whether you are qualified or not, you-are-stuck.  This place has all the "cons" you can imagine for an IT shop:  a mega-"hero" culture; no real planning or priority setting, consequently fire-fighting, panic meetings dominate activities; no training; no salary increases for three years; surprise layoffs and demotions.  In short, it's an IT sweat shop run by some of the most incompetent managers on the planet.

job_title: Rooms Operations Voyager in Washington, DC
pros: They have amazing opportunities if you want to grow as a professional (including tuition reimbursement), some of the best guests and employees in the world, and a vested interest in seeing you succeed.
cons: The amount and variability of the hours are a downside, but once you reach a certain leve, that ceases to be a problem.  Work hours are also very demand based, so if your hotel if full, you will be working a tight schedule, if not then you might have a lighter schedule.

pros: An Amazing company to work with. i had the opportunity to put the hotel together and to meet some key people. and if i stay i could've really see myself grow in the company. i got to work with incredible individuals.
cons: i waited to work with this company for two long years, unfortunately i went to property that wasn't even open up yet. that  comes with problems it self and a lot of things was very disorganize. lots of drama i guess because we all became friends before co-workers due to the fact with all work on putting the hotel together. we all knew each others business but the time it open. i work with a manager who wasn't meant to be a leader. he had absolutely  no leadership skill and should have never put in the position.  he was extremely petty and pushy and constantly told us he didn't care if they fired him.

review_title: Micro managed company, and extreamly over managed. Filled with people who did not get there positions by merrrit.
pros: They have not yet canceled the 401-K match.  They have dropped the minimum amount of hours to hold your benefits for the remainder of the year.  WE can have benefits no matter how little we work due to the economy.  Big thumbs up here!!!
cons: You are worked like slaves there, we work much harder and are treated worse,  and often  talked down too.  You have to sign a procedure for everything (mico-managed) I doubt if Nasa has this kind of treatment.  Cought managers lying and stealing money (that was to be given to the employees as a bonus) many times.  Our bonuses given by a client for the extra that we do.  Cash is given to a managager in an envelope for us, but we never see it.

review_title: Working as a Senior Cdp in London Parklane Marriotts 2AA Rosette
pros: Sterching over 3,000 properties and over half a million rooms spread throughout 70 countries around the globe, Marriott is one of the world's largest hotel management specialist. Marriott pocesses moderately-priced chains like Courtyard and Fairfield to the esteemed luxury of Ritz-Carlton, Marriott's broad portfolio of brands has something for every traveler. However, the firm specializes primarily in attracting business groups. Unlike many rivals, who are facing heavy capital expenditures to overhaul their properties and re-energize their brands, Marriott has already infused its hotels with fresh bedding and high-thread-count sheets. And many rooms have also been outfitted with high-definition TVs and the latest in connectivity technology for travelers with iPods and laptops.
cons: nothing much but still some usual guest comments regarding housing ,lodging and food issues which could be tolerated by offering some other valuable facilities and services to the guest in terms of "in house "service to compensate the araised complaints

pros: Marriott has amazing benefits. Great health insurance which is hard to find these days. Paid time off. Awesome hotel discounts around the world. And if you ever really NEED something the company as a whole will back you. Mr. Marriotts idea of investing in his employees is a great foundation for a company
cons: Downsides to working for Marriott has got to be lack of communication.  In 2016 technology has advanced MUCH further than Marriott is appreciating and it would be beyond helpful to guests and employees alike if the company would invest in upgrades in order to stream line things like what is included in each guests stay. And how they chose to use their elite status points. These are things the guests get frustrated with us over and there is no way for us to know them with the current "system" in place.

pros: There was a lot to learn with it being a very large hotel in downtown Kansas City. It's a 24 hour business and that can be exciting.
cons: I felt my time was undervalued. I was asked to work long stretches without a day off and often be the only manager for several different outlets in a 12 hour shift. There was very little in the way of corporate education which was something after speaking with former employees had recently changed or was not something that the downtown location utilized. I felt very "out to sea" every time I walked into the building and felt like I received very little practical support from my superiors. There also seemed to be great confusion about my actual job title. It changed 4 times in my first 100 days and I was never given a clear outline of what was expected of me.

review_title: Good if you just want an easy lazy job
job_title: Engineering Supervisor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good management training, Opportunities for growth and advancement if you are into moving around the country and a good room discount especially during holidays.
cons: Bad work-life balance and lack of willingness to innovate. Lacks new and a spirit of trying new things. The workforce is full of long time employees that think their way is the best and unique way and why to change. My manager constantly told me to do things using his KISS method. Keep it simple and stupid, in other words, don't try anything new. Also, at my 28, I was the youngest and I was constantly referred as a millennial and everything I did, it was an as the "millennial way".

pros:
- opportunities to upsell and make commission
- can be cross trained if you show interest
- moving up can happen quick if you work hard and there are opportunities to transfer to different hotels and departments
- good training for the software system
- open door system, can approach management
- upper level executives and the director of the front office are great and truly can be counted on when it comes to changing things for the better
cons:
- disorganized management team, not all on the same page
- lack of communication between departments
- scheduling is week to week and is never regular. you find out if you work on Saturday on Thursday, sometimes Friday
- low hourly wage
- expect to work holidays and weekends! there is a system for requesting off during the holidays, but nothing is guaranteed
- high turn over rate, there are always new people

pros: Well established company with a great reputation.  You can be proud working for Marriott.  Many folks who leave because the “grass is greener” come back. Work-life balance is good.  Hard work is encouraged but so is taking time for yourself.  Can easily make a career here once you get your foot in the door.
cons: Salaries throughout the company could be more competitive.  Must have political skills to progress.  Expect the same beaucracy that would be expected at any large public firm.  It can take years to create new positions for advancement or for someone to move on.   Senior management could be firmer to push for change.  The company is slow to change anything.  Communication between departments could be improved.

pros:
Overall, this is an excellent company to work for in the hospitality industry. Marriott management takes excellent care of its employees and plan several training opportunities throughout the year to engage associates and build stronger camaraderie. 

Marriott associates are known to stick with the company for a long time. In fact, if you are with the company for 25 years, you can stay at Marriott hotels for free for the rest of your life (great benefit!). 

There are many opportunities for advancement and you will find internal candidates are given priority, should they have the appropriate skills & experience, for promotional hire over external candidates.

Internal resources are numerous and you can always lean on a team member or review the materials on the companies' intranet.
cons: I experience this myself and hear this time and time again from team members - work life balance needs some serious improvement.

pros: Famous hotel brand in Canada
cons:
Poor management, a lot of managers are very rude to employees, only good for customers, treating employees very bad.
Managers like to cut costs and limit budgets. So even if you are full-time employees, you may only work 4 days a week, or one time they even told me work on call...excuse me, full-time position, it's not casual.
low salary, but a lot of paper work to do, sometimes no break.
Poor training system, they want you work like you already knew what to do even if you are a new employee. When you made mistakes, they blame you.
Weird internal relationship. They hire employees internally (not outside candidates) by how good relationship you have with supervisors/managers, not based on how many skills you have or your background.
Some lazy old employees, they might work for Marriott brand's hotel for long time, but they are very lazy and trying to bully new people.
High employee turnover rate.
Customers are always right, Employees are always wrong even if you do things correctly based on logic. No excuse, always blame employees.

review_title: Stay on top of your pay and hours
pros: Coworkers are friendly and nice but they work you like a dog. Did multiple weeks where I worked 12 days in a row with over 12 hours each day.
cons: Be aware of your money and pay. Marriott requires employees to have a 30 minute unpaid break if you work 6 or more hours in a shift, however if you don’t have time to take your break, they will still take out 30 minutes equalling 30 min of unpaid work. Another issue I’ve ran into is my PTO payout. It’s been over a month since I put my two weeks in and I’ve called HR multiple times and they don’t have any answers for me. That is 64 hours of pay they are skipping out of. I’m about to get lawyers involved. Do yourself a favor and skip Marriott. You would think that a huge company like this would take care of their employees but there’s a ton of scheming going on inside the company.

review_title: Largest In The Industry Means Opportunity
pros:
Working for Marriott International as part of the IT team is rewarding in that you get to learn something new everyday you work.  Don't know it, ask! There are no "stupid" questions when you work in IT since there is just so MUCH information to be learned. 

Working as a Flex Associate gives me all the benefits as a Full Time Associate including health care, stock purchase program, discounts, etc.   The main difference is a Flex Associate is an internal contractor.  I opted not to take health benefits because the current provider is not on MI's list.  No problem.  As a Full Time Associate, one is not given this choice.

Just depends where you are in your working career.
cons: Various "teams" who are responsible for a certain area in MI, do not go out of their way to assist customers, be it internal or external.  So when you work for MI, please be patient as some departments will hand-off to another department instead of asking more questions or assisting, just because the system is different.

review_title: Depending on what you are hired for, Marriott is a job with little to no room for advancement.
pros: Great schedule, friendly coworkers and some nice supervisors. Hotel room discounts are also a plus, though I rarely ever used it. 4myhr has a discount site where you can get discounts on computers, phone service, etc. We also had many informative meetings and competitions.
cons: Don't apply for an on call position!!! I was hired thinking I was a part time employee moving up to a full time position. I got a 90 day pay raise and that was it. On call workers are ineligible for any pay raises after a 90 day pay raise, even if you work forty hours and overtime. You also can't get any benefits or any paid time off. I averaged 35 hours a week for two years and my managers could care less that I wanted to move up to a full-time position. The food at our hotel was disguisting crap. Thank god I graduated from college and now have a REAL job.

job_title: Front Desk Manager in Kansas City, MO
pros: Great Benefits and core values. Great Corporate leaders. Clear vision and goals.
cons: The work at times can be overbearing but at end of day I love what I do. Globalized pay rates for staff would be great as it seems the your worth and pay varies depending on the market, but I believe a people first organization should keep associates pay the same or at least in competition with the large markets hotels and cities. Clear career paths that include mentorship for those wanting to advance there carrier and take it to the next level

review_title: Good Cop - Bill Marriott. Bad Cop - Management.
job_title: Front Desk Agent in New Orleans, LA
pros: Excellent insurance benefits. Free meals and uniforms. Paid time offs. You get paid attending trainings and treated like hotel guests with banquet meals. FEW genuine Managers and associates, mostly those who's been with the company all their lives.
cons: Not being given the right tools during training. You basically have to learn from your own mistakes. Training new supervisor hiree by a front desk agent. Territorial Associates. Training mostly done by their fellow Front Desk agent who refuse to share their knowlege. A lot of negative conversations behind ones back by Supervisors and Managers. Front desk associates leaving their posts whenever they want to but passing their probationary status and being paid the same amount as their dedicated associates. Career growth seems to be favorable for Whites and Blacks. Silent racial discrimination is felt regardless of their fair treatment policy.

review_title: I was misunderstood, judged, belittled and "thrown away."
pros: I absolutely loved working with my guests and majority of my coworkers (one's that did not target me with rudeness and cruelty). This was one of the first jobs I must say I enjoyed on a customer service level because of the amount of time required with the guests. This job really introduced me to a new understanding of customer service, thank you!
cons:
I fell victim to personal attacks, emotional abuse, and other acts of incivility by managers. 

On a different note, there is no effective training program at this location; the managers expect their coworkers to know what they have not introduced to the entire staff or what other coworkers may know.

review_title: Not a bad place...if you don't have big aspirations
pros: This company truly believes in team-building, and showing employees they have value to the company.  They engage in lots of fun events for the sales team, and do their best to make the company a fun place to work.  The company also greatly values diversity.
cons: If you're not in the Sales department, expect to be un-invited to fun events.  The majority of those hired in the sales department are entry level, have no professional skills, and are only there for the paycheck.  This makes it much harder on those who are there trying to do a good job for the customer.  The Omaha call center in particular provides little opportunity for career improvement.

job_title: Banquet Captain in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: They had many training and cross training opportunities. If you want to grow they will help you do so. I cross trained in 4 different departments and gained a lot of experience. Don't know if it is still the same but the management was great and the people in general were fun to work with. I enjoyed going to work everyday despite long hours and sometimes working holidays.
cons: No company is perfect and there were definitely a couple of managers that were not as reasonable or did as well empowering their employees as others.

review_title: Review for Spring Hill Suites Marriott
pros: I learned a lot about the hospitality industry. I have a lot more respect for the housekeepers and all of the other service workers that work so hard every single day.
cons: The lack of respect for the people who work so hard for the company by the management staff. Sometimes, certain rules and regulations would be put in place that were almost degrading.There is a lot of favoritism and it is hard for employees to move up in the company.

review_title: Review for Spring Hill Suites Marriott
pros: I learned a lot about the hospitality industry. I have a lot more respect for the housekeepers and all of the other service workers that work so hard every single day.
cons: The lack of respect for the people who work so hard for the company by the management staff. Sometimes, certain rules and regulations would be put in place that were almost degrading.There is a lot of favoritism and it is hard for employees to move up in the company.

review_title: Constant schedule changes leads to turnover which leads to more frequent schedule changes. It's a non-ending cycle!
job_title: Customer Care Specialist in Hollywood Park, Optional[TX]
pros: Option to work from home, friends and family discount on rooms is ok, potential to stay for free at select locations, lots of freebies/food for on-site employees.  Training was enjoyable and I have mad respect for the trainers that have to try to keep up the morale when half their classes quit before completing it.
cons: Don't expect to get time off to actually use employee discounts or free trips. Company feels that additional savings off hotel rooms during the winter is equivalent to a holiday bonus... it's not! Holiday work requirements frequently change so you'll be told you only need to work one winter holiday and then it will change with about 3 weeks before the holiday.  Don't expect any real coaching, it only happens once a month. Turnover rate is crazy high so schedules are always being redone, every 6 weeks to 3 months so it's hard to make long term travel plans.

job_title: Guest Service Agent in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Good employees to work with and lunch provided.
cons: They hired me and started to train me and my son got sick so I had no choice but to call in. Then I went back to work they never said anything. Then the day after my tire blew and I was thirty minutes late I notified my manager and she said to be safe. Everything seemed fine then I was trained for another 4 hours got called into the office and was fired. I asked why and they said because they could because it was my 90 days. Then I told them I know they made this choice to fire me and I don't think it's right. Then the manager then told me I chose this while raising his voice. I then asked what he meant because how could I choose to have my child sick or to have my tire pop and he said nothing they had a receipt from the tow truck and a doctors note. I felt discriminated against for having a kid. Horrible work place.

review_title: Good place to work in IT data center but might change soon
pros: Lots of interesting tech work and fairly flexible work-life balance and good vacation policies (but changing and not so good for new hires). Work from home for many techies. Employees are generally happy with the way it is run, good hotel discounts, and Marriott has been run like a family company with employees treated well.
cons: Very big changes are underway as IT outsourcing projects have been started so be aware of this if you are looking for a long term job as it might turn into a one year job, if they even hire at all because they might close off outside hiring in light of the consolidation and outsourcing ahead.  Given current events, for short term experience, it is good, but not long term which is a gamble.  Med insurance is available but not especially cheap.

pros: Quick to hire, possible paths to move up in the company, if you work hard they'll keep you through the winter. In my area where the winter months don't have alot of work that is important. For lunch you get free food. In my year and a half of working, I've seen 5 of my friends get promoted.
cons: Its a min wage job. It kinda sucks. Lots of noise in the kitchen. People yell alot. Its a fast pace environment. Alot of the servers and cooks mess up my dish area and I feel like they make it disorganized on purpose. There have been times where I got a small cut and I requested a work place injury report and management made me feel like a wimp/ baby.
