In the end I did get it, but I know others who have gotten small burns and didnt bother because they knew management was going to make them feel bad.

pros: The management are all very considerate and thank you at the end of each shift. The companies provide lots of benefits and opportunities for personal/professional growth (e.g. tuition reimbursements, Rosetta Stone) which all makes for happy and a hospitable work environment. The company's ethos is that if employees are treated well they will then treat the guest well and the guests will return. Annual employee appreciation weeks and regular special employee events.
cons:
Very limited on site parking, "official" employee parking is about 1/2 a mile in the garage up the street and theres no shuttle service to provide transportation to it. So if you work late nights it can be intimidating.

The price of the employee meals isn't worth the cheap crockery its served on.

You sometimes lose a sense of yourself and feel like a robot.

pros: Very nice people. Good benefits. Unionized. If hospitality is your thing, you can transfer to other hotels or with the proper allies to another department. If you love it, make a career of it. Most employees are lifers.
cons: Because it is unionized, it is very hard to get rid of bad co-workers. Management has little power to do anything. I also find that it is difficult to get coverage for time off. Technically you are given the days to use but many go unapproved due to lack of qualified coverage. Also, it's become clear that all supervisors and management are transient, whereas the team has most likely been there since the building opened. Finally, I have found that there are so many supervisors and managers covering for each others' breaks that you can never find your own sup/manager.

review_title: Customer Service and Sales Marriott Reservations
job_title: Digital Marriott.com Marketing Specialist in Omaha, NE
pros:
Excellent benefits with the associate discount at hotels.
Tuition reimbursement opportunities for associates.
Associates can qualify for healthcare benefits by working 30 hours a week
Shift differential for working later hours and weekends. 
Currently the direct managers tend to be "home grown" and are responsive whenever an associate has questions. 
Little to no micro-managing. 
Flexible schedules once you gain seniority within your position.
cons:
Upper-management seems disconnected with the hourly associate needs for support. 
Advancement opportunities are waning and management positions require prior management experience which is impossible without leaving the company. 
Many positions are becoming outsourced to international centers and outside companies to save on overall budgeting. 
Poor employees are not confronted and good associates are expected to do more work to compensate.

review_title: The JW Marriott is a nice place to work, but of course has its downsides.
job_title: SPA Concierge in Palm Desert, CA
pros: Good Benefits, transferring with the company easy, good about requesting time off (Flexable scheduling), paid weekly, great hotel and vacation discounts.
cons: Pay is terrible compared to competing resorts, communication is lacking, constant disorganization, incompetent management, no consistency, favoritism, too much gossip, associates talking down to others, dicipline principles don't apply to certain other associates, protocols do not get executed properly amongst others.

review_title: Great values, solid upper management, but limited growth in major markets
pros: Marriott places a great emphasis on taking care of their associates. While the retirement and heath care options are standard when compared with other companies, the discount programs available (both for hotel rooms and companies who partner with Marriott) and vacation time for associates who have been with the company for 5+ years are huge pros.
cons: The one challenge is for those management candidates looking to move upward within the major markets outside of Washington, DC. With limited roles that are highly contested, those who are mobile and can move around the company have the best chance of promotion within 2 years. Also, management is expected to work 50 hours a week, which can certainly affect work/life balance.

job_title: Manager, Sales Analysis in Bethesda, MD
pros:
The people are great at Corporate Headquarters. They're passionate about what they do and have a bright outlook for the company. Case in point, many associates have been with the company for 10+ and even 20+ years.
There are lots of things going on so you definitely won't get bored, but it's all mostly fun. Work-Life balance is great nonetheless.
cons:
Like many large companies, there's a lot of politics, red tape and silos going on. You need to know how to navigate all this in order to get things done and move up.
Also, what used to be a company with awesome benefits has become your regular Fortune 500 company with average benefits. Nothing sub-par, just average.

review_title: you still work for the Wentworth hotel as a bellboy and then housekeeping duties in the lobby
job_title: Housekeeping Department With Potential to Grow to Management in New City, NY
pros: I've always been interested in working in a big hotel like the Marriott Hotel to go up of the experience that I can learn in the housekeeping department, and supervising position I'm in an IVA position to learn and I also want to see if I can grow within via Corporation of America the Marriott Corporation.
cons: there are really no downsizing and you live in the country of the designer I think that the only thing that you should be doing just turn to grow within the corporate world of America I am very interested in working with this corporation.

pros: Marriott is accepting of and open to different types of people and lifestyles. There is great diversity within HQ and on property. They are great about allowing a work/life balance and flexible working options.
cons:
Marriott does not provide support for career movement or growth. There is a lot of talk around helping employees move ahead in their careers but when the time comes to receive the support, HR is very hard to get ahold of, management does not provide support or referrals to other internal management. There is not succession plan for employees moving up in their careers which makes it less likely that management will be supportive of an employee move.

Benefits are also sub-par. They are behind industry standards and do not recognize the amount of time and work each employee invests in this company.

review_title: Great Hotel Discount, Good Avenues for Opportunity
job_title: Internet Support Operator in Omaha, NE
pros:
Working at Marriott I have been given a chance to excel in my roles. It is a strong organization that isn't going anywhere soon, in other words great job security. They are a little behind on the digital age but are keeping up with if not setting the standard for hotel management chains.

Strong opportunities to promote in different career fields under the same company.

I couldn't see myself working for any other hotel chain. Period.
cons: I have had issues with age discrimination, and being taken seriously by management, which hasn't always been the case. The associate rate is almost never available, which high level management doesn't see as an issue. Not competitive pay compared to other companies in my area.

review_title: It all depends on the property
pros: -Room discounts, 401(k) contributions, some good employees, interesting guest interactions.
cons: Salary, poor work/life balance, upper management, depends on who owns the property.... can be challenging if they do not invest in renovations.... and then senior management questions your abilities if GSS scores are down..... while at the same time stating they know the property is not in good shape because of the needed reno.

review_title: Positive experience at Laguna Cliffs Marriott Resort & Spa (Food and Beverage)
job_title: In-Room Dining Server in Dana Point, CA
pros: Great managerial leadership within the F&B department.  Managers cater to employee attributes and apply where best suited, and further skill sets with hands-on training, advice, and demonstration.  The support (benefit) system of Marriott is well-established and applicable world-wide.
cons: Specific to Laguna Cliffs Marriott in Dana Point, CA:  Too much emphasis on lower quality at a higher price.  In the resort environment, especially in Southern California, prices are elevated to roughly match the going rates of the area.  Unfortunately, this specific Marriott undercuts most of its products/services while still charging rather excessive prices.  This leads to occasional customer dissatisfaction, and reduced brand loyalty that is so renowned with Marriott customers.

review_title: A great company to work for, especially for entry-level professionals
pros: Promotions offered regularly, along with may opportunities for spot awards (cash and kudos) as well as corporate-level awards if you can deliver exemplary customer service. And it's really not hard if you treat others the way you want to be treated!  The people you work with truly become like family and when you spend so much of your day with them, that makes for a great environment.
cons: Parking is challenging downtown on a good day and you will have to pay for a spot. This can be tough for part-timers. The testing you have to go through to get into a management position is a little crazy.  I believe your performance should speak louder than those timed tests.

pros: I worked for Marriott International for 10+ years and enjoyed my time with this company.  They have excellent hotel discounts, reduced meals for employees that work within a hotel, great opportunity to advance if you come in at an entry level position, and the opportunity to switch positions about every year to 18 months if you meet the qualifications for the position.  Life at Marriott sometimes seems like one big family.  You often run into former colleagues and many people work there for 10 plus years.
cons:
If you work in Hotel operations, you often work long hours and shift work.  A hotel is open 24/7 and sometimes you may be required to work late in the early or early in the morning.  You need to remain flexible.  

The higher you go up in your career with Marriott there may be less opportunity at the top.  Keep your options open and network.

pros: Really nice hotel expectations for the rooms and the up keep were great management is nice to you well at least to your face.
cons: As a housekeeper they were severly under staffed giving us 30 rooms a day or 20 plus check puts a day. If they like you they give you help. They dont split the boards up evenly someone will have all check outs others all stay overs. Linen is never stocked or clean. You start at 8 but dont get finished running around getting everything you need till 9-9:30 you cant leave till your done so your working long shifts cause all the extra rooms In which your suppose to get paid extra for but it's your responsibilty to check your pay check cause they dont pay you for it unless you notice. Worked there a month and still didnt have me clicking on and outI and my pay stub said I left at 3 everyday when I.was there till at least 5 and 7:15 at the latest.

pros: I work at least 40 hours a week

One of the maintenance men goes into the rooms before we are able to and steals our tips. I have continually been told that I will be able to move to front desk or breakfast, but they just keep hiring new people for those positions. The hotel that I work at is ranked 900 something out a little over 1,000 Marriott hotels. They blame the low cleanliness scores on the housekeepers. I could clean one room from top to bottom for four hours and it still would not put us any higher in the rankings. There are stains in all of the rooms, the walls are disgusting, and there is mold in all of the showers, but they just cover it with caulk. This hotel needed to be renovated years ago.

job_title: Food and Beverage in Syracuse, NY
pros: Not being held accountable for anything, not expected to do too much. SOME co-workers. SOMETIMES you get decent free food from leftover banquets, free lunch that is like high school lunches.
cons: Management, pay, guests, morale. Here you will experience the white male boys club to the extreme. They don’t care to add diversity in terms of gender or race and will do anything to defend each other even when their counterparts are clearly doing a terrible job and have no idea what’s going on.

review_title: Take care of your employees, and they will take care of you.....
job_title: Loss Prevention Officer in Cleveland, OH
pros: Teamwork and great benefits. Good PTO package and great co-workers, make you fill as one big family....
cons: Management is like us and them, micro manager's that are very lazy and not team players, sometimes very young....You can at times work very long hours with out even a break or lunch....Once you are with Marriott for years, you will max out in your hourly rate and not get an annual raise. Most annual raises are 30 cents, and you wont even get that, your wage is frozen at that rate until the market shows it has went up. All pay is market driven and averaged. Poor for your dedicated employees.

review_title: Upper Management has Personal Agenda, Empowers wrong managers
pros: Good benefits, discounts, training is readily available
cons: Marriott Cons: Long hours for management, not compatible with Millennial generation, company politics are extreme, management does not have necessary skills to fulfill their competencies. Property Specific Cons: New management has personal agenda to replace employees, wrong managers are empowered and take credit of others when convenient, big changes are not explained and only strictly enforced, low moral and engagement survey scores are not addressed and are ignored, tasks are delegated to lower management with out explanation and out of current job scope.

review_title: Marriott needs to pay more attention to franchised hotels
pros: I really enjoyed my department. The recreation team was so much fun sometimes it didn't even feel like work. My manager and supervisor were fantastic.
cons: They make you pay for the staff cafeteria whether or not you have religious beliefs that keep you from eating or allergies. The food they feed you is repulsive and poorly maintained. Maggots in the pop machine is just unacceptable.  The core values of the company are great but need to be executed better. Executive leadership seems to think they are an elite group and do not seem to care to much about staff. During the slow season your full time employment get cut to part time which makes it hard to live in Muskoka.

pros:
I was able to use my creativity
$40 rooms for you and your parents and $60 for your friends and extended family (better than hilton with $30 rooms for only you and the cheepest starting at $60 for your parents and siblings. 
Way easier to get a room for anyone you can go online and do it yourself rather than have to have the hotel picked out in advance, Hope that you do not get stranded somewhere on a weekend with no excess to get a discounted room becuase the two people that can give the room passes are only in the office monday through friday 9 to 5 and hope that you can cetch them in their office as you pass through (harley  ever does this happen)
Great health bennifits better than Hilton! Small co-pay
Free food from delievery 
discounts or free taxie service
meet people from around the world and build conncections
cons: alot of turn over in managment and desk staff

pros: Great benefits. Opportunity for advancement (if you're willing to move)
cons:
Marriott is a management company. They only own 10 of their hotels. Working for one of these 10 would be the best because they actually get the money to keep the hotel up to date and competitive.  There are Corporately managed hotels and Franchise Managed hotels. I work for a Corporately managed hotel, and our ownership group is reluctant to give up the money to keep the hotel up to Marriott's standards.  Also they could care less about the guest satisfaction as long as the hotel makes them money.  So obviously you can see the power struggle between Marriott management wanting to keep the guest satisfaction high and the ownership group being cheap.  

Also, Opportunity for advancement only if you're willing to move.  Most people have to constantly switch hotels to advance, which is not always ideal. 

And of course, dealing with guests that are terrible humans.

pros:
Opportunity for development if you are mobile and able to relocate. 
Food on Shift, Use of Leisure Facilities, Flexible working, Culture, Training.
Loyal and inspiring directors/managers who want the best for the company and you.
cons:
The associate discount is not competitive with other hotel companies. 
Unfortunately the Marriott Hotels in the UK have different owners. You can tell there are tensions between the Marriott people and the owners. Owners just want to see more profit and want to take people out of the structure, cut down on benefits, not spend where it is needed the most, just cut budget and payroll to zero. And this is forcing talent to leave the company. and untrained people to come in but no one there to train them. Causing Marriott to lose sight of the core values which make Marriott a great place to work. Too much statutory training - but not enough time/ people to complete the training.  All affecting GSS and Engagement Scores.

job_title: Houskeepng Supervisor in Palm Desert, CA
pros: Beautiful Brand New Hotel, Great Benefits, Amazing Employees!
cons: Nitpick on unimportant things! Need to realize the good with the bad to keep morale. Directors of departments need to be hands-on at least one time as employees think it's a bad quality. No business, no hours, no budget so for almost 5-6 months...NO WORK!  Seriously not acceptable.

review_title: Marriott is an awesome company to work for, though compensation is all over the board within departments.
pros: Marriott is very supportive of moving up within the company.  There is an infinite amount of training and information that is available to all employees who wish to take it upon themselves to learn more about the company, the standards of operation, advancing their career, dealing with personal matters in their lives,  etc...  The corporate culture is very rich throughout the company and everyone works to keep it in place.  Also, the company does a lot of charitable deeds within the community and for it's associates.
cons: The pay structure is not good.  If you unknowingly go in too low, you'll quickly be passed up, wage-wise,  by new hires with less experience, because once you're in it's a max of an annual increase of 3%.

review_title: One of the BEST Stepping Stones, to work somewhere else.
pros: Best reasons:  Consistency in rules & regs at the workplace.  There is a great Intranet describing positions WORLDWIDE that anyone can apply for if they wanted to move up or transfer.
cons:
Marriott uses all software programs, like Outlook, Excel, Word, that are ten years behind the latest versions.  This is purely institutional in its intent, and in my opinion, orchestrated so that employees cannot advance their skills TOO much, and abandon ship with their experience with MODERN software.  They are still using Office 2000.
BIG CON: NEPOTISM, FAVORITISM, and MORE NEPOTISM.

pros: Good company that values hard work. If you put in the time and work hard you can get promoted. Company is full of ground up success stories. Strong culture, service oriented and likes to promote from within. As long as you are open minded and willing to put in the time the sky is the limit so many routes to take within the company. Benefits are pretty good.
cons: With the bad economy hourly associates (non-management) have a hard time getting raises compared to when I first was hired with the company.  I would like to feel that I am getting paid based on my contribution to the company right now its based on your service years in your position. Good, bad, or ugly performance my raise is going to be the same. Sick time and vacation time are lumped into one. Don't use up all your paid time off on vacation or you will be in a bad position if you are sick or have an unforeseen emergency.

pros: Fun place to work. Get to meet and greet new people on a daily basis. Flexible when requesting time off. Pay is on par with industry in the area. Ability to learn many systems used throughout the hotel. Ability to transfer to other Marriott properties. Uniforms are supplied and cleaned at no charge. One meal, per day worked, is provided for free in the employee cafeteria. Very good medical and dental benefits. Great hotel discounts. After 25 years of service, you get lifetime room discounts. The list of good things just goes on and on...
cons: Not necessarily a Con, hotel is open 24 hours 7 days a week therefore many positions can have varied hours including working on holidays. Some high level corp management decisions are not ideal for all properties and can have a negative impact due to their cookie-cutter mentality.

pros: Marriott is an amazing company to work for!  First off, they offer great benefits. One of the best things about working for a hotel company was getting discounts on hotel rooms.  My dad has worked for Marriott as a general manager for the past 7 years or so and our family has always enjoyed some wonderful discounted vacations at Marriott hotels and resorts.  Another great thing about Marriott is that the company does everything they can to keep their employees well trained as well as giving them the opportunity to continue their education and follow their dreams.
cons: The only downside to working for Marriott was the insurance plans.  I didn't feel that they helped out as much as I'd want them to.  I broke a tooth one day, so bad that I needed a root canal and even with the insurance, it was going to cost me over $2,000.  As a college student, I just couldn't afford to do it so the tooth remained broken for almost three years.

review_title: Good company, but it's temporary for me
pros: Associate rates at hotels (depending on occupancy for the hotel), discounts at their restaurants and gift shops etc, nice benefits, overall good company
cons: For my position, pay is terrible but it is a tip job. Tips vary everyday but it makes up for the low pay at the end of the week, although there are days when it's slow and you'll see very few dollars go your way.

review_title: Great place to work and grow your career
pros: Excellent training and development programs.  Big focus on self development and on going development opportunities.  Opportunities to cross train in multiple departments and several different brands while growing your career.  The company makes it attractive to travel and see the world.  Strong values and culture that makes you proud to work for the company.
cons: The hours can be challenging since the hotel is open 24 hours you do not have a set schedule and will need to work different shifts in order to grow and learn the business.  In addition the hours can be long depending on which department you are learning.  Sometimes it is necessary to relocate in order to grow.

job_title: Night Auditor/Guest Services Agent in Portland, OR
pros: Great customer service values and experience. Awesome hotel benefits. Working for corporate I found is way better than franchise. Corporate has better standards and perform the values of Mr. Marriott himself. Treats employees well knowing that happy employees=happy customers. Flexible scheduling. Always room to move up within the company (hire from within)
cons: A lot of work and responsibilities for little pay. No set schedules. Hard to plan your personal life ahead of time. Alone at night, if you dont have good and alert proactive security overnight then its an uncomfortable unsafe work environment. Hard to find coverage if you need the night off. You have to stay late after being up all night if the morninh shift is late. Not very good communication because you dont see management or other department leads. No breaks (cant leave the desk).

review_title: A Great Company to Work For
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Bethesda, MD
pros: I've worked at Marriott HQ a combined amount of almost a year now and I still haven't met one person here that I've disliked. Marriott has a talent for attracting and hiring people that are genuinely pleasant to be around. I feel like my work is always appreciated.
cons:
Because Marriott is a great company that attracts a lot of talent, competition for entry-level jobs here is tough. Because of that, I think I'm being paid a bit less than the worth I've demonstrated (although everyone thinks they are underpaid so that's not an unbiased assessment). My work hours are also longer than the typical 40-hour week which, while not uncommon, is still a detractor in my mind. As an older company, technology here is also a bit behind the times and it can be difficult to get the tools you want.
However, for me the pros outweigh the cons.

review_title: Senior Director cringing daily in apathetic real estate/franchise develooment department
pros: Work is simple & accomplished quickly.
cons:
I'm not a minority so senior leadership in the franchise development group is comfortable using racist, vulgar language around me. HR is just the there to protect them. Potential franchisors/investors arrive for interviews & the unprofessional atmosphere is embarrassing.  
Inflated titles for realtors, unnecessary business trips, & questionable kickbacks for investors. Investors personal financial information is shared unnecessarily, printed and left sitting on printers, and emailed unsecurely. 
Fake titles like "Global President" are used to waste money buying unnecessary items like Superbowl tickets and the such while back at HQ we don't even have basic supplies. You'll find uneducated (literally no college) leaders who have had the same job for 20 years. 
No willingness to learn our new software since it would shine a light on how little work is required to accomplish tasks.  HR looks the other way about favoritism & hiring personal friends/children of personal friends.

review_title: One of the very best in Hospitality
pros: Marriott has a very positive reputation and they live up to that reputation.  They have a strong focus on their employee's moral and well being.  They are avid proponents of promoting from within and treating people well.  Fantastic benefits including, of course, very cheap hotel rooms all over the world at any of Marriott's 20+ brands.
cons: The primary 'downside' is the same downside you will find with other hospitality companies - pay.  It is not great compared to other, equally demanding, professions.  Also, depending on your position, you can work very long hours at very 'off' times.  Keep in mind that hotels NEVER CLOSE therefore, someone is always working and that might be YOU.

review_title: Great for a steady pay check, but little else.
pros: Steady work, job security. Good experience with customer service. Great discounts on hotel stays/vacation packages for both the employee and friends/family. Manager tries her best to get my requests for time off okay'd.

Management finds ample time to scold my performance for the littlest things wrong, but never gives a pat on the back when truly deserved. Sometimes have to remind management of materials needed to be ordered for Weeks until they finally order them.	Too much responsibility for too little pay. Certain male members of the staff treat me like an invalid because I'm a woman doing a ”mans job”.

pros: I loved meeting new people, making food food for our customers and serving them drinks when ordered in our bistro. I learned how to work with people and I learned a lot when I had to fill in on front desk when the staff was short. I also learned a lot by talking with customers that was in town visiting for different meetings.
cons: My cons were we never got a raise or appreciation for all the hard work. I still did my job because that is what was required of me. We would be short staffed a lot so sometimes no off days. We also had no benefits

Managers don't have any idea about what they're doing ,they got the position just because they are working there for a long time.
Salary is 9 cent more than minimum wage in Ireland, every single company will you pay you more.
You shift will depend on your performance, so be ready to be the first 6 months in the late shift (1.30pm until 10pm) even at the weekend.
No cantine, don't forget your food!
Worst company ever. If you are student or you don't have another chance to work, take it and escape as soon as possible.
Now with the SDM and the "exciting changes coming to Marriott" the conditions are worse and you will have to do more things in less time.

review_title: No work life balance, Excellent benefits
job_title: Senior Operations Manager in Columbus, OH
pros: Benefits are about as good as they come including medical, dental, and financial.  Working for this lodging company also has additional perks such as hotel discounts and a company site for all associates where you can get free discounts on countless items from sunglasses to locating a certified babysitter.
cons: There is ZERO work-life balance.  Marriott has gone from a company that invested in it's people to a company that works them to the bone and takes, and takes, and takes.   Unless you're an executive team member you will not be able to take time off that is part of your contract and annual pay; up to the point that you're not compensated for it.  If you're an exempt manager expect to work an average of 70 hours and 6-7 days weekly while the executive team members work about 40 and are not there during the times you need them most.

review_title: Not as great as it's made out to be!
pros:
- Some great people to work with
- good office location
cons:
- There are absolutely no chances of progression at all. Management keep piling more responsibility on junior staff, and there is no increase in compensation to match the level of responsibility expected.
- Poor management, no adequate supervision, have not had one single performance review since I started because they do not care about progression or training and development at all. 
- Pay is awful, and they try to make out the benefits of hotel discounts make up for this. The hotel discounts do not work on any of the nice hotels, and for the mediocre hotels, it works out about only £20 off which is rubbish!
- They want you to stay in your box and work on the same thing. If you have any bright ideas to improve processes or make things easier for your team and others, those ideas are quickly dismissed.
- Very old school mentality as flexible working is highly discouraged.

review_title: Marriott is family centered company that believes in taking care of their employees.
pros: Marriott has a very family centered corporate culture.  Employees seem to stay with Marriott for many years, which I think is a true testament to Marriott's ideals of promoting employees within the Marriott Brands.
cons: The income potential seems to be lower than the competitiors.  When working at a smaller Marriott property you are given more responsiblitly within your job function without the reward of higher pay.   The other downside is accruing PTO as you work instead of having 2 or 3 weeks that you can take any time after your 90 days of employment with the company.

review_title: If you look for being considered a human....go somewhere else
pros: Employee rate in luxury hotels....when available
cons: You are a number. End of the story. Working here will end in you being burned out, belittled, bullied depending who your manager is. Don't try to report to HR, if you're lucky they will just smile and tell you to take a few days off. Otherwise,  anything happening is your fault because you misunderstood (obviously being a non native speaker has its perk to cover bullying). No career progression, unless you know the right person and smile. Thinking out of the box is not allowed or even considered a skill. You do what you've been asked, no question. God forbid you suggest an easier, more efficient way to complete a task. Nobody knows who does what. Questions are not answered, and you'll hear angry customers who are absolutely right, but you are unable to assist them.

review_title: Hospitality can be a rewarding field if the career title is kept up front.
pros: In broad strokes, some of the best things about working with this company are, potential carerer growth in field, competitive benefits package, travel discounts, global footprint.  You can travel, and work, almost anywhere in the world once you are a regular associate, with expenses like education, healthcare, money management, and various types of life assistance, shared by the company.
cons: Marriott has shown good growth potential, even in the economic down turn.  While this is good news for investors, for employees it has meant adaptation to a numbers driven, stress and compress business model, which in some markets has lead to a 90 percent turnover rate.  There also appears to be a disconnect between corportate growth solutions and product day-to-day operations

review_title: If you're OK with being part of a large organization, this place is the best.
pros: Marriott has earned its reputation as a world-class organization.  The benefits are terrific but even more is the spirit to serve that is imbued in each employee and manager.  The selling point of "People are our best asset" that has become very common across domestic companies these days has become overused and almost void of any meaning but with Marriott, it is actually true.
cons: Very bureaucratic environment and not a lot of room to be creative.  There is the right way to do things, the wrong way and the 'Marriott Way'.  If you want a free hand with how you carry out  your duties, than Marriott is not the place for you.  Managers have a tendency to micro-manage and in some cases, be very petty with how you communicate.   Expectations are often made clear to you after the fact, not before and usually to your disadvantage.

pros: Decent salary but they do offer benefits. Clean environment and opportunity to grow. Great managers. Didn't like eating in the cafeteria and the computer system there is terrible. I felt I could be better suited for a different area, but you have to kind of just take whatever Human Resources thinks you're suited for to begin with. But I would give it another go if I were offered.
cons:
It can be slow at times especially on the graveyard/late night shift. So if you're antsy, I wouldn't suggest it. They changed my schedule a lot so it was "go to bed after late night at work, and then get back up and go back.....and then just CRASH!" 

I believe in employment, but I have other goals and I felt like those went to the way-side for a direct deposit.

review_title: Corrupt, abusive, harassing, discriminatory, patronage oriented New York Marquis Loss Prevention Department
job_title: Loss Prevention Officer in New York, NY
pros: The pay and because of that people are doormats. If you are a slave to money then this is for you. Management likes weak uneducated people who need a check and "lay down."
cons: Horrible New York Marquis Loss Prevention Management team. They play bias favorites. Everything is about favors and who know who. So don't bother applying because they always gonna hook up some buddy who is a cop or friend with this job. There is no equal opportunity. They post and waste your time interviewing when they always give the job to somebody waiting as a favor. If you do get the job be careful, keep a daily diary of what happens to you. Management believes in favoritism, nepotism, harassment, discrimination, petty games, targeting, fraternization and the list goes on. And don't expect HR to do anything for you. They know nothing. You probably know more about human resources then they do. Don't expect corporate to help you either. They only respect a law suit. Trust, they have many of those on New York State Courts public record.

job_title: Banquet Server in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
At Marriott we embrace a unique code of service we call “spirit to serve”. We believe it’s essential that each of us do our part to make a difference in the lives of others, whether it’s our fellow associates, customers, business partners or neighbors.

Marriott offers a competitive compensation and benefits package that you’d expect from an industry leader and we provide the programs and resources that help our associates achieve a true sense of satisfaction – on and off the job.
 
In keeping with our associate-centered culture, Marriott’s benefits package includes:

   1. Medical, dental, life & disability insurance
   2. 401(k) retirement savings plan
   3. Continuing education/tuition reimbursement
   4. Ongoing training and career development programs
   5. Work/family programs and services
   6. Discounts on hotel rooms, food & beverage
cons: Dealing with annoying,upset, and stuck-up customers.

review_title: Breakdown in communications between supervisors and employees made this otherwise lovely place to work a complete pain.
pros: They have great meal plans, great uniforms, great benefits, and they are very supportive, but in a 'fake' manner. It is refreshing for a company to empower employees to make decisions on how to treat guests without having to fill out form after form - they treat you like you are a smart competent worker most of the time.
cons: the supervisors and upper management have NO idea how to work any software, and they view each situation 'on paper' instead of taking into account how the customer was feeling at the time. They became incredibly angry when mistakes happened due to a breakdown in communication, not a mistake by any one employee.

review_title: It's a great job that's why I live the job geart co-workers. Love the hours they train you good pay.
job_title: Banquet Server in College Park, GA
pros: Love seting the tables love meeting new people and seeing about the customers and making them very happy. I love doing this job. I have been trying to get back in this company for years I was there form 08  to 2010. Love this company.
cons: Making sure you have everything is set up the way that the customer ask for it to be set up. U have to read the beo for every room u set up that's why I would love to work back with this company.

review_title: A great place to work if you can handle the stress of irritating guests and making your goals.
job_title: Reservation Agent in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Challenging work environment with high goals.
Going to hotels at a discount or for free.
Great healthcare rates.
401k and profit sharing.
Great coworkers and managers.
cons:
Fierce competition between coworkers causes some jealousy.
Dozens of people going for one management position every six months.
Attendance policy is so lax that it is a joke.
The training department is severly lacking and there is very little recurring training.
It is difficult to take the job seriously because we see very little of the income that we generate.

review_title: Let's not all make assumptions shall we
job_title: Peon, Also Known As A Housekeeper in Foxboro, MA
pros: Good hours. For the most part they'd allow time off when needed. Holiday party that, despite being during work hours on work property, was pretty fun. Turkeys for the holidays was pretty nice.
cons: Work long hours for little pay. Managers sit on their butts all day (or take naps in guest rooms during business hours, to which the housekeepers have to clean AGAIN). Hiring buddies takes precedence over advancing employees with seniority. Advancing family members to higher management positions, while competent employees who've worked there longer and harder are passed over. If you're not buddy-buddy with higher management, you won't go anywhere in the company.

review_title: Let's not all make assumptions shall we
job_title: Peon, Also Known As A Housekeeper in Foxboro, MA
pros: Good hours. For the most part they'd allow time off when needed. Holiday party that, despite being during work hours on work property, was pretty fun. Turkeys for the holidays was pretty nice.
cons: Work long hours for little pay. Managers sit on their butts all day (or take naps in guest rooms during business hours, to which the housekeepers have to clean AGAIN). Hiring buddies takes precedence over advancing employees with seniority. Advancing family members to higher management positions, while competent employees who've worked there longer and harder are passed over. If you're not buddy-buddy with higher management, you won't go anywhere in the company.

pros: Marriott has a wonderful culture. People are very team oriented, supportive and encouraging. They are open to sharing their wealth of knowledge and you know it's a great place when you have so many for-lifers who have climbed the ladder over a span of 20-30 years. You also have great perks - benefits are top notch plus you add in the associate discount for hotels. You can't beat it! Everywhere you go, there's a Marriott hotel so it means growth potential like crazy, plus a footprint you and your family can take advantage of.
cons: It's a huge, complex company with a lot of bureaucracy but it comes with the territory of being such a large company. Compensation is not in the higher percentile but they make up for it with work/life balance, family emphasis and great benefits.

review_title: Good atmosphere but very hectic place to be in IT
job_title: IT Build Member in Bethesda, MD
pros:
Many very intelligent and motivated people around you.
Cordial and polite atmosphere, slightly formal but not overly so.
A wide range of things going on, many technologies in play.
Prestige from working at an industry giant.
You're working for an end user so there's no pressure for business development.
Company is stable and always has cash for initiatives.
Excellent corporate headquarters facilities.
cons:
Projects often drag on for years and  seldom provide the promised benefits.
Overambitious management has embarked on many simultaneous changes.
Heavy use of service providers has degraded team spirit in recent years.
More of a "seniority-ocracy" than a meritocracy; takes a long time to move up.
Interdeparmental rivalries often make for suboptimal progress on projects.

pros: They're a big, international company so opportunities for advancement abound, & the benefits are very good. If you're passive aggressive, you'll fit right in.
cons:
Chaos reigns @ HQ. Due to an overabundance of duplicative responsibilities, decision making suffers, and projects constantly scramble at the last minute to accommodate a shift in the slightest breeze. 

Business serves IT, rather than a partnership. IT motto is, "If a person can do it, why have a computer". Ancient systems require manual data entry of identical information when automation would reduce risk, time and effort. But IT doesn't want to pay to automate because it costs the hotel owners money to pay someone to do the data entry, rather than Marriott to write a little bit of code. It's a shell game - your fees are lower, but you're paying employees to do stuff a computer can do. 

Paternalistic culture means you can't say  no to Daddy.

review_title: Tossed to the curb after renovations
pros: Great benefits and I felt like part of a big family, when I first started working there.
cons: After a so many years, they freeze your pay. But they will give you a lump sum for doing a good job with your review. I was there for over 20 years, but since I'm an older person with a few aches and pains. They decided that I wasn't good enough to keep me employed with them. They would rather have a younger person working for them.

job_title: Recreation Attendant in San Antonio, TX
pros: Workers at the Marriott are amazing people in all departments. Exceptional pay and it is an experience, especially for a first-time job. Great hours but you must be a hard worker to work here. Supervisors are great with scheduling and most are lenient with shift switching.
cons: If you aren't willing to do the work for your money, do not apply here. If you aren't a people person, save yourself the time and do not apply. The Marriott is an amazing brand and truly values it's employees and guests. The most inconvenient part of this job is that the schedule is weekly, showing your hours for Saturday-Friday. The issue is that the schedule goes out on Thursday's so you won't know your availability for the weekend until days before.

pros:
The people that you work with are friendly and I've built lasting relationships .
I've met plenty of people outside of the hotel, that have come in for events and connected professionally with a lot of these people.  Its a great job for meeting the right people to take you somewhere in life.
cons:
Turn over is extremely high
Management sometimes asks a lot and a common theme within the team is not feeling appreciated
Since we are in a department by ourselves and don't really have a specific manager to answer to, no one understands our frustrations or even cares to know us
Competition is crazy if you want to move up in the company

job_title: Group Sales Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: The people and leaders are kind, hard working, and awesome! Marriott has a great team atmosphere. It feels like one big family!
cons: Pay is low, work load is high, & 10 hrs a day is ridiculous!! Managers at Marriott work a minimum of 10 hrs a day for at least 5 days her week... the pay is so much lower than other hotel companies!! 8 hrs per day needs to be the new standard. You basically expect everyone to be a workaholic.

review_title: A lot of potential wasted due to bad management and inability to hold people accountable.
job_title: Conference and Banqueting Supervisor in Bristol, England
pros: Good opportunities due to the size of the company. Huge choice of brands to work for currently. Good training opportunities in your own time on Marriott Global Source. A lot of good employees and potential lifetime connections.
cons: All properties are obviously not the same but I had the unfortunate luck to work at one of the "good old boys club" properties. Total stagnation and suffocation of ideas by senior management who had been there for years and years. Managers playing favorites with certain employees. Bad hires, bad decisions made by bad hires. Unwillingness of HR to assist associates to fulfill their aspirations.

review_title: Not the best not the worst
pros:
They feed you breakfast from their Buffett everyday
The pay is pretty good
cons:
They are particular about the wrong things.  
The uniform u are required to wear is humiliating 
The cleaning staff and janitors work just as hard as everyone else and are treated like they are nothing

job_title: Housekeeping Team Lead in Columbus, OH
pros: Upper management is friendly to all employees, great global reputation.  They give empowerment to even the lower level employees to correct customer service failures.
cons: Limited career growth.  I took an entry level position as my first full time job after graduating college with a hospitality management degree.  After 10 months at my position I started applying to some open positions that were just a step above what my current position was and I got passed over each time for someone who didn't have a degree but had been working at the hotel for 5+ years.  I understand the value of experience but I don't have 5 years to waste making barely above minimum wage.  So I switched to another company and after 4 months I was promoted and now make twice what I made at Marriott.

job_title: Food and Beverage Attendant in Anaheim, CA
pros: They like to give overtime, especially in busy season which is may-august.
cons:
They will over work you, I once had 3 doubles back to back for three days. The staff is rude and they need to replace half the people that work their. Some people have been their over 5+ yrs and will never move up or go anywhere and are so stuck that they can only do a certain amount of work its ridiculous. Everyone complains all the time

Management de-powers their supervisors by undermining them and their decisions. They dont let supervisors  do the necessary disciplinary actions to get certain other employees out of their. They also basically let the people under supervisors do whatever they want rather then holding individuals responsible .

job_title: Reservations Agent in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: They are very flexible with your need for time off. Their attendance policy is very useful, once you learn how to work with the rules. The benefits are awesome, expensive, but awesome.
cons: There is very little opportunity for promotion. You are stuck on the floor, unless you are a mindless and uneducated worker bee. There was also very little communication from upper management. The employees come in three categories, those that are there for a short time, uneducated people who are there because they can't get anything better, and college students. If you are a college student, don't expect a promotion. Also, very few people actually get to the hotel they want, if they get to a hotel at all. If you want to be at a hotel, you are better off to start there. Once you get to a certain pay you will not likely to get them to pay that at a hotel.

review_title: A great company to work for, the Marriott family gave me the necessary foundation to begin my career!
job_title: Lead Guest Services Associate in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Very flexible on schedules, very forgiving, family environment, everyone is exceptionally nice, loved working here. Once you get in, you're in for the long term. Great benefits including discounts on phone providers, centralized online HR makes it easier to manage benefits, the Company offers a lot of help, including tuition reimbursement, etc. They really care about what their employees think. Managers have the incentive to keep their employees happy as the management gets reviewed on a yearly basis by employees worldwide.
cons: Low salary compared to other places in the area, In the recent years, the Company had become less forgiving due to the recession. It used to be that no one would ever get fired, now they were more strict. The hotel is small so not a lot of room for advancement.

pros: People are nice and knowledgeable.  Certain departments permit telecommuting.  Health insurance is pretty decent.
cons: The PTO for new hires is laughable, as you start out with 12 days.  Not sure how this company can be rated top by working mother magazine!  As a working mother, 12 days are not enough. Then they also decided to get rid of the "Borrow Leave" policy.  So you have to use all your prior year leave by June 28, only get 12 days, cannot borrow any leave, thus have no PTO available for when your kids are on summer break.   I'll be leaving this company next year.  There are better places out there.  Marriott had the reputation of being a great employer, but that certainly will fade, as more of the older people retire and new people with the same crappy benefits are hired.

review_title: Started off well, then when we got a new GM things started to get worse
job_title: Night Auditor, Front Desk Agent, Manager On Duty in Chattanooga, TN
pros: Benefits were awesome and fairly priced The people that I worked with at the front desk and with on overnight were awesome. The GM that hired me was by far one of the best GMs I worked for.
cons: pay was very low compared to other night auditors at different hotels...also worked there for 3 years and only a $.50 for 3 years!?!? Always came up with bogus things on my review so I wouldn't get a raise, management-they would only work 9-5 M-F as soon as the clock hit 5 they would be gone didn't matter if we were busy or not, they did not care about employees at all

review_title: One of the Best Companies to Work for...
job_title: Sales and Service Associate in Omaha, NE
pros: Flexibility - I have worked on property, in a Regional Office, back on property, and now from home.  It is important to treat the company you work for as your second home.
cons: Good positions can get quite competitive. You really need to just put yourself out there and perform your best.  Goals can sometimes be quite difficult to achieve. Some superiors do not share the same mentality as most upper management. I have just been lucky enough to have mentors and bosses who are supportive and share the same passion as I do. Some other colleagues are not as blessed.

review_title: It was a good temporary job
job_title: Guest Service Representative in Harrisonburg, VA
pros: The hotel discounts for all members of the staff is one of the best perks of working for Marriott. The job itself, wasn't bad, and they do allow for you to stay and move up. I worked at a franchise location, so I'm sure it really varies a lot by property.
cons: It probably really varies by property, but at our specific property, the management was new and at times, we knew more about the system than they did and how to interact with the guests, but were never given the credit. I knew it was a temporary position though so it didn't bother me as much as other people who were making it into a career.

job_title: Rooms Operations Voyager in Detroit, MI
pros:
-The hotel discount is the best benefit. Although as of late, discounts aren't available in the cities that you actually want to stay in during the dates that you actually want to be there. 
-Health, 401k, profit sharing are all good benefits offered.
cons:
-You will not receive the proper training needed to perform as a manager, but will be expected to perform at the level of a fully functional manager who has been doing this for years and years. 
-People at the property will have no idea what a voyager is or what to do with you. Good Luck trying to get through your voyager course work. It is nearly impossible to d when you are thrown to the wolves and expected to run shifts as a voyager before you get all of the training. 
-Not paid enough for the number of hours you work.
-management required to word 10 hours a day. Average work week is more like 60-65 hours a week.
-upper management is far too disconnected with the day to day BS that you deal with.

pros: In the hospitality industry, Marriott is a recognized name that looks good on anyone's resume. They're good operators and odds are, most people either have worked for or know someone who worked for Marriott.  Benefits are decent (have gone downhill), pay is slightly below industry average. They still have some very good people that work there and they work very hard at maintaining their image. Culture is VERY important to them; they talk about it a lot and it's more than just talk.
cons: It seems to me like they've lost their way a bit. They're VERY focused on social media and image, but would do well to retain that focus yet remember what made them the giant that they are.  They talk about work life balance and taking care of their employees, and while they're better than some companies the work hours can still be quite long.

job_title: Food and Beverage Associate in York, England
pros:
Great culture, very collaborative. My time there was like being with a big family, many of whom I still keep in touch with

Plenty of options for training, moving to different departments, and moving up the company

Discounted room rates
cons:
Ambiguity for bar staff when closing the shift. We didn't have an official closing time so we were left to argue with the nights team every evening about whether we could go. This often resulted in us starting at 15:00 and not leaving until 03:00-04:00 with only one 30 minute break. This is particularly frustrating when you can see the nights team on bbc/ social media on the computers in the office - they are more than capable of assuming responsibility of the bar. 

Pay isn't great.

review_title: Great Job, needs to pay more!
job_title: Front Desk Agent in Houston, TX
pros: The best pro is the family you make when working at a hotel. The best co workers you will ever get are in the hotel business. I have worked all over the United States for Marriott and no matter where it is, the people are just simply amazing.
cons: Need to offer higher wages! Poor housekeepers and back of house workers make minimum wage and its hard work HARD work. Bending over scrubbing tubs and showers and toilets for $9 an hour and half these ladies and gentleman are grown adults with children. Shame on you Marriott for allowing such low wages. TARGET pay starts at 11 an hour base pay. These people deserve more. Bill Marriott used to say, "TAKE CARE OF YOUR EMPLOYEES AND YOUR EMPLOYEES WILL TAKE CARE OF THE GUEST". Please live up to this.

pros: I was with Marriott for many years.  The education and knowledge gained over those years was phenomenal.  I met and worked many wonderful people and some not so wonderful.  Marriott took very seriously the integrity of customer information and went to great lengths to ensure personal data was protected.  The benefits we’re very good.
cons: Senior Management put on a good show of cohesiveness, but in reality most of them could not stand each other.  It was like watching a pack of wolves fight for the leftovers.  If you we’re marked badly from above your career was finished within Marriott.

pros: quiet during the night hours, not super busy,
cons: Hours, no bonuses, alone, 3-11 usually leaves the hotel a mess for me to clean, yet they are never corrected for not doing what is on the checklist.

review_title: Quality work environment with quality employees, for the most part.
pros: Great potential for internal growth if you work hard, and establish strong working relationships with your peers.  They also offer excellent benefits.
cons: Company tends to rely too much on the resume/credentials of their employees when hiring/promoting, rather than the quality of their work.  A lot of quality employees get looked over for Management positions just because they haven't paid thousands of dollars to take a certain test, or for an extra degree.  It seems like the common saying, "you will learn exponentially more actually working, than you would in any book," does not always apply.

review_title: Great place to gain world class experience!!
pros: Big multi national corporation, lots of training options. Access to a large amount of information, an answer fr every question, very professional. Company culture. Training from the bottom up. Good company benefits.
cons: Advancement is next to impossible without someone leaving and this could never happen. Salary although not bad could be much higher in a smaller chain/private hotel. Advancement becomes a waiting game of who gets caught and ''recommended for termination'' first or outworks/lives (decades) the others. Also I don't know the ''PC'' term for this but being ''best friends'' with senior management is the easiest way to get promoted.

review_title: MARRIOTT is great, NOT White Lodging.
job_title: Front Desk Agent in Austin, TX
pros: Phenomenal company if you are pursuing a career in hospitality.  There are a multitude of positions that you can work your way around, and a variety of hotel types so that you can find your niche and hone in on your skills from there.
cons: Unfortunately, some Marriotts are owned by White Lodging, and it is THAT company that is not the greatest to work for.  If I were you, I would research whether or not the Marriott you are working for is owned by White Lodging, and if it is, high tail it out of there.  Promotions/advancements are far and few, and benefits are rarely seen.  It doesn't seem as though they take care of their staff as much as it first appealed to.

pros: I worked for the courtyard by Marriott the hotels are beautiful and all the staff and hotel guests are so nice. The pay is great, the benefits are great and the perks are amazing. You get access to the company website and can get discounts for anything and everywhere. Plus being with them you can transfer anywhere in the World to live and work and you get discounts on rooms for any Marriott chain as low as $30 a night. Best job to ever have they provide uniforms and food and you can make crazy tips. They treat there guests and there employees like gold.
cons: Very fast, always be pleasant and follow the rules.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Tysons Corner, VA
pros: Great benefits, some good people to work with and build relationships with. Company as a whole was good.
cons: Management from the top is very cliquey and doesn't try to hide the fact either. Very disorganized in terms of keeping the different departments to monitor and keep up with their own needs. After understanding that nothing that is brought forth to management is never really taken under advisement you start to just do your time until your able to get out of the property. Its a revolving window of people just using this specific hotel as a standby hotel, until they are able to post out and get to a better hotel with a lot more structure and business.

pros: It's very hands on at times which teaches you good work ethic and to appreciate your employees. You learn various aspects of the property rather than just the position you're placed in.
cons: You could be hired as a manager straight out of college rather than this lengthy program that doesn't exactly follow what they tell you. I was placed at the front desk and was told I'd be visiting housekeeping, bell service, and client services but never left the front desk because they're ALWAYS shorthanded.

pros: Marriott offers endless opportunities for growth and personal development in your career.  I worked at Corporate Headquarters for 8 years and it truly was the most outstanding experience of my career. Movement within the company is encouraged.  Leadership is strong and assists you in developing your skills. The work environment is positive and the tone at the top focuses on excellent guest service. The "Spirit to Serve" is alive within Marriott!  With that focus, everything else falls into place!
cons: Competition at such a great employer is tough, but that encourages you to sharpen your skills to remain an excellent candidate for new opportunities as they arise.

job_title: Director of Sales & Marketing in Marco Island, FL
pros: One of the most ethical companies in the world. Period. You'll never have to apologize. The company puts it's associates first. In my twenty two years with Marriott I've found Training, communication, opportunities, loyalty are just some of the elements that make this company so great to work for. In a business world where companies struggle to keep employees, loyal customers and be financially successful, Marriott continues to deliver.
cons: Some chains pay more. When Marriott people leave because they think the grass is greener, they usually come back. If you are looking for a management job where you want to punch a clock at the end of the day and never think about work until you return. Forget it! It gets in your blood.

job_title: Night Auditor, Front Desk Agent, Manager On Duty in Orion, MI
pros: If you are in college it is easy to get morning or night shifts that won't interfere with your school schedule. 7am-3pm, 3pm-11pm, and 11pm-7am. Discounts at Marriott hotels, week paid vacation after a year of employment. Easy to request days off. A lot of down time to do homework.
cons:
Every hotel is run a bit differently so these cons may not apply to all Marriotts.
There is only management at the hotel betweel 8am-4pm; it is rare that they stay any later than that; because our hotel is small it is one person on each shift so there are a lot of times you are the only person at the hotel. Open 365days a year so you can expect to work holiday's.

job_title: Front Desk Agent in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
- Pay is competitive, 
- You meet some great people
-Job itself is pretty easy
- Great company overall
- benefits
- Time off flexibility
cons:
- Scripts, scripts scripts
- Training ( Trainers) Lacked, received better training from co-workers
-Management has no patience. ( if you can deal with micromanagement to a T & irate managers walking around huffing & puffing, go for it)

pros: You get discounts to stay at pretty much any Marriott anywhere (with advance planning) and it's not one of those "boring desk jobs". You get TONS of customer service experience and learn something new daily. Great for college aged kids not looking for a career but a respectable job.
cons: It's hard to get those discounts sometimes, and can be hard to get off on the weekends naturally. Marriott doesn't give its employees enough "reward" or benefits, so make sure it's a hotel with a good management company. There will ALWAYS be be turnover in hotel business, it's just not a career, so be prepared for change in management in employees IF you're even there long.

pros: Travel Benefits, PTO, Health Benefits. Global, stable business model.
cons:
Complacency runs at HQ. Many people have been in their job 10+ years and don't look to do anything different. Everyone wants to do "what was done last year". Stale environment. 

Hard to get any decision made without having 10 leaders give their opinion. Meetings about meetings. 

Leadership goes into meetings without having first looked over the presentation, then asking 10 follow up questions that are needed right that second. In addition to that, endless ad hoc work from ownerships as margins are declining. 

Favoritism and waiting your turn to get promoted is the only way to advance your career at HQ, work product is supplemental but takes a back seat.

pros: Great image and reputation, traditionally, the company has offered great benefits, the employee discount rate at hotels and the ability to make decisions involving customers and your acreer at most levels of the company.
cons: In some hotels, long, hard hours are needed to move ahead, even if they are not necessary, set match for 401K/profit sharing has been replaced with a variable match causing higher paid employees to severely limit their contributions, career opportunities are based less upon what you have accomplished and more about who knows your name, medical benefits costs have gone up substantially, slow growth means fewer opportunities to move ahead

pros: Opportunity to grow if you work hard.  Company is flexible if you prove yourself.  Large amounts of growth and change going on due to globalization -- this can be both good and bad.  This is still a place where you can make a career for yourself and explore a number of different jobs.
cons: Benefits are good but not great.  Some divisions at HQ are very flat and there is little room for promotion within a skill set.  Property level associates have more room for advancement, it appears, so long as you are willing to move.  This is still a "good ole boys" place to a large degree and senior management can be very conservative.

pros: The regular customers are great! Pleasant, and I love learning about their work and meeting new people. Better money than retail.
cons: Management no longer gives you the freedom to make adjustments to give customers the best experience possible. This means you get roasted when a client is unhappy--from the client, and then from your boss. I have heard from the part-time employees that hours have been cut and inconsistent. As a small company, there's almost no room for growth (Plamondon).

review_title: It’s is an ok place, if you are really into hospitality.
pros: It’s a  great company and overall it treats employees very good.
cons: The company wants you to start from the bottom up, no matter how good or how much experience you have prior to them. I worked on Reservations. Even if you are doing an excellent job for a few months and have experience in other fields, and want to apply to other positions in their hotels, you are told your current managers will not sign off on the application or that if the hiring managers calls they will say “you are not prepared” because you have not been there for a year or more. Also, pay is not good enough for all the work.

pros:
Multilingual and multicultural environment 
Discounts on Marriott Hotel bookings (up to 80%)
You communicate with customers and front desk colleagues from all over the world, which improves your English and your confidence
cons:
Very busy lines (calls enter constantly)
You cannot trust the system because many times it won't do what it's supposed to do, which turns simple tasks  into frustrating experiences for you and for the customer as well. (i.e. when you try to make a reservation, the system may tell you to try again because an unexpected error occurred. This means you have to start all over again, which makes it longer and makes the conversation unpleasant.)
Nothing really assures you that this time the system will work, and you still have to get mentally ready to go through these type of situations again and again.

pros: Employee Discount for rooms is great! Night audit is a good gig if you like to work alone. I like the team I work with. Everyone is really nice and works well together when I cross paths with them.
cons: Some shifts can drag on and be very slow and you have to keep yourself awake. The job does not pay a living wage so don't expect to take care of yourself and family with the money. However, team here is great to work with. Lots of turnover with associates and management.  This job is best suited for retirees, housewives, and people who have other solid income.

review_title: Guest services agent night auditor. And MOD
job_title: Guest Service Representative MoD in Erie, PA
pros: It was great working for the name I worked for residence inn and courtyard by Marriott I spent 3 yrs at residence inn and loved it.it was my first hotel job ever. I became a strong leader at the front desk and mastered richi and marcha and fossi when we upgraded. Though the pms system is still used today it needs upgraded though Marriott taught me a lot and Mr Marriott was my idol if anything they taught me about how to provide the best service imgiable going above and beyond I carry today
cons: The cons is for the frangise I worked for why u let them connect a water park to a residence inn it killed it for me courtyard by marrott to I worked at didn't run by the book it dissapointed me

job_title: Guest Service Representative (Front Desk) in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
It was a good experience to be able to work at the Marriott. I mean not all Marriott or hotel I should say are the same. But I worked at the Minneapolis Marriott west in Saint Louis park mn. The GM there was awesome! She was loving and did her best at knowing all her employee which was definitely a leadership skill there! I had a lot of fun! 

Also free food!!! The cooks have food ready for tl everyone (employee) and the awesome hotel discount of 50%
cons: The hours were so draining! I almost felt like I have no life but work when working there because it was not set whether I have first or second shift. Monday I can be first shift (7-3pm) then Tuesday I have second shift (3pm-7pm) and they are open 24/7 365!!! So you can be working Christmas and new year and thanksgiving.

job_title: Front Desk in Elizabeth City, NC
pros: Working at Marriott is the best job oppourtunity that I have ever had. The manager is very understanding and professional at the same time. We have weekly guest here and they are the most down to earth people that I have met. It is like my second home here. It is a very professional place that  gives you plenty of room for a career growth.
cons: There are very few downsides to the front desk at a marriott. I would say dealing with rude guests or trying to answer the phones while checking people in.  That's about it!

review_title: Insensitive Management - Lots of work for low pay
pros: You get to meet lots of people! Typically (If you are in a busy area) surrounding restaurants will offer benefits and discounts in exchange for recommendations. The travel benefit is another obvious perk. If you work second or third shift, you have minimal contact with management. This makes the job less stressful.
cons: Management tends to be snooty. At Front desk, the expectations are high with little remuneration. The Management jobs are good and have decent pay, consequently the turnover is low within management making advancement opportunities minimal at best.

job_title: Senior Event Operations Supervisor in Bethesda, MD
pros: Management really cares about employees and their development, associates have the opportunity to be double coded, Mr. Marriott visits property and is genuinely happy to greet staff,  company allows associates to spend quality time with their families
cons: Overcoming the gossip amongst staff, staff isn't supportive of others who have been promoted, oftentimes associates don't have the proper tools to effectively do their jobs and at times feel management doesn't care

job_title: Front Desk Agent in San Francisco, CA
pros: The hotel I worked for was part of the Autograph Collection. I worked for the hotel pre and post acquisition. It was pretty lax pre, but it got very corporate post. It drove a lot more business into the hotel with the rewards program, but it also brought in a lot of the not so fun loyalty members in. You get steep hotel discounts during the holidays.
cons: Hotel industry in general are very taxing. You're constantly working because there is always something breaking in the old building. You stand all day, and the shifts can be really late. The hotel never closes, so somebody has to be working at any time.

review_title: I miss working for Marriott, it was a great experience for someone starting out in the hospitality industry.
job_title: Floor Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great benefits package, great discounts on hotel rooms, excellent training programs and networking opportunities, opportunity to transfer and avdvance to management.
cons: Hard to make decent money at some of the suburban locations, and at some locations the hourly associates made more than management.

pros: There are some decent people who work in the hotel.
cons:
Management is in collusion with the union representative which makes it exceedingly difficult for employees to approach their union. The place is extremely disorganized; the Marriott's right hand doesn't know what it's left hand is doing. New employees are given full-time hours in the beginning, but are eventually relegated to working only one day per week; coincidentally, just before their probationary period has expired. Nineteen dollars is deducted from each pay cheque to cover union dues. 
"Kitchen Associates" is just Marriott's vernacular for dishwasher. They don't pay you extra for doing tasks outside your realm. My advice to anyone who's interested in applying for this position is to look elsewhere. Trust me, it would be better to work at McDonald's.

review_title: Great for associates, forgotten when a manager
pros:
Great benefits
Competitive pay
Endless locations
Meet a lot of great people
cons:
Lack of training for supervisors/managers
A lot of nepotism
Politics play a big role when trying to move up
Managers expect you to complete work with zero training on it  
Care more about opening hotels rather than checking what condition the older hotels are in
The higher you move up, the less life you have

review_title: Good Company, but not great for new hires
pros: They have good health benefits, flexible schedules and telecommuting.
cons: They really axed the PTO for new hires this year.  Hard for a company to promote a work life balance and getting awards from working mother magazine, but then to cut PTO in half.  Not sure how working mothers can accomodate a busy schedule with such little PTO.

review_title: Slightly above average in certain areas and certainly below average in others...
job_title: Rooms Operations Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Excellent Training, Great potential for career growth, and International Company.
cons: Extremely political!!! Salary compensation is certainly below other hotel companies!!!

pros: The job is so much fun and it's exciting meeting new people and having a varied schedule. The Marriott benefits are awesome, too! The managers are good people as well as the coworkers. It's a rewarding job to be in for someone who enjoys working with the public.
cons: The pay is low. Ugh, it's awful. They need to increase starting pay too as a way of hiring in better quality of people on the front end. As well as adding better bonus options for days the hotel sells out. The low pay causes people to leave to search out better jobs. They'd have more stability if they'd just increase the hourly wage some.

review_title: Used to be great, but not so much anymore
job_title: At Your Service Agent-Front Desk in Houston, TX
pros:
-Very good hotel discount more than 50% off 
-Excellent benefits 
-able to use workout facility, if the property has one for free
-cheap meals available everyday, although you probably won't want to eat it
cons:
-Nothing is consitant-everything depends on management, if you have a good manager you'll have a good experience, if you have a micro-manager you'll have a bad experience
-work every weekend and most holidays for $10.25 an hour
-No time and half for holidays, however you get  paid for the holiday, but so does the people who are off, so there is no incentive for working on the holiday
-Guest encounters are becoming too rehearsed, what happend to just being warm and hospitable and making the guest feel like they are at their "home away from home"?

review_title: Prejudice Supervisor, Unaccountable Management , Insufficient Time for workload, don't care about employees
job_title: Housekeeper, JW Desert Springs Marriott in Palm Desert, CA
pros:
Its a nice hotel to work at, 
mostly nice staff, great benefits, excellent customer service, good safety standards, free lunch
cons: Prejudice supervisor who made it unbearable for me to get into learning my position, catty co-workers, insufficient time for workload, confusion , careless management, unaccountability, poor communication . I was also unable to switch to a position that better fit my skills.

review_title: If the hospitality industry is your passion, Marriott is a great place to work
pros: Marriott has a fun, family like culture. An open door policy applies among all levels of associates at the property level. Development and growth within the company is highly encouraged. The way to be promoted is to transfer between different hotels, and sometimes across disciplines.
cons: Like any job in the hospitality industry, the work-life balance is tough. For hourly associates, schedules often come out weekly, on Thursdays before the coming week. This makes it very difficult to plan your life with family and friends. Managers are required to work a minimum of 50 hours per week, and 55-60+ is more typical.

pros: Room Rate Discount, meals on duty, uniform/dry cleaning. There isn’t 20 words that I can write to reach the minimum required!
cons: Work life balance, bullying, pay increase only minimum/national wage hidden as a merit increase, long hours, attitude of cluster managers to hotel managers stink.

pros:
Flexible schedules - because they are open 24/7
