Paid vacation
Easy to switch schedules with other people.
Some recognition of achievements.
cons:
Oppurtunity for advancement is a sham; the next level up was such a small pay increase and I would have lost my sales bonus - so the promotion ends up being a pay decrease.
Company does not give you proper tools to do the job - if you like to pass the buck, this is the place for you.
You will be on the night shift for a long time, years - permenant changes in schedule are impossible.

review_title: Great job, Super Job security, and Plenty of Opportunities to move up for smart people who work hard.
pros: Job security. 6% matching 401k. Dental limit at 1,500 per year for about 2 bucks a month. Very good Benefits and a job that you know is secure.
cons: Teamwork is essential in a hotel job. If you are Front Desk, you will get complaints from other team members' performance. ie. room not cleaned property (usually something small like someone didn't empty one of the trash bins in the room). You will then have to deal with a problem you did not cause in effect cleaning up their mess, some but very few guests can be very petty with small issues. Biggest con is in evening when people can sometimes get rowdy, but this is seldom. A good FD and NA combo can minimize rowdy crowds.

review_title: Great job, Super Job security, and Plenty of Opportunities to move up for smart people who work hard.
pros: Job security. 6% matching 401k. Dental limit at 1,500 per year for about 2 bucks a month. Very good Benefits and a job that you know is secure.
cons: Teamwork is essential in a hotel job. If you are Front Desk, you will get complaints from other team members' performance. ie. room not cleaned property (usually something small like someone didn't empty one of the trash bins in the room). You will then have to deal with a problem you did not cause in effect cleaning up their mess, some but very few guests can be very petty with small issues. Biggest con is in evening when people can sometimes get rowdy, but this is seldom. A good FD and NA combo can minimize rowdy crowds.

review_title: Great company that takes care of their employees
job_title: Front Office Supervisor in New York, NY
pros: "If you take care of your employees, your employees will be happy and take care of your guests, your guests will be happy and they'll return." Marriott backs this philosophy up with generous pay rates, profit sharing, company match, health insurance and of course - travel discounts. There are always opportunities to grow your career with the company something like 5,700 properties in 110 countries and people are constantly on the move.
cons: If you want to really grow with the company, its politics as usual and be prepared to kiss a lot of butt. The travel discount program is great but don't take advantage of it - I've seen people lose their jobs from things they did or even friends / family did.

job_title: Room Operations Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Well established company with good health benefits.
cons:
No work/life balance when working at a property level. As a manager you are stuck trying to uphold Marriott brand standards while trying to drive the bottom line for the owners. Most hotels I've worked at, focus on the bottom line rather than providing the service level that comes from following the Marriott brand standards. 

Marriott launched a program called the Art of Hosting, which is a GREAT training program for associates and it's there to provide our guests with a brilliant service but staff and management are often left to their own creativeness to find ways to uphold this program.

Also, there are many career opportunities, worldwide, but when it comes to transferring associates or managers to other properties it can be very difficult.

pros: Where I worked I had a set schedule, guaranteed hours, and usually a pretty relaxed work load, the only time that differed is when something serious happened.
cons: I worked at a extended stay so it was only me there at night so if it was busy it was only you to handle it, also like I said only you there so if you would happen to need a manager they would rarely pick up the phone because of the time which usually was around 1am-4am.

pros:
9 to 5 steady work hours with weekends off.
Okay leadership.
Large company so the opportunities to move elsewhere within the world are vast.
cons:
Office politics are very fratlike.
Low pay. Extremely low. Like I could qualify for food stamps.
Out of date office and technology. Like taking a trip back to 2001.
Everyone is pretty miserable because they don't feel valued and the leaders just ignore it. They gave us a 20 cent raise recently, if that's any indication as to the sorts of treats they give to their employees (sarcasm).
Turnover is high because they don't invest in anyone but themselves.

review_title: If you are looking at hotels to work at, Marriot is the right choice for you.
pros: Great benefits and dealing with people.  The schedules are designed to fit just about every employees personal life and can be adjusted if needed to under the right circumstances.  The opportunities to advance up the ladder are very good and if given the right chance, can be done in a reasonable amount of time after starting there.
cons: The work hours can be grueling if appointed to an overnight shift and at that time the customers can be a bit hard to handle.  The employees that work there are all great people to work with and management shows a great deal of consideration for their employees and the overall work enviroment of the business.

job_title: Front Desk Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Marriott is a great place to work because of Bill Marriott's philosophy "if you take care of the associates the associates will take care of the guests", this is why Marriott International ranks very high in Guest Satisfaction.  Marriott's benefits package is second to none.  Marriott believes in having a diverse workforce.  The opportunity for career advancement within the organization are excellent.  There is an excellent balance between work and life when it comes to the scheduling aspect of the company.
cons: More money should be allocated to updating some of the older locations.  They could pay middle management more money.

review_title: I enjoyed working with the guests, however management did not take the time to care or train employees accordingly.
job_title: Front Desk Associate in Seattle, WA
pros: Very friendly guests, staff was also friendly.
cons: At the time, poorly run hotel - new management and ownership I believe has hopefully helped change the property.

pros: Good benefit package including generous time off and great hotel deals. Not bleeding edge but fairly current technology approach. Solid company guaranteed to make money, share profits, and not embarrass you with ugly front page scandals.
cons: Definitely a good old boy network in management. People who rise to the top never leave, so advancement opportunities are rare. Most innovation now being farmed out to a revolving cast of offshore service providers, leaving the remaining Marriott employees tasked with constantly mentoring and babysitting inexperienced, inexpensive offshore labor in a timezone of +9.5 hours from home, making it very inconvenient.

job_title: Sales and Customer Care Agent in Cork
pros: Colleagues are very friendly and they are the only reason to be able to come back to that horrible place every day.
cons:
- Shifts are assigned depending on your stats/sales per month. If you are honest, you have nothing to do, say goodbye to your friends, family and spare time because you are gonna work from 13.30 a 22 including weekend. If you cheat and fool the customers you may have a chance to get a better shift... 
- Management are just the most useless people I've ever met. People who has no management studies or background AT ALL but have been working long enough there to get that position. I would even call some of them 'sociopaths'.
- No rewards or benefits: as much as you can get will be few sweets for halloween and chocolates for christmas. Salary is very very bad given that you have absolutely no life.
- No canteen: they give you absolutely nothing, no milk, no coffee, no sugar.... If you forget to bring your own food you will starve for 8h30min.

pros:
Free snacks and Starbucks coffee.
Really nothing more positive to say; I have to enter twenty words or more in this section...
cons:
Be prepared to be treated like you have no knowledge whatsoever of the culinary arts, regardless of how many years you've worked in the field.  Executive Chef will stand within 6 inches of you and scream in your face about how to prepare and present their food (even though you've never been shown their menu).
Do like not having any breaks or lunch periods?  Then this is the job for you!
Want to be ripped-off for the hours you work (and not be paid on time)?  You'll love it here!

pros: decent benefits, diverse associates, lots of places to transfer to if you are willing to relocate, working for the brand name of Marriott International may help you get a job in the future
cons: Marriott International may have a great reputation but you are at the mercy of the management at your specific property.  Corporate/Human Resources does not take associate complaints seriously.  Even as a group of 12 associates sitting down with to discuss your issues you may be told "if you don't like it, you should probably find a job that would make you happier"  instead of entertaining the idea that possibly there is something going on with senior management

review_title: So proud to be with Marriott
pros: I'd been with one of Marriott Hotel in China for more than 5yrs.  It's a great company, I was taken care of, treated fairly.  Marriott provided a lot training to his staff.  I was so proud to be with Marriott.
cons: In recent years, Marriott Management is not strong enough to stand for his staff against the hotel owner, like salary increase percentage, benifits, training fund...  You know the owner in China is quite tough in cost control.  Some of Marriott hotels under the name of Marriott, or JW Marriott are not luxury enough as before.

review_title: Great place to work if looking to advance in your career!
pros: This company really cares about its employees. The perks at my property are never ending (hotel discount, employee appreciation week, dry cleaning services, free breakfast, etc.)  you meet new people and give them a level of service that other hotels can't compare to. if you are wanting to get your foot in the door to grow in your career a popular brand like Marriott is the right way to go!
cons: Long hours!!!!!! A hotel never closes so it is very likely that you will work on major holidays and on the weekends. Very rare that you work a 8 day shift or 40 hours a week unless you're HR or accounting or sales.

pros: Employee discount was number one reason for me. Additionally, it was nice to get to know the guests who were regulars. I left on good terms and if my circumstances allowed, I would reapply. I worked at a franchise location but I still felt completely like a Marriott employee. My GM and his assistant were wonderful to work with.
cons: This was the first time I had ever worked a night shift position. I did not prefer it and would not work night shift again. This is a personal preference, not a Marriott issue.

review_title: Top place to work in hospitality, but it's not perfect
pros: If you're looking for a place to advance quickly this is the place to go. Every 6 months you can easily switch jobs as long as you're working hard. Company is very diverse hiring a lot of immigrants.
cons: Schedule comes out on Thursday and it varies a lot from week to week. Compensation is very low and lots of benefits went away in recent years.

review_title: If you are interested in hotels then this is for you ........... if not ..... Don't quit your day job
pros:
Free meal during the shift 
Allot of potential to learn more about the hotel and hotel management in general if that is your thing
cons:
Marriott employee discount is an absolute joke, almost worthless. 
Company loves to play the blame game, and is amazing at never taking responsibility for anything bad that may happen.

review_title: Job can be stressful, but rewarding...
pros:
-GREAT benefits (health insurance and various discounts)
-Always an opportunity to get extra hours, whether at your property or another property
-Average 40 hours a week and weekends off
-Hours range from 7am-3pm /8am-4pm/9am-5pm/10am-6pm (varies by property and the needs or the General Manager)
cons:
-VERY demanding especially working in Midtown Atlanta and Downtown Atlanta
-Leading up to and during City Wide Conferences, you can be working long hours to ensure everything is an easy transition for your team and guests
-You WILL be working the Front Desk regularly if you are at Marriott Select Brand Hotel (not Full-Service) and you are still expected to get all of your work completed in a timely manner

review_title: Positive all around experience, but limited career growth opportunities.
pros: Great travel benefits. The people I've encountered have been genuinely passionate about what they do everyday and it reflects both in their approach to work as well as their everyday lives outside of the hotel.
cons: Limited growth opportunities unless you're willing to relocate every couple of years. Senior leadership tends to get comfortable once they land in a desirable location, so you have to constantly move where the next level of opportunities are (domestically or internationally). Relocating every couple of years is not a viable option for everyone.

pros: Easy job as long as you dont have the Management micro managing every little thing that you do.
cons: Management team sucks. Small property and very under staff. Manager doesn't listen to employees. She talks to them like they are bunch of kids that she is baby sitting. She doesn't let you explain yourself. She talks over you.  If you have a suggestion she takes it as if what you think doesnt matter. She is very RUDE to a lot of customers. She should not be working in the hospitality industry with that kind of attitude. You see the awards display at the front desk from Marriott, sometimes I wonder, the awards does not apply to what the management  team is showing their employees and how they treat their employees.

job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Boston, MA
pros: It is a safe company to work for with room for growth. Leaders and team are very friendly and easy to work with.
cons: 50 hour work weeks. You get paid very little; most of my colleagues have gotten second jobs just to get by. Even VPs and Senior Management talk about how they can't afford to do this and that. VERY hard to stay motivated knowing that 10 years from now you could work tooth and nail and still be complaining about pay.

review_title: Awesome co-workers, but management is awful
job_title: Marriott Engagement Center Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great people work here who deserve better honestly, but the culture is nice and everyone is equal and positive in that regard. Nice benefits such as discounts at properties and insurance (although it’s expensive).
cons: They keep you where they want you. In addition to the terrible pay, they only promote those who are suck ups to management and don’t care about your goals in reality. They work you to death and with the multiple system issues they’ve experienced lately (due to outdated computers), when something crashes and messes with your adherence slightly, they usually don’t care and penalize you anyway. Management can be petty and criticizes employees which is super unprofessional. What use to be a good work environment soon became soul sucking.

pros:
Marriott is overall an alright company. 
I was offered a new job a few years ago and was asked to go on pool status with my hotel, that has been the best move I’ve ever made job wise as it’s allowed me to step away from the full time hustle and bustle but still keep my employee discounts and have the option to earn extra income on weekends if I so choose!
cons:
The hotel branch I work for is corporate, they try to do a good job however there is so much turn over in all areas and positions that it feels like you’re constantly starting over. 
There are also a lot of call outs so being asked to work a double shift is common also the system which Marriott runs on isn’t the most user friendly and can create a lot of issues.

review_title: Do not fall for the "culture" of family. The only culture is revenue at ALL costs.
pros: Your friends and family getting discounts at Marriotts. Most of the time these were not available anyway.
cons: The long, unpaid hours. Excessive stress and pressure. The company only cares about the revenue not the employee. HR is only there for show. No follow up or being there for the employee was ever demonstrated. HR broke employee confientiality by reporting everything employees would say to their Directors. Employees would cry in their offices and that was ignored by Leadership. If an emloyee ever "rocked the boat" or voice any concern they were told they need to work smarter and may not be of Marriott culture. The culture is to work as many free hours as they can get. I worked many 19 hour shifts ..... worked many 6 day weeks ... as long as I brought in high revenue and the clients were happy then leadership did not care.

pros:
I've had the pleasure of dealing with some of the nicest, smartest, and most engaged people. The environment that I work in doesn't take itself too seriously and still gets a lot of work done. I enjoy having the opportunity to manage multiple projects simultaneously and interact with different disciplines throughout the company, globally. My manager is hands-on but doesn't micro-manage; my team is fun and helpful; my clients are mostly good to work with (though, I do have a few who are difficult) and let me be a strategic partner to them.

The company itself seems to care for its employees, though some may disagree. I personally have not experienced anything negative in that area. Marriott offers decent benefits, decent salary and bonus structure (for mgmt positions), a decent building (currently under renovations to increase collaborative work spaces) with an amazing cafeteria, a gym, fitness classes, innovative learning opportunities, volunteer opportunities, and social networking. Most opportunities for advancement are internal (some would say that's a con because it is hard to get into Marriott from the outside). Marriott is all about collaboration (sometimes, a little too much) among teams and flexibility. The company has a flexible workplace philosophy, which is mostly adopted and modeled by leadership. And, there are the discounts when you stay at specific Marriott properties (not all properties give them).
cons:
The biggest con for me is the vacation and salary. As a new hire - my vacation is terrible. Your vacation and sick time are combined and you only get 12 days total the first year. Plus, you accrue it so don't think about making plans until after the first year. This used to be different but recently changed to the new system. Also, the salary isn't that great for a company of this size (and span) but it's decent and they do have a decent bonus structure for management positions and above. The commute is long, but that's a personal choice (not the fault of Marriott).

And, depending on what discipline you're in - Marriott loves to restructure. I think my team has been restructured and placed under new management three or four times over the past several years. That doesn't help the team's morale or the appearance of stability.

job_title: Food Beverage in South Beach, FL
pros: Flexibility, Marriott is a very understanding company. Lunch was at a decent price and the Coworkers are Amazing.
cons: Unprofessional Management, Unwilling Management, No recognition, very low pay compared to other hotel companies

pros: Very good medical and dental benefits, depending on the tier of Marriott hotel and location you work for.  When jobs are posted, the pay is public so there is no unfair pay scale within the department. There is opportunity to advance. Hotel discounts are good as well for personal travel.
cons: When they hire a new batch of management, the newbies tend to not help out as much, or at all at the front desk, where our previous management would help with long lines and meal breaks. The new management tends to sit in their offices and chat with other managers. They try to reinvent the wheel to gain notoriety, but things were working better before.

pros:
Fabulous culture. Unlimited career opportunities. Mr. Marriott has assembled a world class executive team that is headed by Mr. Arne Sorenson, President and CEO of Marriott International. Arne's picture is next to "The Real Deal" in the dictionary. I could not be more impressed.
They have articulated a winning vision and have proven time and again they can execute. Mr. Marriott is fond of saying "Put People First", and it's not a slogan but a way of doing business. if you want to be with the global leader in Hospitality, look no further.
cons: After 35 years I don't have any cons to share. I worked in over 15 Marriotts in four major markets and the company culture permeates all of their properties. The company values their associates and their associates provide world class customer service. It's a winning formula.

pros: Marriott International (not franchise) is a company that offers strong benefits to their employees including college reimbursement. It is extremely LBGT, student, and family supportive. Encourages hotels to learn about their customers culture and how to take care of them while learning about yourself. Marriott budgets for employee relations allowing managers to take care of their employees and especially housekeeping. Working in hotels is hard work, but Marriott works to provide their employees with the care they need.
cons: Many of the hotels are going franchise so it is becoming harder to find Marriott Corporate hotel positions. Also, hotels are open 365 days a year and 24hours a day so depending on your skills and job title you may be working odd hours, swing shifts, and many holidays.

review_title: Me personally love the place grate staff cooks and workers an the rooms are perfect thats why i feel the job is for me
pros: My best reasons on working here is everything its really for people like me that are clean freaks an that love what we do i also love the time an effort i will be giveing working here at marriott.
cons: I don't think that it is a challenge for me im fast an a great cleaner also fast learner.

pros: Vacation Time was good. Benefits include cheap hotels for employees and friends or relatives of the employee. Discounts on in-hotel items. Worked around my schedule so I could go to school and work. Free lunch and laundry was provided. Meeting new people every day and you get see how people travel for their jobs.
cons: There wasn't really any way to get a raise unless you get a higher position.  If an employee lags behind you're on your own and if you don't fix their mistake, it's on everyone on that shift even though you had no idea. If a guest expects something most of the time they are going to get it even though it can go against the rules. Expect to get treated like dirt by some people.

job_title: Reservations Coordinator/ Front Desk Agent in South San Francisco, CA
pros: benefits, discounts needed at other cities during vacation.  there are many great connections around the other states that are truly friendly and once they know that you are part of this great company, you are then treated like you belong in a secret society.  While I've been to some other locations where the service can use much needed training, even for the management level position.  They seem to not want to be there.  Their level of curteous isn't a 10 but not even in the average level in my opionion.  All I received was "thank you for choosing ____ and enjoy your stay".  There wasn't any eye contact you know, how could this be?
cons: weekends, holidays are a must

pros: Benefits are ok. Travel discounts, Many opportunities to relocate/change jobs.
cons: Constant cuts in labor cause excessive work for remaining staff. Your choice is to work extremely long hours, take work home, or risk losing you job. Managers and staff struggle to use paid time off hours earned and often lose the time because of their use it or lose it policy.

review_title: Marriott Reservation Center - Reservation Sales Associate
pros: Marriott cares about associates. Great benefits, 401K, tuition reimbursement, and hotel discounts are nice (when they are available). Overall, it's a fun and positive environment, surrounded by great people. Advancement opportunities are available, but the more you are willing to travel or transfer to other Marriotts, the more opportunities that are out there.
cons: The pay could be better. I've struggled trying to advance within the company, but I know others who have. The advancement opportunities I see the most are in reservations but with different brands or specialties. Or as I mentioned, if you are willing to try to advance in other branches of Marriott or states, even more opportunities are available.

pros: Great atmosphere, benefits, and managers.  Opportunities for advancement are available all over the world.   Continuing educational opportunities are abundant.    Stable work environment.
cons: Many employees have been with company for years and years.   This might be considered a benefit for some but there are many examples where long tenured staff members drag others down with the "we have always done it this way, I remember when..."   HR should allow managers to do their job rather than coddle lackadaisical employees that are only there because they wouldn't make it anywhere else.

review_title: Great for your vacation....if you get one!
job_title: Event Manager in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Growth Opportunities are endless and Travel Benefits for discounted hotel rates are wonderful.
cons: Hotels are open 24 hours and so 40 works do not apply. More toward the 60-65 hours per week for managment. This is because the hourly paid staff un severly underpaid and never allowed overtime due to budgeting. Bonus structures were never clear. They were almost "guaranteed" when negotiating my salary. I never received even one in full in all 5 years I was with the company. Even when my individual goal was exceeded by 200% my group goal and training hours brought me down.

review_title: For a sense of stability, not a sense of high pay
pros: Working for this company has shared a number of great attributes from company sponsored outings, leniency for associates needing time off, and a sense of nurturing for those eager to grow.
cons: The pay just isn't there. Only way it appears to gain the a higher salary is to know friends who work within specific departments, transfer around different departments or acquire tenure status; basically working for a very long time.

pros: Great atmosphere because you are interacting with guests on a daily basis. There are good days and bad days it's the hospitality business so you would assume that.
cons: Depends on what type of Marriott you work for if it's a small franchise hotel you are limited with advancement in the field. Bigger hotels located in bigger cities may give you opportunity to grow within the company.

pros: Marriott offers excellent training and continuing on-line education for many positions.  There are opportunities out there, but you have to initiate your interest to move to a new opportunity within the company.  It's up to you how far you want to go!  They offer great benefits and take care of their associates.
cons: You will work very hard.  It is a very large company, so it can be easy to get lost among so many associates.  It's up to you to keep yourself visible.

job_title: Senior Manager, HQ in Bethesda, MD
pros: Great culture with purpose beyond just profit.  CEO has managed to add innovation focus without losing the warmth of the culture.  People management is big focus.  Hotel discounts are awesome.
cons: Leadership has become over-fixated on Millennials, leaving the Gen X workforce (half of HQ) feeling pushed aside.  Yes, we need to look to the future but also need to motivate the associates we have today and serve the guests we have today.

pros: Most of the people you will meet make the job what it is. The culture here is strong but The discount and PTO is the biggest pro.
cons: There's no work life balance and the pay often no where near worth it. Depending on what brand or level your at your often split between 4-5 jobs. Half of the time the PTO they give you will expire before given the chance to use it because they never seem to have enough employees and you can easily get stuck in the same position if you don't know the right people. And many of the newer generation of managers have no clue what they're doing.

pros: Associate of 4.5 years. You're able to promote quickly. Some of the Managers are really great and you can learn quite a bit. Excellent hotel discount! The discount alone made me stay with them for over a year after deciding to start actively looking outside of the company.
cons: The pay is not competitive. On my group specifically merit counts for naught. Seniority is all that's considered regardless of how poorly/great you preform. They can't retain good talent because they won't address terrible associates which drives away hard working, bright, employees.

pros: The benefits are relatively good. It is women friendly. And it has a good cafeteria.
cons: This is a not a great company to work for in a technical/non-managerial role, especially software related roles. The company relies very heavily on outsourcing companies who are doing a poor job. The standard coding and development practices are completely ignored. Worst code I have ever seen. Don't be fooled by the title of the positions. Software engineers here don't really do much of technical stuff, they are expected to do be in meetings the whole time and address the impediments of the outsourcing companies. I did not enjoy my time here. The recruiters seek out Indian guys for the Software positions. Perhaps they think they will stick around in spite of the very shabby work environment. I have absolutely no disrespect for the Indian developers. Many of them are great. But not all outsourcing companies and projects are the same and this company puts them on a pedestal.

review_title: Marriott - An excellent employer to work for!
job_title: Quality Assurance Specialist in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Marriott strives to treat its employees well.  One of the core philosophies of Marriott is, "If you treat your employees well, they will treat your customers well, and your customers will come back to you."  Marriott offers professional development courses to help you grow and advance professionally.  The benefits are nice, and I've stayed at many nice hotels on a highly discounted rate.
cons: Sometimes the right hand doesn't know what the left hand is doing.  To put it another way, Marriott has so many different departments, such as Reservations, Customer Care, and Guest Services, that it is difficult to know what is going on.

pros: Co-workers were awesome. The culture is nice, they do take care of their people to an extent. If you work in a higher end (4-5 star) Marriott you're going to make good money. Plus they pay you more per hour than a restaurant does, and you don't have to declare cash tips. If you're full time you can qualify for a 401k, health benefits, life insurance policies etc..
cons: However, Marriott doesn't recognize that it needs to pay supervisors more money per hour. I had terrible supervisors who were miserable because I was making more money than them an hour but they were handling the stress of 3-4 outlets (restuarants/bars/coffeeshops) in the resort and making 15$ an hour. They took it out on employees consistently and finally it was the reason I quit.

pros:
The hourly wage is fantastic during the slow season. 
The other workers such as receptionist, housemen, and managers are friendly, generous, and always happy to help out. 
This position is a great way to grow as a bartender especially of you are working solo.
cons: The managers somehow don't listen when I'm reporting a complaint about a colleague who doesn't complete their tasks or even do most of their tasks to take care of the business and it's frustrating. I brush it and deal with it, but business is very unpredictable that I need to be prepared for business regardless.

pros: My best Season of working at Marriott it when people couldn't stop talking about me After the two letters that Mr Dennis Obriant ant the ex president Clinton have sent to my director the ferbrery 24th for the good service i provided yo them while  their visit in Haiti.
cons: And the donwside of my work at Marriott it's when the bosses don't treat people as human being, they make seems people worth nothing they treat them how they want because they know if you're not agree with their treatment they'll find person who will accept worse than that without saying none just because Haïti IS a very jobless country.

pros: The benefits package is wonderful. The benefits website makes it very easy to access pay checks, 401k information, information about job postings, etc.
cons: You have to work a minimum of 50 hours a week in management and most of the time it will be 55-60. In order to apply for a management position you have to take their management training program (which lasts almost a year and you can't start until you have been there a year) and then are still not guaranteed a management position. When you have already graduated college, this program is pointless because college will teach you more than this program ever will. Pay is awful and you will be worked so much you will not have a social life.

job_title: Front Desk Associate in Rancho Cucamonga, CA
pros:
Great starting place fr someone who doesnt have work experience
Wonderful discounts on Marriott hotels
cons:
Do not expect to be paid above minimum wage even if you are worked like a race horse.
No management to employee support
Strange hours. They like to have you work 25 hours but will spread it across the week instead of condensing it appropriately which affects work-life balance
High turn over with employees
No lunch breaks
No in house food discounts
No attention from management unless it's Q&A season and the attention an employee does get is usually bad
No empathy for employees 
Employees had to train themselves without any help but is expected to pass Q&A with jobs on the line
Don't expect to move up in the company, you will remain stagnated

review_title: Refurbished not just a few years ago,hotel in great shape. Guest interaction can be pleasant  or horrible.
job_title: Guest Service Representative in Fishkill, NY
pros: A few of the maintenance employees a bright and cheaper. Some guests you meet will brighten your day! On occasion, some guests will tip you for checking them in.
cons: You are expected to work front desk and make Starbucks drinks from the bistro area when it's closed. Specialty drinks can be tedious when your on a shift alone and have guests waiting to check in. Other employees are child like and let there personal life affect their work. a lot of lazy coworkers who put their work off for the next person to do.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: Overall it is an amazing company to work to, and prior to changing positions and having to work with the management they sent down form Omaha, I absolutely loved working for Marriott. The reservations portion had AMAZING management and were understanding when it came to my pregnancy and my young children and their needs.
cons: When I shifted to Customer Care, there was issues with the new management from Omaha and their inability to understand mandatory doctor appointments due to pregnancy. At one point I was told that I need to slow down and not have any more children (my kids are 18 months apart, and planned just so). I was hurt, and mortified.

pros: Hospitality employment that offers health insurance and a partial company match on savings deducted from the paycheck. Often four shifts a week gets all the hours I can have, three days off is nice.Employee rates at other properties, subject to occupancy, and they just bought Starwood so even more options.
cons: Evening hours can be difficult while young children are part of one's life. The business is open 365 days a year, decide which holidays you want to miss out on, you have to work your fair share of them.

review_title: Great development, staff shortages, little HR support
job_title: Department Leader in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros:
Developed to run a business within a business.
Moved quickly into management
cons:
Little to no HR support with staff issues. 
No support from executive team in providing additional help to department leadership. 
Lots of meetings and committees, taking time from short staffed department. 
Do more with less mentality, and do it perfectly. 
The yearly associate engagement survey does not work. Department leaders give their department high scores in order to avoid repercussions in reviews and raises.  It in turn gives their executive committee member high scores, when in reality, that is not the case.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Bethesda, MD
pros: Most people seem to have good intentions and are willing to help you learn.
cons: Despite the desire to appear “innovative” my experience has been the exact opposite. Systems and processes are so outdated, unreliable and bureaucratic that it makes a simple task take 3x longer and requires 4x more effort. This results in long employee hours, bad information, and disgruntled employees. The data should tell the story itself, there shouldn’t be a need to reconcile a reconciliation to another reconciliation.

review_title: Marriot, where individuals are trained to lose their identity.
job_title: Sales Agent in Costa Mesa, CA
pros: Marriott offered employees incredible lucrative perks, in terms of discounted hotels, or in some cases free nights.  Additionally, fellow employees were of the same cloth so to speak, understanding the goal and working together to accomplish it.
cons: Salary was very low.  Marriott prefers individuals without a degree to maintain low salaries.  Individuals with a background in the armed forces do very well, the ability to not question decsions and just say "yes" is highly sought after.  In terms of individuals who advance at Marriott, are individuals who have a track record of "not" asking questions, and doing exactly what they are told.

review_title: A GREAT SMILE IS ALL IT TAKES
job_title: Guest Services Associate in Toronto, ON
pros: great benefits but most of all the staff is great to work with and of course it is a hospitality environment therefore you end up creating a very home away from home type environment with alot of the associates you work with.  Marriott aswell offers great discounts on rooms and on food and beverage.  They even offer free rooms at a certain point of time during the year and they also offer special rates for your friends and family.  THe beds are very comfortable.  The customer service is amazing.
cons: very big on corporate culture, senior management seem a little intimidating

review_title: Was great as little as 3 years ago; now...wow...where to begin?
pros: great training and probably the best in hospitality; help you to see from a macro perspective; great leadership 3 years ago; a sense of team spirit; great at allowing job transfers, changes.
cons:
now with all of the changes within the sales environment, where to begin?
- capped on bonuses so where is the motivation?
- only company I've ever worked for where the minimum work week is at LEAST 50 hours or more
- expectation is being available 24/7, no excuses
- no work/life balance anymore
etc

review_title: No career opportunities for experienced and hard workers
pros: Flexible rota, free parking, nice uniform, staff rate discounts, nice people around to work with
cons: No opportunities for experienced, promotions only for who knows whom, drag & drop promotions, senior management oblivious to staff needs, cheeky methods to spy employees, rules applied on as and when basis, procedures change when GM & Dir Ops change , HR practically un functional

pros: For someone with a future in Hotel industries and studying it in school great starting spot and the job expirence is invaluable. Learned alot and its a very nice hotel easily one of the top in town.
cons: Communication is poor, departments dont get along management wise. In a smaller town the amount of canidates for certain positions must be lacking because some of the hires are head scractching. Im just here to learn and this place has plenty good and bad to take forward.

pros:
Better than average benefits, great discounts, opportunities to transfer,
Word of advice: avoid smaller properties (Courtyard, Residence Inn) unless you want to be on a shorter track to GM as you will end up with more work and less pay
cons:
Transfer process is not good. If an associate has a good review, there current manager should not be required to give a reference as I have had managers at different properties basically screw me over so that I would be stuck with them. Also managers should be more receptive to employees trying to transfer from different departments.
The tuition reimbursement program is great except for the fact that you have to jump through flaming hoops.

pros: You work for an iconic hospitality brand that's born and bred in the United States of America. If you're just starting in your career and you want to truly understand Customer Service and/or Restaurant/Hospitality this is the place to be.
cons: It's very common at most large corporations but micromanagement (at certain levels) made me really detest this place over time.

review_title: Hard work and long hours, but pays the bills:-)
pros: my hotel was five stars and Very expensive, so, nice environment....Marriott staff discount card is useful for traveling around,but still not cheep...working with few hundred people is exciting and never boring, new things every day...hotels are alive organisms ****
cons: never sure when you gonna finish your shift, especially in F&B departments... only 15 min break is paid...there are lots of managers and managers levels...and if you are not one of them, you will ended up doing their job too...too much pressure all the time, some of supervisors and assistants managers not helping at all, very messy rosters, bad delegating responsibilities...

review_title: I learned a lot but the pay was bad
job_title: Front Desk Clerk in Orlando, FL
pros:
Great training
They treat their employees very well for the most part
They value their guest and that brings happy and returning guests all the time
cons:
Pay was very low, I was getting paid the same as when I worked as a sales rep but I had 10.000 more responsibilities.

Early hours or late hours, but that was part of the position, I mean the front desk times are like that everywhere, there s no " 9 to 5 front desk"

Since it wasn a full service property I had to do duties from other departments than when you work at a full time Marriott you don t have to do...

review_title: Not the Marriott I used to work for...
pros: Great co-workers, smart and caring. Decent benefits and discounts at hotels.
cons:
Pay was not so great. Long hours sometimes. Management not so responsive - some employee issues were ignored and "swept under the rug"
The company used to have that family like atmosphere; employees were cared for and allowed to be innovative.  The IT division grew so big, server sprawl exploded and the costs spread down to the property owners. This prompted management to take a hard look at cutting costs. The end result was a massive reorganization, outsourcing and laying off hundreds of good people. There's no sense of loyalty any more.

pros: You are the only one managing the desk at night. If you complete your tasks efficiently you have time to complete personal tasks. I gained financial accounting experience. Lots of reports and direct contact with executives via email. Good experience in hospitality. Not as busy with check-ins.
cons: Pay does not reflect overnight pay or responsibilities. If something happens YOU are the ONLY ONE RESPONSIBLE. NO MAINTENANCE - NO MANAGER - NO SECURITY. You have to feel confident being on your own and making quick accurate decisions. If you are working nights full time something will happen! It's a 24/7 hotel, SOMETHING IS ALWAYS HAPPENING> THERE IS ALWAYS A SITUATION in some compacity. Especially if you are working in a big city.

review_title: You get what you put in, most of the time
pros: Opportunity to succeed; they care less what you came to the company with, and more for what you do when you get there. The company has a culture of taking care of their associates. It's now the largest hospitality company in the world.
cons: For a company that doesn't require significant prior training, they don't invest much in training their staff. There is a culture of "learn by doing," which can be positive, but can also be unnecessarily stressful. At times it seems that local leadership forgets about Mr. Marriott's admonition to take care of their associates so they can take care of their guests.

review_title: I don’t know how, but I miss it.
pros: Great discounts on hotels/meals, really strong training program and online growth courses, regional management was awesome, loved all of my coworkers.
cons: Immediate upper management was mediocre. I was sexual harassed and assaulted there for almost a year, and I was told I could only file a report if it persisted. And when it did, they looked the other way. The general manager often looked he other way when department managers were being corrupt. When supervisor positions opened up, they ignored people with strong potential and desire to grow and gave it to people who literally did not want it.

job_title: Shared Services Market IT Manager in Bethesda, MD
pros:
Large company where you can aim to do anything anywhere and lots of potential and opportunity for growth in different cities. 
Decent Health care options.
8 weeks paternity leave. Room discounts. PTO and Holidays in comparison to the rest of the hotel. Work life balance is okay if you manage your properties correctly. 
Lots of good people you work with that become like family.
Lots of new roles and good career path and structure to move up.
Associates are often celebrated in the company with small parties and perks.
cons:
Underpaid based on market value. 
50 hour work weeks expected.
People are scared to record their actual time when it comes to overtime because projects take more time than allotted weekly at most properties. 
401k match is vague based on company performance.

review_title: Ok for a short time and for very young people just to gain experience
job_title: Customer Services, Front Desk in London, England
pros:
Uniform
Free lunch (rarely tasty though)
Ability to swap shifts
cons:
Low very low pay
They want you to provide the best possible customer service, but pay you as for cashier in a local store (no offense at all for any job, but if you consider your business as a high quality brand, pay accordingly to your employees too).
Of course, it depends in which country/city you work. But if it's London and you're getting ~18-19k it's A JOKE.
Lack of motivation from management, prioritizing staff according to nationalities and other with job non-related things.

review_title: Sanibel Harbour was an amazing resort and spa to be apart of.
job_title: SPA Receptionist in Fort Myers, FL
pros: Sanibel Harbour Resort & Spa is an expansive property with a lot to offer. The Spa is top notch and recognized as the top spa in within the company. The staff strives for perfection despite working with an outdated reservations system.
cons: The only con I had about working with this company was the outdated computer reservations system we had to work with. Having a modern spa reservations system would allow for more time to be spent on clients and would cut down on entry errors.

review_title: A Place Where the People Matter
pros: Every Marriott property I have worked for has wonderful people. It sincerely has enriched my experience with the company to be graced with so many hard-working, genuine, intelligent, well-traveled fabulous people. If I can say one thing, it is that Marriott knows how to pick people who care about other guests and employees.
cons: Very VERY strict rules with no discretion from management. They pretty much play by the book... Even if it seems silly. I've seen some of the best employees get fired for forgetting to punch in and some of the worst employees I've ever seen stay with the company forever.... and they are still moving up into management.

review_title: It is an ok job but not career.
pros: For this area the pay is ok. The job itself is pretty easy. Just do your checklist and that pretty much it. You have the whole day to do what you need but if your just getting off at 7 am the only thing your probably going to want to do is sleep.
cons: If you're not use to working at night then it is going to take some time to get adjusted to. At times you may work at night or if they need you during the day then you have to re-adjust your sleep pattern. Guest at times can be a little more on the rude side for things that you have no control over. Then again many people who work in customer/guest service can relate to that.

pros: Although you start at the bottom as far as schedules go, but there is a real chance to move to a better schedule with your  stats. The pay is decent coworkers are great. And theres opportunities to work from home
cons: Downtime. It could be that it bothers me because I like to be able to constantly be in motion.  The stress on you to try and make your goals for the day when receiving horrible calls.

review_title: Great Organization to Grow Your Career With
pros: Great health, dental, vision, retirement, and travel benefits. Inviting culture throughout. It's your job to be happy and welcoming; the people attracted to hospitality are generally genuinely kind.
cons: Mandatory 50 hour work weeks for hourly managers. Operation positions (at a specific hotel) can be demanding as you need to keep a smile on your face 100% of the time, even if you are being berated by guests.

review_title: Non-monetary benefits far outweighed the salary benefits
job_title: Guest Service Representative in Vail, CO
pros: Great company culture, friendly staff, lots of training and resources, hotel consistently ranked very high in service rankings, and the benefits. Since the hotel was franchised by marriott and owned and operated by "Vail Resorts" you got to double dip in benefits. Within 3 months of being there, I had been given several thousand dollars in benefits.
cons: Not a lot of opportunity for advancement because a lot of the staff have been in the same role for many years. Salary is not great, there are some raises but they do not always accommodate the very heavy increase in cost of living in the area

job_title: Sales, Marketing, and Operations Manager in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Even though I am a part time, franchise employee, Marriott still provides some great benefits to its employees.  If you've worked at one hotel and decide to leave, you're still part of that hotel's family in some way.
cons: Marriott puts on the appearance of trying to recruit the best work force and about how personal and family oriented they are but the structure of the overall organization is still very much corporate.  I consider myself a very qualified, motivated, and passionate individual who has worked for two different franchises of Marriott and yet when I attempt to apply for managed or corporate positions I've been denied.  It's a very unfriendly appearance.

review_title: Very good in 1957 - still great in 2008
pros: Opportunities abound.  There is a place for creativity and ingenuity.  Community and global concerns are factors in our culture.  Overall, two of the best reasons are the wholesomeness of the organization and the enterprise, and the opportunity that exists due to the clarity of our mission and the leadership.  Slackers find their way out the exit doors.
cons: Our customers and associates are living in the era of rapidly advancing electronic technology.  That technology is largely absent in our hotel and work practices.  I assume some Marriott's have check-in kiosks, ours does not.  We use 20th century radio communication on our property and not for all logical means.

review_title: Great Job, No quality of life.
pros: Despite what I read from other reviews, there is a lot of opportunity for advancement
cons: LONG HOURS, 6 and 7 days a week are the norm. New vacation model of, use it or lose it, is not going to work for the associate. Back loading all vacation pay in the back half of the year, knowing that not everyone will be able to take it only benefits the corporation and not the associates. The chances of taking your full vacation time especially if you are in operations is unacheivable. Payout of difference would be a fair way to thank dedicated associates for working through their earned vacation. Instead it goes right back into the companies pocket.

job_title: Night Auditor, Front Desk Agent, Manager On Duty in Prescott, AZ
pros:
Management really tries to work with my schedule. They are strict but will praise your work regularly. They
always have fun events for staff and encourage a positive atmosphere.
cons:
The pay is the worst I've ever made. But I was still learning my position so I feel certain they will give me a
raise in the near future.

pros: The employees are wonderful. And the benefits wouldve been great if i ever got the chance to use them.

job_title: Guest Service Representative/Night Auditor in Washington, DC
pros: Benefits package, tuition reimbursement, 401k, job stability, meeting people from all over the world, open door policy, empowerment to make decisions, employee discount for employee and immediate family.
cons: As a 3 year employee I'm finding it's difficult to move up in the company. It's all about who you know and not the hard work being put in. Work/life balance. Constant back to back or double shifts. Week starts on Saturdays but schedule comes out on Thursdays. Pay can be low for the amount of work and stress dealt with on a daily basis.

pros: Work Life Balance, Easy work, Technology is behind most companies by at least 5-10 years especially in Contact Center.  Everyone is often so nice that its fake. Nobody dares challenge the current management that has been there for 20+ years because they are not innovative and not competitive.  A lot of dead weight around the office.
cons:
1) Hold back on positive feedback. But let the negative feedback fly. You don’t want your people getting too high on themselves. Positive feedback is the cotton candy of HR tactics; you don’t have time for this. On the flip side, these drones working for you aren’t going to learn their lesson unless they stop making mistakes. They need to fear making mistakes. That way, mistakes simply won’t happen!

2) Take credit for the work of others. Hey, you hired them. The glory is yours. Besides, your employees probably would have been embarrassed had you publicly recognized their great idea and nose-to-the-grindstone effort.

3) Get your employees hyper-competing with each other. Yes, we’re competing externally with a host of other talented, amazing companies. But competition begins from within, where employees duke it out in the employment octagon, leaving the most talented standing. We need to separate the wheat from the chaff; once that’s done, we can start cooperating and going after our competitors.

4) Ignore the great ideas of your employees. In fact, don’t even listen, unless it’s an idea worth stealing (see no. 2). You’re the one with the fancy degrees; these people work in lower positions for a reason, right? With a limited amount of precious time each day, mete out your listening carefully.

5) Keep dead weight around, but fire good people for no reason. And when it’s time to cut off some heads, do it with extreme prejudice and impunity. It’s best to keep your employees off-balance, sort of like a gunslinger making a poor sap dance by shooting at the ground near his feet. Keep ‘em limber and focused!

6) Haze outgoing employees. People quitting your organization are quitters. They need to feel pain for their betrayal, even if you’re providing them a dangerous narrative to share via word of mouth, social media, blog posts, future speeches, and so on.

7) Keep tabs on employees by stalking their social media accounts. And if you get a sniff of something you don’t like, ask for their personal passwords so you can log in and get the real scoop. Oh, you need not worry. It’s probably not yet illegal in your state. And they’re your employees; you deserve to know what they’re doing online.

8) Stop even thinking about work-life balance, because it has nothing to do with work. Get a grandparent to go pick up your puking child. We hired you to be here, working for us, and we expect you here. We don’t have time for sick children, nor your own sniffles. Athletes play through pain every day. Why can’t you and your kids do the same? Our company is on a mission, and we need to know you have skin in the game (otherwise, see no. 5).

job_title: Front Desk Agent in Atlanta, GA

review_title: HQ is horrible - don't be fooled by "Best Company to Work For" rankings
pros:
They're striving to become something bigger and better, and at the property level they do deliver consistent experience and stays.  Working hours are very flexible especially if you are a working parent.  If you are looking for a slower pace and simple work, or to coast, it's easy to do this at Marriott HQ.  If you are smart, it's really easy to get a good review and stand out.

Their CEO (Arne) is wonderful and you can tell is passionate about the company and employees.  He is compassionate and communicative with the organization, which a lot of large companies lack.
cons:
This review is based on HQ.  For anyone coming from the outside (i.e. non-Marriott "lifers"), esp from other Fortune 500s, I HIGHLY recommend you stay away.  BE WARNED!  Don't be fooled by their "Best Company to Work for" rankings - this is likely based on the on-property employees who have a different experience.  Marriott touts itself as an innovative, forward-thinking company who's breaking boundaries and changing the old Marriott ways.  It's ALL TALK. You will become very frustrated very quickly if you have a reputable work history.   The work is archaic, backwards, and very rudimentary; you will not learn, grow, or be challenged.   You have Directors at Marriott who wouldn't even cut it as an Associate at other companies.  The caliber of work you get from a lot of Marriott HQ employees is very hit or miss (more miss).  Your experience largely depends on which dept you end up in, however the feeling of discontent is widespread across all depts.   I wouldn't even know where to start re: how to fix Marriott; it's permeated throughout the whole organization, especially post-Starwood merger.  Their chaos happens at every stage: e.g. recruiters contacting you 6 mos after you've applied and then going MIA, teams bleeding money  with nothing getting done, HR not paying out final paychecks once an employee leaves and not responding (totally illegal), them doing the merger on their own with out the gel of a consulting firm, etc.  It's a testament to what Marriott is really like.   There's no forward thinking or strategy or intelligence being applied as a whole, and you will feel it as an HQ employee. 

Also, their benefits are meager in comparison to other Fortune 500 companies.  If you're an expectant mother, their mat leave is laughable.  They've been getting away with mediocre benefits based on their name and the fact there isn't much competition in the DC area, but that will likely change in the next few years if I had to guess.

review_title: Work interesting, work life balance good, pay terrible.
pros: The location is great, the people are nice, the work life balance is fanatastic, and there are tons of opportunities to move around.
cons: Definitely the pay.  I always felt underpaid.  There are some people in top positions that made it there because they did their previous jobs well, but they should not be leading large departments.  Additionally, people are afraid of looking bad so they don't share information.  Lastly, the company does not seem to value higher degrees.

pros: My direct manager is the reason I love working for this company no matter what it is my manager is always there to help me get better. If you show interest in wanting to move forward with the company and get promoted they are there to give you the tools to do so. Marriott is a company that would like to see there employees move up the chain and if you have a great manager they will help you to succeed.
cons: You can be forced to cross training at the particular  Marriott property I work at and yes it's fine to learn other departments but if that's not what I applied for then that me make the choice to not cross training right away.

review_title: Worked for Marriott International for over 15 years.  Started in the hotels and after several years ended at Headquarter
pros: Benefits including medical, dental, disability, profit sharing, vacation time, some departments offer telecommute and flextime,  daycare for a fee, exercise club for a fee, cafeteria, gift shop, post office. Associate rate for hotel rooms with good discounts.    Competitive pay.   Formalized HR and associate review policies.   Big company so many opportunities in different departments.   Respected company in the area.   If you are a person who is type A competitive and enjoy big company politics then this is the place for you...
cons: Although they claim, the company culture is still the same "we take care of the associates so that they take care of the guests" the company culture has changed signifigantly to be direct profit driven.  They no longer value expertise in the hotels or the hospitality industry and go out of their way to outsource and/or hire people outside of the hospitality industry.  This has resulted in not accomplishing objectives because the right people are not in the right jobs and therefore it takes more time, money to get anything done and in the end although they think they saved money but outsourcing they actually increase cost because of the lack of expertise and inefficiences.   Customer service is suffering as a result.   Departments are very sioled and each VP is more concerned with covering mistakes vs learning from them, and competitive to the point of  heeding progress.   Therefore switching departments and job growth is very difficult because of this competitive and siloed environment.  Associates are expected to work long hours to reach unrealistic deadlines with inappropriate staffing and is very stressful environment . Workload varies greatly between departments.    What was once a culture of collaboration and a work family is now one of  competitiveness and backstabbing.   I long for the days of the old Marriott ...

pros: Managers were incredibly committed to finding growth opportunities for me; they truly wanted me to succeed and gain a lot of experience this summer and always created time for me to talk to them, gain career advice, and get insights on the industry. The internship program itself is comprehensive with workshops, tours, weekly activities, and speakers. The culture itself is energetic and collaborative and innovative. Truly loved it.
cons: They don't really provide housing assistance (just advice on where to live) and transportation there can be a bit of a nuisance; they just put in a shuttle system from the metro though so it isn't too bad.

job_title: Food and Beverage in San Diego, CA
pros: Good view. Awesome associates (not management)
cons: Mentally exhausting. Unorganized management team. (All males). Let slack fall on employees. Don’t work WITH employees. Excuse certain behaviors in the work place because too lazy and just don’t care to handle it. (F&B department is a mess). HR department is unprofessional and very sketchy. Do not trust. “Higher up” managers treat department managers like puppets leading to stress, leading to unfulfilled duties, leading to slack and no attention on certain departments.

review_title: Thankful for the resume builder, but don't recommend.
pros: Large brand name with opportunity to build global marketing management experience for the largest hotel / travel company to date.  Creates opportunity to gain experience in the day to day of a global brand.
cons: Joining a company that has recently taken on a large acquisition is a challenge that even the most experienced candidate may never be ready for. The culture that emerges reflects power struggles, lack of clarity in roles and responsibilities, and long list of other struggles that are difficult to rise above.

job_title: Banquet Kitchen Supervisor in Baltimore, MD
pros: Used to work for almost 2 years, and training with a big Marriott hotel. I liked the overall environment, fair treatment for all employees, decent pay, the fact that a lot of employees are still working there since the opening says a lot. Recognition and feedback were good. No perfect place, but a good one. Marriott manages more than 3000 hotels in the world, hence it makes your travel much cheaper. One gets very good discounted rates at all properties, like Fairfield Inn, Courtyard, Rennaissance, Marriott. Having lots of properties makes promotions easier, as people move a lot among cities / countries / hotels.
cons: i think it depends on each hotel and each department head.

review_title: A nice place to work if you like what you do.
job_title: Golf Cart Attendant in Chicago, IL
pros: It was a nice, relaxing environment with kind people.  I had an easy job that I really liked: I worked on the resort's golf course servicing the golf carts.  I didn't have to deal with customers too often, but when I did they were usually pleasant.  My co-workers were nice, as well.  I think that getting to work outside makes for a nice environment.  It was never stressful, even on busy days or days with bad weather.
cons: Not too much opportunity to provide feedback or suggestions.  Management did not interact with lower-level employees to find out if their policies were successful or not.

job_title: Front Desk Associate in Saint Louis, MO
pros: From day one every person has been very welcoming and inviting ... my questions have been answered and the associates on my team have been very helpful in guiding me on the processes and procedures.
cons: With the many hours spent on my feet - I was not informed to wear comfy shoes ... it took about three weeks for me to realize I need NEW SHOES!!! I have been with Marriott for one month and I have not found a "downside" ... this has been a very positive new hire experience.

review_title: Marriott is the place that I look forward to retiring from.

pros: Its a really great company to work with. Everyone is friendly and professional. I have only been here a few months and am already discussing potential promotion with my manager. And if you are willing to be trained for higher positions, they are willing to train you!
cons: The only cons I can really think of is not great medical benefits, and low salary. I mean I guess $11/hr is okay, but for an adult its barely enough to get by.

job_title: Front Desk Associate in San Diego, CA

review_title: Fantastic Company to work for, but stressful environment

review_title: any type of work only in florence, Italy

review_title: Marriott is a great place to work!!!!
job_title: Senior Sales Manager in Lincoln, NE
pros: Working for Marriott allows you unlimited possibilities if you are willing to move.  The training structure available is awesome.  Communication within the hotel flows pretty free. cons: If you aren't willing to move, then the opportunities shrink immensely.  Sometimes the expectations are set too high, based on demand of the city.  It would be better if the owners were present more often within the hotel.  Most Marriott properties are not owned by Marriott, but are a franchise ownership.

review_title: balanced review from someone who took a job out of college
pros: If he/she wants to work in the Hospitality business this is a good start to be.  There is ample entry level opportunities.  The benefit are very good even for non union workers in some cases even better because dental and vision benefits are better than union workers.  Usually there is free lunch or dinner at most full service hotels too.
cons: Lack of training and growth, when there is a recession it can really be a problem because morale goes down and so does productively with workers.  Sometimes union/management problems can arise which is a distraction.

review_title: Marriott is great company but management sucks
job_title: Front Desk Agent in Tucson, AZ

Benefits
Training (if your at a Marriott Corporate owned location)

review_title: Courtyard Tarrytown, A great place to work
pros: Courtyard Tarrytown is a well managed hotel. Every employee is a  team player. Even the management from the GM to the front desk supervisor are willing and able to get their hands dirty. All are team players! Salary is equal to or better than the median and the benefits are good. The guest rooms are cleaned very well by the housekeeping staff and then inspected by either the housekeeping supervisor, GM or assistant GM. Respect among all workers, management and guests was a priority and was always present during every work day. I have to admit that I miss working there.
cons: None that I can think of.

review_title: Charlotte Marriott City Center (don't come here looking for a career)
pros: Working for the Marriott was an overall good experience in terms of benefits and team members.
cons: Don't take a job here if you don't have ample schedule flexibility, children, or a social life because the scheduling is often sporadic. Turnaround shifts are so common it begins to feel as if it is illegal to be working your staff 5 hours after they last worked. Opportunities to advance are common and accessible in the Marriott brand in general, but at this particular property there are very few opportunities if you don't go to college first. You could work here 15 years in every position expertly and you wouldn't get a management role because you lack a degree.

review_title: Not worth it in the long run

Definitely living pay check to pay check and not saving anything per month even though my living expenses are about as low as they can be. Marriott wages do not get that much better throughout your growth. I would say that financial compensation based on your work output is severely unmatched.

cons: There are not many cons but I guess the long hours could be one. It really just ends up becoming a balancing act at times between debating whether the long h9urs is worth all of the overtime hours (more money) you get. I have always found that it is worth it.

review_title: Skilled in most all aspects of kitchen services, work with a teamwork attitude and keep doing it.
pros: I love working in any kitchen and keep my areas clean all the time....Always refill foods the FIFO way..Work with a clean as you cook way... That keeps the area sufficiently clean most all the time even in a rush hour...
cons: I cannot stand a kitchen with full trash cans....The floors must be clean all the time so to speak....sometimes they do get dirty in rush times...clean them asap.

pros: Good Tips, other workers were very diverse and friendly, never a dull moment at work.  If you like staying active and are an early bird, this was a great job to be at.  I was out of work when everyone else was coming back from lunch. I loved it.
cons: Little down time and few time for breaks.  This is not the place to work if you're looking to hang out at work.

pros: Good health benefits, 401k, and other insurance programs. Spending accounts & tuition reimbursement. Tenure is rewarded & there is a lot of tenure in this company. The company's longevity is supported by its continual evolving but based on the simple principal of "if you take care of your associates they will take care of the guests".
cons: Work days are 10 hours and salary is based on a 50 hour week. Salaries are capped at percentage growth of promoted within the company. And annual increases (raises) are based on merit with the highest rating equals 3% annual increase

review_title: It's an okay company but poorly managed
pros: Pretty good benefits for employees
cons: Management unprofessional, the one decent manager we had, quit. I was accosted by two male guest and told management and nothing was done for my safety. One of the leads was rumored to steal tips from housekeepers. We were overworked and forced to work ten hour days sometimes without our consent then we would get yelled at by middle management for having "too much overtime" but really we weren't given a choice. Most employees are disgruntled for one reason or another which causes it to be a very negative work environment.

job_title: Front Desk Associate in Charlotte, NC
pros: Everyone is extremely professional and hardworking. Most employees have a very positive attitude, the managers are extremely helpful and try really hard to make sure that there is more of a family feel to the work environment.
cons: I have no cons really. Of course like any other job, this one can get busy, some of the customers can be hard to deal with and of course making sure that other people feel comfortable is never easy, but all of that is a given with any job. In conclusion, to work at the Marriott Courtyard in Charlotte Ballantyne is a great opportunity, and if that opportunity ever presents itself, you should definitely take it.

Big hotel with a lot of dept., and a lot of employees.

Supportive Senior Management.

review_title: If you work hard, opportunities are endless.

The most consistent hotel company in the business.  The biggest asset - people!  Endless opportunities, especially for those that want to move around.  If you do a good job, it gets noticed!
cons: Hours can be demanding at times.  Have to pay dues and work your way up the ladder.  Some management needs to walk to talk - too hands off.

review_title: Overall positive experience working at Headquarters
pros: Opportunity to move around HQ if you are proactive; I moved from Finance to Operations.  HQ facility is great -  has daycare, nice cafeteria, gym, post office, pilates.  Management and senior leaders have been in place a long time.
cons: Because many of the senior leadership team has been at Marriott for 20+ years, they may discount your pre-Marriott work.  Difficult to get into Operations if you have not worked in a hotel before.  They do not seem to value MBA's, they value your work while at Marriott.

pros: Great benefits. Of course working in operations has less than desirable hours and schedule, but the sales and event planning side offer a much better quality of life
cons: Hours can be long. Old school management see the quantity of hours just as important as the quality of the work... Therefore low performing employees don't get work done and are almost rewarded for it

pros: They offer development to young talent, if they show interest. They have some occasional staff perks.
cons: The lowest salaries in hospitality industry, which make their employees work overtime to earn enough to have a decent living. Their management is based on inflicting fear on subordinates - that is their way of keeping 'order'. They do not care for line staff and will only support the manager, even though they have feedback from other staff, that he is just an unbelievably horrible manager. They would even re-hire someone, who they know had a bad relationship with the team. If you want to feel respected at work and have a normal living standard, look for a job elsewhere.

pros: Great organizational climate. Teamwork and partnership are a constant day to day present in every shift. Flexibility is also present both in employees and supervisors, you can ask for days off depending on your personal priorities. Good place to work.
cons: The salary is low compare to the level of demanding expectations. Each shift you will have to fill a checklist that is way beyond natural human capabilities, so you will have to set priorities with your supervisor and you will have to be prepare to hear no compliments and many claims.

review_title: Great place to work but very chaotic in IT
pros: innovative, top talent and willing to take risks.  Growing fast as well.  Technology is at the core of their success and a force driving growth. Technological innovation is going to keep the business relevant to the millennials.
cons: It seems everything changes at the same time, sourcing, people, re-orgs, acquisitions and spin-offs, etc.  Change is good and necessary but unless it is done at a pace and order  that can be absorbed and  managed, It results in too many miss steps, false starts,  waste and chaos.

review_title: A Great Company with Room for Advancement
pros: I started as a valet/bellman and the job was really pretty simple. I was given more responsibilities as time passed and felt as if I could have advanced. Hospitality wasn't my career path but it was nice to know it was there. Overall, I highly rate them. This was a great college job and I truly had a blast.
cons: Sure, there are occasionally tough customers but by the same token, if you've ever hosted before, you'd been there. It's not a surprise. There can be tough personalities but that's fairly common. You also may have to stay late depending on late arrivals, high profile guests, etc. That's honestly all I can think of.

pros: Work ethic among top leaders is exceptional. Very talented and motivating leadership in most hotels. Put people first is the founders words and they live by it. Many paths to take within the industry.

Not a good place to work.

Lack of cooperation between departments. Short of staff in all departments. Poor pay. Lack of any help or respect from management of different departments (too busy, too important).
Sometimes very bad customer service presented by managers (especially reception) and then followed by other staff. The worst personal hygiene that I've ever seen presented by some of the staff especially food and beverage team!
Night covered by only one staff member for entire hotel which must be terrible stress hazard plus unsafe. Imagine fire alarm!

review_title: good availability to move up but very political
job_title: Assistant Front Desk Manager in Chicago, IL
