For as large as Chicago is your reputation if tarnished whatsoever can lead to promotions becoming nearly impossible within the market
cons: For as large as Chicago is your reputation if tarnished whatsoever can lead to promotions becoming nearly impossible within the market.  salary based on 50 hour work weeks which ends up not being very good for entry level management

review_title: Chewing more than they can swallow
job_title: Director of Sales in Kuala Lumpur
pros: Marriott Culture, resources, systems, tools, trainings
cons: All the pros are not being followed/utilized properly after the merger with Starwood, too much dust floating around, chaotic atmosphere. There is a lot of hate & an overall feeling of vengeance between former Starwood legacy employees & so called blue blood Marriott associates.  Everything that the company stood for until 4 -5 years ago has gone into the drain. No focus on employee well being anymore, all about making money. All work no play, no fun, only stress!

pros: Working in the hospitality area is a lot of fun, but it is also alot of hard work.  Marriott has many benefits and is recognized as one of the best companies to work for.
cons: The hours and the schedules are not always what you want.  It is very difficult to work in this industry and have a normal schedule.  This is not the fault of Marriott, ot is the industry as a whole.

pros: I worked in the Fine Dining and Bar area at the Marriott. My manager was one of the sweetest people to work under.  HR were very helpful. Hotel benefits were awesome, if you wanted to go on vacation and use your Marriott discount. Mr. Marriott will come in and greet his employees once a year or so, very nice and genuine person. We had an awesome GM that was always in a good mood.
cons: I was sad when another hotel brand bought the hotel, had it not been for school, I would have transferred to another Marriott hotel. After a the hotel changed its name, the GM was replaced and the hotel went down after that.

pros:
Meet new people from all over the world. 
Work with a fun team. 
Gain customer service experience. 
Get great discounts to stay around the world.
cons:
Agents are expected to be 100% attentive to the guests entering and leaving....all while doing a bunch of paperwork that needs to get done. If paperwork isn't done, agents get in trouble. If agents aren't on point with guests, that's another problem. 
Pay isn't that great for the amount of work there is for one person. 
Every day, rules are changing and new ones are implemented. 
Employees are written up for the silliest of things like if they were little kids.

pros: Great hotel, very classy, very friendly staff, easy job and was actually good paying. The job its self was great.
cons: Poor management, no communication. Everything I was told during my interview turned out to be a lie from how many rooms I had to clean to how long I had to clean them. The room care boss was the worst of it all, everyone would be getting along great and she'd go around talking about other girls stirring up drama. I have never seen anything like it before.

review_title: I love working at the courtyard!
pros: Lot of really great guests, fun coworkers, and General Manager who appreciates the team.
cons:
Not enough lead time on scheduling so planning anything outside of work is tough.

It seems that its harder to score an associate rate when traveling.  I used to have no problems getting $39 room nights a few months in advance so we could plan trips. This year they don't seem to be available.

job_title: Front Desk Agent in Portland, OR
pros: Good employee discounts, free breakfast for employees during morning shifts at Residence Inn.  Colleagues can be friendly depending on the individual.
cons: Lots of drama and gossip all around. Didn't feel appreciated as an employee at all. Management only cares about revenue and will cut hours all the time without reason if they feel it needs to be done, regardless if you're considered a full time employee.

review_title: An amazing company to work for, however depending on which franchise you work for greatly depends on your career experie
job_title: Assistant Food and Beverage Manager in Lima, OH
pros: Decent pay,  meet new people everyday,  chance to grow within company.
cons: No work life balance,  high employee turn over rate,  unless new title no raises,  no set hours,  long shifts,  lack of team work,  lack of management communication,  lack of management accountability and follow through

review_title: Good Hospitality Company to Work for Overall
pros: Most managers genuinely care for employees. Benefits are very competitive, great 401k with company match. Company has great values that most properties stand behind.
cons: If you happen to work for a manager that isn't accommodating things can be a little rough. Company has gotten so big that the overall values of the company are not lived out at some properties.  Schedules can be awful with no consistency. Hours can be long.

job_title: Guest Service Agent in Toronto, ON
pros: Staff as a collective garner a genuine passion for Hospitality.
cons:
Outdated system (FSPMS, MARSHA), doesn't seem to plan on switching over to more user friendly applications "as it has been one of the pioneer hotel properties put up in Canada".

Outdated practices that ultimately takes more time to complete in comparison to other hotels I've worked in. Absolute refusal to try and amend these ongoing issues as far as I've been employed with this company. 

Current property in particular needs a complete overhaul, sluggish staff included.

review_title: Non-pay internship up to 50 hours per week with limited over time working is fine. Management is easy to approached.
pros: Management is well-known. It is the biggest convention center in the city. The senior management are taking care of young interns and willing to provide chances to switch to same level different positions. Free meal, shuttle bus are provided. Employees could have lockers and take shower before or after work. Nice uniforms.
cons: Really low payment to college graduates and entry-level positions. Far away from downtown, although free employee shuttle bus is provided, still takes an hour and half to get back to the city.

pros: The staff that I got to work with was phenomenal. I was able to easily connect with other employees and establish real relationships with all of them. The hours were also a plus, I was able to work early in the morning to around 3 in the afternoon.
cons: The compensation for the amount of work that I had to put in was not equal to the workload. I was barely able to pay my bills let alone buy anything outside of the payments I had to make.

pros: I worked 3rd shift also known as Night Audit. Wasn't a bad experience. One of my favorite jobs. Was able to study for classes and get paid for it, how can I complain? Shift was 11PM-7AM.
cons: All the employees were always late. You're up all night and always waiting on the next person to show up. People would call off with no penalty on a regular bases. They want you to cover when others call off with little to no notice. Refuse to fire anyone no matter the reason, call off regularly, show up late, doesn't matter your job is safe. These problems could have easily been avoided if they would just google the persons name before hiring.

pros: Lots of opportunity for growth and development. Large company easy to stay with the company. Good benfits are offered. Hires and promotes within the company often
cons: Their proformance annual reviews and feedback are designed exceptionally well but they fail to teach management to properly use the review tools and give proper feedback to employees. Management can forget that employees value life outside work when business demand increases leading to downturn in moral in employees

review_title: Regional Sales Office is nothing but a call center
job_title: Sales Manager in New York, NY
pros: Great place to start a career, training is the best  and growth opportunities are good up until a certain point.
cons:
Faternity style atmosphere ,many  males get promoted due to their relationships they have with management and not the work they put in, hard work and effort can go unrecongnized unless you play the game. 
Company has moved into a very unpersonalized sales force, depending on your position, you have to wait for 5 other people to get promoted before you can even think about being promoted.

job_title: Assistant General Manager in Dallas, TX
pros: I now know how to score free nights at Marriott Properties
cons:
TownePlace as a brand is not well know. Marriott is more concerned about making new and other brands so it can make more money. It doesn't put the necessary support and resources in the current brands to make them more well known by the public.

Marriott offers very little to no corporate support to the franchise companies. 

They place rules and regulations on certain travel programs, but don't back up properties when they try to enforce the rules. They are more concerned with the money to be made.

review_title: disappointing experience, the property standard is well below the acceptable industry standard.
pros: good start for freshers, lots of training and hand holding, Marriott offers freshers a first time look at world class hospitality systems.
cons: work life balance non -existent, arrogant bosses, poor quality of work specific training, gaps in knowledge and poor property setup, salaries well below the industry standard.

pros: Love the people, culture, and mutual respect everyone has for each other. Flexible time, fun leaders, fast paced. Everyone I met had been there forever, said they'd never leave because they loved it so much.
cons: A lot of corporate red tape that can get annoying when trying to move projects forward. People are sometimes slow to respond to emails, which can be frustrating at times. HR can be slow to act too, which is also frustrating if you're in a rush to get started with your new job.

job_title: Loss Prevention Officer in Orlando, FL
pros: They have special assignments called "Details" that pay 20hr.  You can sign up on a sheet as much as you want.  Comes in handy when you need extra pay.  Plus the details are usually very easy.  You can bring a laptop and watch a movie your entire shift while watching equipment/room.
cons: The base pay is terrible!  The management is terrible.  Though it is getting better.  The job entails that you do "bio's."  "Bio's" (Bio Hazards) consist of feces, vomit, blood.  Worst part of the job

job_title: Food and Beverage Associate in London, England
pros:
I love the team, they are amazing and fun, and we always help each other and have a laugh together.
I love the guests, they can be amazingly friendly, and when they are satisfied they are very greatful.
Good tips, and canteen food is available.
Amazing enviroment, beautiful hotel.
cons: The money is very little, for a five star hotel. They expect more from the employees than what they pay them for. You can feel valued by the guests, but not by the higher management, they don't value a regular associate at all.

pros: People have drunk the koolade and do their best to prove the concept that ignorance is bliss.  Without the collective delusion it would be harder to tolerate.  That said most of the GMs are far more credible leaders than those in the corporate teams.
cons: Barely scrapes above the minimum levels of pay.  Does not invest significantly in development of its employees and will struggle in the evolving internet age to compete and stay relevant.  The brand may be appealing but the not all hotels are within the group.

pros: Coworkers are amazing! Amazing Management! Full benefits, company perks, and great staff.
cons: The only cons are the 1 or 2 rude guest you have to deal with. But dealing with those 1 or 2 guest more than makes up for all the pros you get while working for this company.

pros: My best reason for working for Marriott I enjoy dealing with people on a regular basis. I make them feel at home knowing they travel all the time. I learn their likes and dislikes and all their special requests. My guests becomes family and I make sure  they as comfortable as possible.
cons: The downside of working for the Marriott is when it's time to say goodbye to guests who's been with us over 6 months & longer.

pros:
Nice employee discount when it's available. 
They seem to prioritize hiring internally before externally, and its nice that non-management can post for another position after 6 months.
cons:
It can be hard to get good employee rates unless you book months in advance or in locations/on dates that are not in high demand. 
Also, horrible pay. Very unfair to pay employees so low, especially the ones that work in metropolitan areas where the cost of living is higher. There is no reason employees should have to commute 1+ hours each way every day because they can't afford to live where they work.

review_title: Marriott- A great place to work if you want no life of your own
pros:
good benefits
good opportunities to move up, as long as you are willing to dedicate your entire life to work
cons:
24/7 job with not a lot of personal time
not a lot of flexibility with schedules
very "associate" oriented, although this always seems to exclude Managers (very hypocritical)

job_title: Group Sales Manager in Hartford, CT
pros: Quality product  - training and upwardly advancement opportunities. Product maintenance and quality are always top notch - standards are adhered to. Leader in this market, while a franchise operation, very much supported by Marriott Corporation. Top rated hotel in the market is a draw for leisure and corporate groups alike. Local reputation as well as national - a magnet for convention business being adjacent to convention center and for leisure especially when science center is completed.
cons: Takes a lot of effort to stand out on the corporate side. Sales is formulaic and often reduced to the process of just filling out forms.

review_title: Lots of hard work and hours but well worth it because i made a ton of money in tips
job_title: Room Service and Bartender in Lexington, KY
pros: they allow you to work your way up within the company. management and supervisors are very good at watching out for you.  they take care of employees so in turn employees will take better care of customers
cons: lots and lots and lots of hours. sometimes work can be overwhelming cause you have to stay so late but its worth it cause of the money

job_title: Front Office Manager in Provo, UT
pros: Every Marriott I've worked at is very good at treating their employees well. This will vary a little depending on whether the property is a franchise or managed by corporate, however, the culture Marriott encourages is very positive regardless of the management.
cons: When starting out in the industry the pay can be pretty low. Working in departments like housekeeping can be a very thankless job with very high standards and very little time to accomplish them. Departments like the front desk can be very stressful and sometimes the guests can be the worst part of the job.

review_title: Great benefits and room for employee advancement
pros:
Excellent Management 
Great Benefits
Plenty of training to help employees advance in their careers
Easy to be promoted with hard work and commitment to company (2-3 years minimum) 
Higher level jobs obtainable with degree 
Cares about employee health; offers health and wellness programs
Exciting employee events to connect departments and invite family
Paid volunteering opportunities 
Opportunities for cross-training into other departments
cons:
Seeks younger generation of workers
Promotions may plateau without advanced degree 
Level of happiness can range depending on department management and location

pros: Working for Marriott's GRS&CC office in Omaha has been one of the best experiences of my career! With such a large company it has been great to see that all of our associates are taken care of!
cons: Unfortunately, there is a lack of ability to work as a remote associate. This is something that is normally accessible, however, with the need to move to Sacramento,  not being able to work more than 50 miles from the office is forcing me to look for other employment.

review_title: Countless opportunities if you are willing to be flexible and patient
job_title: Guest Service Agent in Irvine, CA
pros: Great culture, family feel at your property, discount is great and benefits are nice to have. Overall the company is great to work for and at the lower levels the schedule flexibility is great if you are going to school or have another job.
cons: Some disconnects exist between upper management and the rest of us. Don't always feel like you make a real difference. Hotel pay isn't great for a long term career until you make it to upper management.

review_title: Perfect company for the high-energy, high-stress individual.
pros: Interesting work with many opportunities if you are willing to work hard. Decent salary and benefits. Outstanding day care center at Corporate HQ. Deep hotel discounts ($29 to $69 per night) for leisure/pleasure travel. Matching 401K and stock options.
cons: Highly competitive and stressful environment. Corporate jobs are 10- to 12-hour workdays. Prima donnas everywhere in senior management; tons of in-fighting and back-stabbing. Projects languish forever b/c no one wants to make a decision.

pros: Marriott has one of the friendlies staff members and the team work is incomparable. I have always wanted to work for a company that I really liked and not just needed for a check, and now I have found it and I plan to grow and mature with the company.
cons: As with any job you will always have challenges and one of the biggest challenges that I see is when people get set in their ways and are not willing to accept change.

review_title: Great company who genuinely care for their employees
pros:
-Depending on your department and your manager, they are very flexible with hours. I was a full time student and worked full time, and scheduling was barely an issue.
-If you work full time you're eligible for health care benefits 
-Great hotel discounts for employees
-Great pay
-A lot opportunity to move up in the company
cons:
-Stagnant communication from lower to upper management
-Departments don't always get along management wise
-Cafeteria food is low-tier

pros: Forward-thinking company always striving for better. Constant development and initiatives are implemented to beat out competitors, adapt to global change, and remain the number one lodging business amongst its competitors. Great health benefits.  Steady growth opportunities. Bill Marriott occasionally visits properties to see the vision through--a people's person.
cons: Appointed leadership is not always competent across the board in their area of management. Not a bad company to work for but sometimes the people working for the company set a bad reputation unethically related to the company's mission and goals.

job_title: Front Desk Associate in Mishawaka, IN
pros: I had such a wonderful time, from the interview process till my last week as an employee before I had to head back to school.  They were so welcoming and so understanding all the time, which made my job all the more fun and enjoyable.
cons: The uniform was god awful, but at least I was able to have my first summer in a suit, which was a pretty fun experience - as I approach getting into the real world in less than a year!

job_title: Front Desk Agent in Dayton, OH
pros: Its a great company and most of the employees I've been that have been there for 4+ years are great and helpful!
cons: But I make only 8.50 to work my a33 off! I pick up the slack in every direction that I can see and yeah I got "rewarded" but they put my $150 "reward" into my regular pay putting me into a higher tax bracket basically taking that 150 back. When I work right next to a McDonald's where they are making $14 an hour to be a33 holes and make dog food...

pros: Daily Physical exercise, tips, work friendships, working together as a team, guest interaction, work experience, good paychecks if you show up to work daily.
cons: Very physical, dirty rooms, attitudes of others who do not want to be a team player, call ins and no shows. Have to look for your own linens when laundry Attendant doesn’t show up for work.

review_title: Not an honest hotel in Bellevue
pros: Like the people I work with, friendly people, bus benefits are good . Enjoy the workers in the kitchen and the chef is great
cons: Our place is now run by Marriott in Bellevue Washington. They lied to us in the time we became Marriott. They told us we would get holiday pay and now they paid us and took it away saying we should not be paid for holidays. I needed that money and they took it back. They Hr people constantly lie to us and now they steal our money away. They can not be trusted. No one trusts them because of all the lies. Can someone help get us our money back?

pros: Place in good location down town.
cons: Unprepared supervisors , awful system to work with ,   Pressure all time , quality of calls very poor , harassment , unmotivated environment.

review_title: Great people, bad opportunity and pay
pros: The people are very friendly and the atmosphere is entertaining.  You would be hard pressed to find a better group of friends, but not bosses.
cons: They are understaffed when business is high and overstaffed when business is slow, which makes it difficult to balance work and family (no time off).  They do  not give raises when they are deserved.  They will praise you constantly but never reward you for it.  It can be frustrating.

job_title: Director of Engineering in Munich, Bavaria
pros: Benefits, retirement plan, hotel discount benefit, you plenty of options to re-locate and experience other parts of the country or other countries.
cons: Some of the challenges at this company are that the pay for the hourly associates is not comparible to the industry and therefore are unable to secure associates with the skillset needed to do a professional job. They also overwork the upper management. Though the pay was good, I am not sure the sacrifice was worth the money earned.

job_title: At Your Service Agent in Munich, Bavaria
pros: Work-life balance was great! Several discounts with different affiliated companies. Great benefits. Endless amounts of opportunities to move up the ladder. Compensation was always the highest in comparison to the competitors.
cons: Former and some current people in leadership that bends the rules too often and not following policy guidelines. Too many people using FMLA as an EXCUSE for everything (i.e. used to get days off if they don't want to work) and not what it was intended for. Besides that, everything was great!

review_title: Good people, stable company, satisfying work, poor pay.
pros: Working with people with good work ethic towards common goals makes up for some of the difficult customer issues that are part of the hospitality business.
cons: The bottom line surpassed the founding Mr. Marriott's emphasis of putting people first.  There is little feeling of loyalty towards the employees but the company still expects loyalty from tbe employees.  If thr paid better they would earn my loyalty better.  They did away with merit increases and salary caps are very low so earning potential is non existent unless you skip from job to job and location to location.

pros: Marriott is a fantastic place to work.  Marriott has such great values, operating in such a deeply ethical way.  Its a company that you can be proud to work for.  They also offer wonderful benefits
cons: I don't really feel there are any major cons, but it is a huge company with hundreds of thousands of employees.  Depending on where you work, the main access to HR might be to call into the benefits line.  I'm sure you could always reach an HR professional at the hotel properties or at least be connected to someone via phone or e-mail.

pros: The benefits are great and there is tons of opportunity for advancement. Most of the managers really want their employees to succeed, and they treat you that way.
cons: Sometimes it is hard to use the hotel discounts, and being in the service industry turnover tends to be higher than average. This can sometimes get in the way of production, but overall it's a great company to work for.

review_title: Good pay but management is very weak
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Oxon Hill, MD
pros: Good pay for front desk and agents that answers the phone start at $15hr by the end of the year you can make up to $20.Housekeeping start as $16.The pay for all departments is ok.Great discount on hotels for employees and free food.
cons: hypocrites management team only few of them are friendly.Managers would gang against other employees especially when they don’t like you.Too much favoritism.Employees and management having affairs which is unprofessional.Its a very stressful place to work.The first month is fine.Worst of all, your boss would pretend they care and when you confide in them just be ready to hear your personal business in the office.If you still want to work for this particular property.GOOD LUCK.Get to work,do your job and leave.WORST PLACE EVER TO WORK .THEY CARE ABOUT THE MONEY NOT EMPLOYEES.Mr Marriott needs to know that.

review_title: Front desk is a good Job to me

pros:
Marriott helps me get experienced and have so much skills.
to work for Marriott helps me enlarge my abilities and competencies to the worldwide competition
cons: it keeps busy because you cannot do other while you are performing your duties at Marriott. and it will make you feel stressed (bored) when you are alone and nothing to do with at the duty time

pros: The program is fast-track to a management level position if you have a passion for the hospitality industry. You will develop leadership and customer service skills as you will manage large departments. Marriott is a company based off networking and the program gives you many opportunities to network with leaders in the company.
cons: Expect long hours for a very low hourly rate. The contract is for at least 10 hours a day but there will be weeks where you will average 11-12 hours per day. The program is said to be a leadership program but the Voyagers are in reality inexpensive well-educated managers.  You are a manger in training and expect to be treated like one.

pros: Benefits, Culture, Room Discounts, Programs, Ability to transfer departments within 6 months of starting a position, Great 401k and profit sharing, Paid Time Off starts almost immediately after you start working.
cons: Hard to balance work and family life, Have little to no option when it comes to getting holidays off, poor compensation for lower management position

review_title: Great service to its customer, not so much for its employees
job_title: Front Desk Agent in Miami, FL
pros: Hotel discounts. Meet new interesting people.
cons: Too many chiefs and no Indians. There are more supervisors at the front desk than regular employees. The hours are long and random. There are times were you will work back-to-back shifts or shifts that won't allow you to rest appropriately. A hotel is open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, all year long. There are 5 different shifts to work from. This really messes up with your sleeping cycle. More cons: Getting yelled at by guest. Getting yelled at by managers. If a guess complains about ANYTHING, you get written up. Three write-ups in 6 months and you are FIRED. Moreover, its like a school yard behind the scenes. Especially if you work in a hotel with 600+ rooms. More employees = more drama.

review_title: Good and interesting work but be prepared to be married to your job
pros: Good company with solid reputation as a business and an employer. Interesting and different job opportunities are available if you carefully build your network.
cons: At HQ, the spread of work is not even close to even. Diligent employees carry the dead weight of people who have long ago outlived their value. Marriott lifers love hotels more than they love being home and they expect the same of their associates. Be prepared for long hours and low pay relative to the amount and intensity of the work. If you're a parent, do your homework so you're not surprised by the skimpy leave benefits.

pros: Great pay, flexible schedule, great growth opportunities. Longevity... We have 9 bartenders in our department, our combined number of years working the same job is over 200... That alone says more than any pro I can mention...
cons: With so many years of experience doing the same job, with the same staff and many of the same guest comes a great deal of knowledge. We are familiar with what will happen and when. Many of our guest have become like family and we know what works and what does not. Management should use our knowledge to help the lounge exceed...

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Aliso Viejo, CA
pros: Many people take the position to get a foot in the door of the hotel. If this is your intention it is worth a try but you have to network. its fun to be a part of a big hotel as you get to meet a lot of people.
cons: EXTREMELY corporate, all about the "brand" and "assets". all employees are extremely disposable. no respect or reward for hard work. dont expect any raises. salaries are flat and non negotiable unless you are exec admin.

pros: Good treatment of employees. Good benefits and perks of working for the company. Many chances to advance career within the company.
cons: Having to work weekends and holidays, as hotels and resorts never close. Upper management is very involved with teams below them. While this a pro in many ways, there were problems with fraternization between managers and their subordinates, and favoritism.

pros: Flexible schedule 30 hours is full-time can work from home fully vested from start 401k Vision Dental short term disability life insurance open 24/7 split shifts promotes from within
cons: Multiple policies that threaten termination for simple infractions little training company changes multiple things without notification to agents customers will know the information ahead of employees poor communication with upper management to sales if you say anything (I do mean literally anything) negative about the company you will be disciplined

review_title: Love working for Marriott! Everything anyone could ever ask for in a great job that focuses on your advancement!
pros: 401(k), health insurance, vision, dental, choices in affordable healthcare, free short term disability and 12 weeks maternity leave.  The ability to live and work any where in the world and now even more opportunities available due to the acquisition of the Starwood Hotels.  The Employee Federal Credit Union has also been a great financial move as well.
cons: Not easy to get into from the outside as they like to hire from within but once one has their foot in the door, your possibilities are endless.

pros: teamwork between departments, level of talent, the dedication each employee brings to the table to increase the guests experience, use of local products to stay sustainable, atmosphere positive, ability to be flexible, one on one with guest service
cons: communication, upper management involvement,  management team concern about numbers and not the employee personal, (some managers were nice, but others avoided face to face confrontations)

pros: Work/Life Balance; Family oriented culture; growth potential; free parking; salary was great, and benefits were great
cons: EA's/AA's should be afforded the same opportunities across the company. Some managers would expect you to produce but not give you the necessary resources to do so. In other departments the EA's/AA's were afforded that opportunity and thrived more and learned more and were able to move into Project Manager positions within the company.

review_title: Great place to start...but there are others that pay more
job_title: Revenue Manager in New York, NY
pros: The travel benefits are nice...the discounted rooms are a big benefit when taking a big trip.  Lots of room to move if you are in operations...but not if you want to become a director
cons: Making the move from Manager to Director is very difficult...Marriott's growth is now in select service hotels and more and more of the Sales and Revenue areas are being clustered creating limited promotions.  The only true way to boost your pay is to move...but the problem is there aren't any places to move.

pros: Marriott seems to be a place that offers career advancement, but only if you're looking to move to another property. The company culture is great and everyone feels valued as well.
cons: It's extremely hard to move up within one property. Promotions are few and far between, unless you're willing to move to another property.

review_title: fun, fast-paced place to work, great customer service experience
pros:
Huge hotel discounts

Get to meet a lot of people

There are slow days, but (depending on the hotel) you are always on the go, which makes time go by faster

Good experience for customer service and professionalism. 

If you are not a good multi-tasker, you will be after working a front desk
cons:
I thought the compensation could have been a bit higher, considering that front desk is the face of the hotel.

Front desk is where all the complaints come to, even if it has nothing to do with you. 

As a front desk associate, you are asked to help out anywhere and everywhere in the hotel, when needed.

pros: I've worked for 5 companies, large and small, since I started my career 17 years ago. This is, by far, the best. The pay is solid, the company plans fun events for employees, the hotel discount is fantastic, the company's branding and communications make me proud to work here. Most coworkers are nice, fair, and even fun. But it is a large company so there are exceptions for sure.  Senior leaders make sound business decisions, which have made the company the leader in its industry.  If you don't like your current role, it's fairly easy to find another position internally. The Marriott family and the CEO feel strongly that it's important to strike a work/life balance and they encourage us to spend time with our families and get enough sleep. :)
cons: There are 2 things that bother me - the annual survey doesn't do an adequate job of identifying and fixing problems in the workplace. Marriott doesn't really use it that way (HR, you know what I mean). So employees just need to leave the company or switch internally if they don't like their situation. In particular, Marriott needs to do a better job of weeding out the terrible managers who demoralize employees. I also don't like the way the 401K is set up. An employee needs to be at the company for a long time before the 401K match kicks in, THEN the match for your full year doesn't get deposited until many months after the year is over. I was there for 18 months before getting any match.

review_title: Job Security Not Always a Good Thing
pros:
Once you've been with the company for 6 months it's almost impossible to be fired
Great hotel discounts
cons:

job_title: Food and Beverage Supervisor in London, England

review_title: Magnificent Marriott, come join our fabulous team.
job_title: Senior Sales Manager in Manhattan Beach, CA

pros: Overall Marriott is an outstanding company to work for. Employees get to enjoy some of the benefits and perks such as 401k match, hotel room discounts, food and beverage discounts, partnership affiliates discounts, health benefits just to name a few.

Free meals.

job_title: Front Desk Associate in New Albany, OH

job_title: Front Desk Agent in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Travel benefits, flexible schedule, health insurance. This is a position where anyone with half a brain and two hands can do. cons: Low pay, moving up in position may be challenging. It can be a loathsome if you have poor leadership and company morale.

review_title: great place to stay, not so good to work here

review_title: Marriott is great as far as hotels go, but for hourly employees, it's def a job not a career

review_title: A good learning platform for overall Food and Beverage product and service.

You are not contained to just one department. Being a small hotel, if any other department is busy, you can always offer help and the best is, people do it on their own. review_title: I was dissappointed and embarrased with the staff, the maintenance, and the food.

review_title: Upper management is disconnected in their decision making processes.

pros: Marriott is a name which is associated with very high standards and expectations. The benefit package which the company offers for the employees is good. Good to have this name in your CV.

review_title: Overall an excellent place to work
job_title: Front Desk Agent in Cincinnati, OH

review_title: Progressive, quaint property with staff that work as a team makes it an easy sell to clients and customers.

review_title: Lack of ethics, racism and harassment
pros:
Interesting work 
Strong, positive culture (sometimes)
cons: I undoubtedly had one of my worst experiences working here. There's a lot of harassment that occurs (even at a corporate level) that leaves people disgruntled and, at extreme levels, mentally ill. For fear of losing their jobs, nobody ever speaks out and the situation spirals only for the worse. Personally, I received rude, ignorant and undoubtedly racist comments such as ' don't you find it interesting how people from particular countries get discriminated upon' by colleagues. I sympathize with the lack of professionalism at Marriott's office. If you are a person of color, I would strongly advice you not to apply here.

review_title: "If we take care of our employees they will take care of us"

review_title: I absolutely miss working at the marriott.

pros: Good product in good locations allowed for good networking with fellow associates and helped get access to customers.  We competed but we also helped each other when needed.  The sales associates really tried to help each other when possible
cons: Feels like it stopped being run by hoteliers and now run by number crunchers, HR-folk and legal departments.  Hospitality doesn't feel like the #1 objective - now it's sales, flow-through and stakeholder/shareholder satisfaction before guest satisfaction.

review_title: Great company, options for movement, respectful workplace.
pros: Marriott offers great benefits include an associate discount at Marriott hotels (when available). Managers encourage you to train in other positions or take on new tasks to promote growth, and actively try to build your skills.
cons: In an Accounting/Finance role, there are few options for promotion. There is typically only one progression: General Accountant, Assistant Director of Finance, Senior Assistant Director of Finance, Director of Finance. From there you may move between hotels in the same role for the rest of your career.

review_title: I learned what NOT to do when it comes to hotel/restaurant management
pros: Employees were still happy and pleasant to work with.
cons: Location. Fine dining rest. was owned by Marriott & managed by another company so we were constantly getting pulled in different directions "do this, no do that. no that isn't working why did he tell you to do that?" Day in and day out I saw how stressed out this made my managers. Hotel management blamed our food for not bringing in business, when it really wasn't.

pros: Very friendly and inviting co-workers. My managers are very helpful and always there to help. Everyone is fun to be around and they function more like a family while still maintaining the business aspects.
cons: I just graduated with a Finance degree and took a front desk position to get my foot in the door so the pay is not good at all. I make $8.25 and hour and only get 20-30 hours for right now (I was hired in December, still training). I have not picked a benifits package yet so I cant comment on that.

review_title: I had high expectations of this company
job_title: Sales Representative in Hollywood Park, TX
pros:
Marriott has a great company culture. They are "supposed to" treat their employees exceptionally well because as Mr. Marriott always said, "Take great care of your employees, and in turn, they will take great care of your guests" 
Awesome hotel discounts. During the 4th quarter of the year, there is an even bigger discount on top of your ALREADY discounted rate. 
Good employee recognition programs and events. 
SO much opportunity for advancement. You can apply for a new position every 6 months.
cons: This is of course, only for the location I was working at, which was the Sales & Reservations Center. The position is in a call center and the calls never stopped. There is a goal you have to meet as far as converting calls into reservations but its really not hard and if you don't meet it, management coaches you on what you can do better. Its kind of a low paying wage so the type of people who apply for this job are often young, inexperienced and extremely immature. I was often embarrassed upon hearing the way some of my coworkers sounded on the phone and how rude they were to guests. There were a lot of bad apples working there and because of them, we were ALL treated like children at a playground. Management lacked maturity as well, showed a lot of favoritism and treated their entire team like kids, always dismissing any concerns or frustrations. If you are a mature responsible adult, looking for a real career opportunity, I would not apply at the call center. You will be very unhappy.  I haven't completely given up on Marriott yet, I may just try my luck at a hotel property, NEVER AGAIN at the call center.

review_title: Great place to start young career with great benefits and promising pay
pros: There were lots of advancement opportunities, along with great benefits outside of hotel discounts and 401k programs. Company culture was strong, along with great coworkers as the result of proper interview processes. Company tries to give you the days off when requested.
cons: Challenging hours at times as well as moderate increases in pay in SOME departments and roles. Management could use more help, but the economy could be in part to blame for insufficient staffing.

NICE FOR THAT BIG FAMILY VACATION!

The pay is also not the best, which weighed into me deciding to leave.

review_title: Great people, but bureaucratic management stifles innovation
pros: They have above average corporate facilities (cafeteria, open work space, fitness center, Starbucks) and benefits (education reimbursement, training, lodging discounts, health incentives). There is a genuine culture of employee appreciation (Associate Appreciation Week) and community engagement(Spirit to Serve day). My Marriott friends are the best, and I engage with them at every opportunity. Compensation was competitive, but the health plan was average/below average - I opted to get coverage through my wife's plan with Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield. Opportunities to travel to interesting locations for business or brand development at various levels, such as staff auditors, etc.
cons: While training and education discounts are offered, I found very little managerial support for advancement within or across functions. Networking is challenging in that there are many managerial layers to deal with. In my experience, only two people in my Information Resources (IT) department of 25 advanced to outside positions in 7 years, with only one going outside of IR. This particular group also spent a lot of time stepping over dollars to pick up dimes -in other words, they were more interested in creating processes to justify their existence than in delivering real value for end users in terms of ease of IT asset procurement and management. This is typical of many business support functions where Senior Directors are cowed by the SVP's to simply do as they're told. Recognition felt superficial and forced, and while some managers were capable of more, the default response to any service delivery issue was to kiss up and kick down. There is an uneven policy for flexible work arrangements, and that created a burden on those who are on site constantly putting out fires. The on-going organizational restructuring and outsourcing of Marriott's management services places a lot of stress on Associates who either leave for outside opportunities or grind it out while surrounded by increasing numbers of external vendors and consultants. They endure by escaping to the gym when the boss doesn't schedule a brown bag lunch meeting, or taking as many coffee breaks as they can.

Yet with every passing quarter or month the company continues to get bigger.  You have no voice, yet you have your job that pays well and can support your family.  All the employees use the analogy "I too drank the cool aide"   After the aquisition of Starwood the company now hows 30 brands of hotels consisting of more than 5 thousand hotels all across the globe!  I think they are more than 50% larger than the next closest competitor such as IHG, Hilton, Hyatt etc.  Every week there were mass company emails welcoming i another VP over this department which you may have never heard of.  A lot of speakers would come in and talk and yet you were not quite sure why they were there or what the point of the meeting was.

review_title: A Once Great Company In Decline
pros:
-Can work anywhere in the world and virtually the same systems will in place - "brand standards."

-Many people circulate within larger hotels, so you can have the good fortune of working with many of the same great associates.

-When corporate culture that is portrayed as standard is in place, this is a fabulous company with high morals, and quality associates and managers.

-All sorts of interesting people come through the door as associates and many good times are had.  We are a family unit under the best of circumstances.
cons:
-Marriott has been for about 5 years now doing everything they can to cut expenses, no matter the consequences towards our core goals as a company.

-Lack of consistency within management towards guests and associates.  Guests are given the benefit of the doubt - even when they are abusive towards staff.  Guests are rewarded with comps and upgrades for bad behaviour in many circumstances.

-GSS (Guest Satisfaction Survey) is given too much credence as a tool.  Careers/Reviews are made and broken based on a flawed mechanism of survey.  In a busy conference hotel we may have 15,000 check-ins per month, perhaps 100-200 or so guests will return surveys, and based on that feedback we get our scores of Overall Satisfaction, etc.  Too much emphasis is pushed through this mechanism via corporate, however the reality is the owners (not Marriott) don't care as long as the hotel makes money.

-Punitive actions are not consistent.  Rules are enforced one month and not the next, etc.  There will be concerted pushes by managers to push certain associates out for minor infractions, that other associates will just be talked to about given the same circumstances.

job_title: Front Desk Supervisor in Seattle, WA
pros: The employee benefits are great. The associate discount is awesome, especially during winter (extra 50%-off rate) and you're welcome to extend it to friends and family.
cons:
The difference between properties and corporate are dramatic. I fell in love with the philosophy of Marriott, but the properties themselves struggle to live up to it. Showing appreciating to associates is limited to "budgets" and scraps by on the minimum. For example: my last property expected the Holiday Party for 100 associates plus family (about 200 people) to be thrown on a $500 budget including food. That's $5 per associate and family for drinks, food, and anything beyond trade-outs. Completely disappointing. Then, after that's all done, we get to hear our GM boast about his new car/boat/whatever that costs $50,000 or more... bought with his bonus (which is typically linked to the budget surplus).

The scheduling sucks. Just sucks. The schedules are typically Saturday through Friday. More often than not, the schedule gets posted late Thursday/early Friday, just days before it goes into effect, making it close to impossible to make plans in advance. This affects almost all hourly associates.

The first thing I was told when promoted into hourly management (supervisor) was not to get involved in "drama" and fraternize. Not a big deal. Until you find out that people are getting promotions and raises, and hanging with the GM, because they are fraternizing. Sigh.

Speaking of "fraternizing", a manager of mine was found to be having a relationship with a subordinate. She chose to promote him and demote me without reason or notice. When everything surfaced, a few associates called HR, and management caught wind. Management's response was to transfer the manager to another property and call it a day. When the associates found out about this, more calls to HR and threats to quit flew around. A HR rep from Bethesda flew out and sorted it resulting in a termination of the fraternizing manager but not the associate. In the end, we were told by the AGM and GM to not call HR, and to bring issues to them so they can handle it. Even though they couldn't with the issue at hand.

review_title: Good Company When Under the Right Manager
pros: I can only speak to my experience at the corporate level, which I hear is different than that at the hotel level.  At HQ, I liked that Marriott made a conscious effort to keep an upbeat environment for employees with different activities and events for employees on a regular basis.  We also had plenty of perks like a nice cafeteria, gym, daycare, convenience store and other things, right in the building.  And of course, the best perk of all: NICE HOTEL DISCOUNTS.  We also had a good benefits package, but I'm not sure that I would call it super outstanding when comparing it to the other benefits my friends receive at other Fortune 500 companies (or even smaller companies).
cons:
Although Marriott prides itself in offering a good work-life balance, having won many awards for one of the best places for working moms, I (nor many in my department) experienced those benefits.  I know that many in the HQ building did enjoy the ability to telecommute and the ability to have a flexible schedule, but I also heard many who didn't, so it all depended on who was your manager.

Another area of weakness was the excessive micromanaging.  My department had a couple managers did it too much and this sometimes lowered our morale.  

And another issue that I had while at Marriott was the lack of ability to move to other positions.  I was a good performer at my job.  So the one thing I thought my manager did a good job at while I was there, was supporting me when she knew that I had outgrown my position and needed to move into a different/bigger role.  That didn't help at all because the two or three times I tried to apply for other positions for which I qualified, I didn't even get a courtesy e-mail or call acknowledging my interest for the position and letting me where I stood.  This is another area, however, that doesn't apply to everybody.  I saw many people who did move to different positions within the company and others who had the same issue I did.  I guess we just didn't know how to "play the game."

Most employees are hourly up until upper level management which is nice for overtime pay since most management jobs are 50 hour work weeks.

PTO is accrued - you can also take unpaid days off if you haven't accrued enough PTO 

Through the acquisition of Starwood, Marrriott is growing and will soon be the largest hotel company in the world - lots of opportunity for career growth. 

Every leader I have had within the company is typically always flexible and understanding when it comes to your life outside of work if things come up.

Having worked both in the operations side and the sales side for the company, unless you work in sales there is very little work-life balance. However, this holds true for the entire hotel industry. In some peoples opinion the overall package is worth it, however if pay (excluding any benefits) is important then you will most likely be disappointed. job_title: Front Desk Associate in Portland, OR

Marriott also has great travel benefits... you can travel anywhere in the world and stay at an associate rate that can be as low as $39.00 a night. Your friends and family are also eligible to receive a discounted rate, they just need a form from your Human Resources department or Manager.
cons: Like anywhere, there are things about the job that are stressful. Since you are working in the service industry, you will be in contact with many different types of people, with different backgrounds, and different ideas of what service is. You will meet people who are so friendly and easygoing that nothing will bother them, even if you are oversold and they have to stay at a different hotel for the night, they just say they understand and don't care. Then you will have the other extreme where if you don't smile just right they will jump down your throat. You just have to take it in stride and realize that sometimes it isn't even you that sets them off, it could be their bad day that started 12 hours ago.

review_title:
A a great company, an industry leader and the bearer of a proud tradition that has not lost it's way. 
 industry leader
pros: Great focus on core business of lodging and a desire to remain ahead of the curve or at the very least, stay competitive when it comes to  adopting new business strategies and trends. Marriott does a great job of recognizing and promoting talent from within - I literally went from entry-level to Department head in less than 3 years. The hospitality business in general is not for everyone but if you are inclined to love it, you will like Marriott more than the other choices in my opinion - better than the franchise management companies that I've had experience with for sure. Please note that all of my experience comes from working at full-service Properties, I can't really speak at all to the experience of Limited Service associates and managers.
cons: The Hospitality business is subject to the whims of the economy so that is tough - not only do bonuses and such rapidly shrink away but contingency plans wait like wolves at the door when travel (and, of course) revenue drop off as companies tighten the belts. Also, to advance to bigger and better things it is often necessary to move to larger markets and often this means places like Orlando or resort areas that are nicer to visit than they are to live in. Since Marriott is a largely de-centralized company when working at Property level  you feel a bit isolated if you are not afforded the opportunity to attend training and conferences.

pros: The Marriott discount is very nice and can be used all over the world.  Most of the employees that work there are very friendly and get along well.  The job generally isn't stressful (depending on the position).
cons: Mid-level management is the biggest struggle.  If of course varies by department but some fell in to their positions and are not as qualified as they should be.  There is low pay and minimal benefits.

job_title: Front Desk Attendant in Laramie, WY
pros:
Pleasing the guests.
Putting smiles on faces.
Enjoyed holiday gifts.
Pay was above average.
Flexibility in scheduling.
Not to many other pros to list.
cons:
Frequent memos about pointless things, sometimes including conflicting information and required employees acknowledgments.  
Changes in policy that were important were often not made clear, sometimes resulted in write-ups of employees because of the lack of understanding.
Even if employees asked questions of management, we were left wondering, or told to take up with another entity.
Employees were written up in mass and for frivolous events.  
Management pushed blame to lower levels and never owned up to mistakes.

pros: Benefits, PTo time and flexibility .YOu can usualyy get time off when you need it. Like if you want four days you can take thurs to sunday and will not lose pay

job_title: Director of Sales in Houston, TX
pros: I worked for a small property management company that opened it's first Courtyard Marriott.  I was the Director of Sales for the Pre-Opening Team. Received warm welcome from Marriott Corporate, great training, and tremendous tools to be successful. Compensation, bonus structure, and benefits were all very good.
cons: As a Modern Essentials Marriott Hotel with 125 sleeping rooms and 4 large meeting/banquet rooms which the Bistro Department was to prepare food, drinks, and serve for, the DOS should have been able to hire an Administrative Assistant/Inside Catering Coordinator to ensure the highest return on investment and total guest satisfaction! I absolutely loved building client relationships and closing sales, but no one can work unlimited hours and have a balance of career and family life in a management position, when Business Development by  Outside Sales is the main responsibility.  50-60 per week is a can-do; however, 70-100 hours is not. No one can be 2 places at once and answer to requests from 5 different staff members in upper management. "Someone is not going to be happy!"

pros: Working under the Marriott name is nice because it is well recognized and highly respected in the hotel industry. Marriott gives employees, friends and family a nice discount on hotel rooms anywhere in the world.
cons: Be careful because many Marriott hotels are franchised by local or national hospitality management companies. Marriott has great benefits and a culture focused on their people. However, most management companies that are franchisees care about saving money at the expense of their people and cut benefits or hardly have any.

pros: You receive great hotel discounts around the world. You also have the opportunity to meet many different guests with a wide variety of careers.
cons: Depending on the property you work for it is hard to move up within the company. You have to get into a good property that is willing to train you and willing to mentor you in moving up your career ladder/

pros: This was a great place to work because I'm a people-person.  Most of the employees decent people to work with, and most of the guests were good people too.  The current management at that location is also very, very good.  They are never too good to get down and work with the rest of us.
cons: I worked breakfast shift, which was way too early for my taste. It's a little difficult to be nice to people that are yelling at you and swearing at you, but you develop thick skin.

pros: Great company and culture. Flexible hours and all employees are nice and friendly. Definitely a family-oriented culture
cons: There is no career growth. People have been in the management position for many years and does not allow the lower level to grow into a leadership position. They want you to do more work but knowing there is no opportunity because the older generation are fixated to their current position. Very discouraging to the new generation. Yearly 2.5% increase in salary isnt pegged to inflation

job_title: Cart & Bag Attendant in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I always got along well with co-workers and the J.W. Marriott Desert Ridge was a beautiful property to work at. We had great benefits that I made use of whenever available.
cons: During the summer, my opening shifts started at 4am and since we worked outside, we would all bring our own sunscreen and drinks to stay hydrated (it was typically over 100 degrees). The food in the cafeteria was really cheap and convenient but could have been a bit better.

pros: The job is wonderful interacting with individuals who are on vacation, in for business, or just staying for one night.  The staff is wonderful, very family like.  They are my rocks when I need and they are always there for one another.
cons: Hours...obviously hours of a hotel are 24/7 however there is no set schedule, and you find out on Thursday your schedule for Sunday and the following week.  The scheduling is difficult to plan out the rest of your time making work/life balance a bit more complicated than the average.

job_title: Server Trainer/Bartender in Boca Raton, FL
pros: They take care of their employees but I work for a franchise just to let everyone know I don't work for corporate. I really would love to work Marriott international because they are an amazing company.
cons: Not being able to move over to another department if the department you're working for closes for renovation. Working for a franchise I'm limited in advancements

review_title: I started as a clerk and I was given opportunities to grow and advance. By the time I left, I was a manager.
job_title: Training and Development Manager in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The company offers Training and Development classes, performance reviews, salary increases, opportunities for advancement, great benefits, including Medical, Dental, Vision, Paid time off, 401k, Retirement plan, Life and Disability insurance, Employee Discounts, annual employee opinion survey, company sponsored events, at Marriott employees are heard and valued.
cons: Some employees (managers) spend too much time at work. They may feel that they cannot delegate or something wrong might happen with the customer.

pros: If you love working with people and take pride in your customer service skills, you will love working for Marriott. I have worked for Marriott for over 7 years and I am considered a "baby" in regards to service years. I have never worked for a company with higher associate retention rates than Marriott.  The pay is competitive so if you are looking to apply at a location, look for properties with a lot of competition nearby. These properties will likely offer higher pay rates. Marriott makes it a point to show appreciation for their employees year round, but especially during their associate appreciation week. This week includes free meals, an associate gift, award ceremonies. There is opportunity for growth within the company as associates are generally given priority over outside applicants for positions.
cons: If you are an hourly associate, you may not always get the hours that you need. There are busy weeks and slow weeks. During slow weeks, management will schedule accordingly to compensate which definitely takes a toll on the pocketbook. Also if there are long stretches of slow periods, and your hours are consistently getting cut, you run the risk of losing your eligibility for benefits as these are only available for full time associates. Also, hospitality is a 24/7, 365 business.  So unless you are in upper management,  you may not always have desirable hours and will have to work most major holidays.

job_title: Digital Content Producer in Bethesda, MD
pros: Great company to work at with lots of opportunities to grow your career. Headquarters is designed so you never have to leave during the day; there's a cafeteria, gift shop, gym, yoga studio, FedEx and a Starbucks all inside.
cons: As the worlds largest travel company, it's easy for teams and departments to work in silos. In addition, it can take longer than usual to get anything approved because of the hierarchy. This, of course, depends on what team you work on.

review_title: Overall a great experience with this company
pros:
- I have had the opportunity to travel the country while advancing my career and skillsets, in a very short time of less than three years. Very few companies offer this ability to move and grow; even fewer companies have leaders and teams willing to support and help you achieve your goals!

- As I said, through this company I have had the opportunity to build meaningful and long-lasting relationships. For those former employees and leaders I did not stay in contact with, I still learned much and am thankful for time spent under their tutelage.

- Usually a strong focus on overall team-focused learning and development; refreshing because at many franchise or non-corporate hotels, L+D is exclusively reserved for the favorites and top-performers. Support and development tends to be equally distributed and management is usually very serious about this! An all aboard mindset is key to success.

- Corporate is easy to get in contact with and provide efficient and helpful support with operations. They also have clearly outlined procedures for handling on-property issues. This is excellent, as some smaller companies have prove to be more difficult to communicate with.

- Overall, this company imparted onto me two important mindsets: 1) Be thankful for initially negative guest or employee situations, they can (with much work) often be turned into the most impactful opportunities, and 2) There is always a better way of doing business for guests and your team.

- This is a five-star review based on my time in Bellevue and Denver. However, rural properties are not being ran with the same standards of managerial excellence present at city and big-ticket properties. Understandably, but also unfortunately, so. I had such a good time in Bellevue and Denver, that I honestly cannot rate Marriott, as an overall operation, less than five stars.
cons:
- Benefits will vary property-to-property. This can be shocking to some. As a leader, it can be difficult to get your team "back to Earth," if they came from another property with "better" benefits.

- This is a pro/con, but I encountered a true Yin/Yang force during my entire tenure with Marriott. Over the course of three years, I found myself at three different properties. The first two were hands down amazing and positive experiences. The last one made me thankful for the first two. Unfortunately, like benefits... there is a large divergence between certain properties and others as far as interest in team development, employee retention, and overall mindset. It is a good idea to do some due diligence and figure out if the exact property you are interested in is a good fit for you.

review_title: It Pays to Work Hard at Marriott
job_title: Catering Sales Executive in Bethesda, MD
pros: Marriott provides a supportive work environment. They have some of the best training in the industry and provide employees with the opportunity to move around and work in serveral departments. Management encourages a wide breadth of experience and are encouraged to push emoployees to try new things and departments. The benefits-medical and retirement are decent enough and competative with those in the industry, as is the pay. There is a choice in plans for medical and the majority if not all of dental, vision, disability and life insurance are covered. Marriott retirment savings will match what you put in up to a ceratain percentage. They are many resources available to all employees for everything from cell phone discounts to help with life planning. The employee discounts on rooms aren't to shabby either!
cons: Being the hospitality industry hours can't be helped. If you are working on property in an operations department, you are going to work nights and weekends. This isn't neccessarily a bad thing, depending on your lifestyle and other obligations. They will always try to give you your two days off in a row as if it is a real weekend. The hours for manager are less than ideal. You must work a minimum of 50 hours per week, whether it is busy or not. Most managers are salaried so this is looser for them than others, however with a new change in some positions, some have been switched to hourly, which means working 10.5 hours per day in order to make their promised salary. There are also problems with going from property jobs to corporate jobs. There is little cross over from one to the other as they make it hard to have the proper requirements/experience to do so.

review_title: Marriott are we losing our culture?
job_title: Sales Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: The company believes in promoting from within when possible.  This allows you to start as an hourly associate and promote into management and from there into senior management.  The Marriott believes in consant training of it's work force to ensure their associates are kept up to date with the latest in hospitality.  There is still a sense of family in most hotels and associates and managers tend to genuinely care about each other.  There has definitely been some improvement over the past 5 years in the concept of balancing work and family life.  Some are allowed to telecommute or work remotely, however this could be embraced by more of their hotels.
cons: The company does not pay as competitively and tends to pay on the lower end of the scale.  This can make it difficult for those that are single parents, or working in high cost of living areas.  The company also seems to be losing focus on the core values that built the company into what it is today.  Mr.  Marriott Sr. believed that you take the best care of your associates and they in turn will take the best care of your guests.  The guests will return because of the hospitality and service they received which will provide the revenues needed for the stockholders and investors.  The company is now at the point where the bottom line is really all that matters, at the expense of their associates and customers.  It's a shame that this company seems to be losing sight of why we are in the hospitality business.

pros: Marriott provides great job security and benefits. I like working for the company and would live to move up but it is a challenge though which is normal and expected. The favoritism needs to stop
cons: There's too much favoritism, everyone should be given a chance to move up based on performance and length of employment. The downside doesn't come from marriott as a company it's just those admin people who are representing the company in a bad way.

review_title: It was an alright company to work for.
pros: Flexible hours, Provided free lunch, occasional pizza or food parties for lunch, good with time off. overall decent people. Very professional, and not a lot of fighting with upper management.
cons: Fighting between departments, when business was slow hours were cut drastically, (even full time got as low as one day of work a week during the slow season)  Low protection of employees from sexual harrassment from guests. I was told that the guest was a vip so not to make too much of a fuss about it.

review_title: Great Culture - could be more nimble
pros: Very people focused, a very "caring. sharing" approach to managing employees. Solid place to work if a steady pace is your thing. Management are loyal and the company does a great job of instilling corporate pride across the organization.
cons: Slow to market with new ideas. Very by the book which is to be expected from a large corporate environment, but could encourage more ideas and entrepreneurial thinking from junior/ mid managers. Happy to accept a large amount of middle of the road performers.

review_title: Marriott was a strong culture, with team members who wanted to work with you to provide a better customer experience
pros: I really enjoyed how open and friendly the workers were with me as a new employee. Everyone was really welcoming and wanted to work with you rather than against you.
cons: Too much corporate involvement. There were little things that needed to be done a lot that needed approval from someone higher up whether it be at that hotel or someone in the corporate office. It slowed a lot of things down that could've been taken care of with more autonomy.

job_title: Guest Experience Team in Linthicum Heights, MD
pros: I worked at a Springhill Suites by an airport. Everyone I worked with was awesome and we rarely got insufferable guests. Pay was 9.75 which was higher than I expected. Slow days mean a lot of sitting in the back eating and on your phone. Really not a difficult job to do.
cons: Poor management-employee communication except when absolutely necessary, long intro period (4 months), a lot of days working alone, cut hours when business is slow, varying shifts

pros: The only redeeming quality of any work I've done with Marriott has been the people I work with and the interesting guests I've met. My fellow associates  have been some of the coolest people that I've had the pleasure of interacting with and working alongside and some guests have been massively cool! They were the only reason I was able to stand working at either property for as long as I did. I made god friends and learned some things about myself, professionally and personally...but those things are things I really could've learned anywhere else...preferably anywhere else.
cons: Now, I love people! I love interacting with others, I love communicating with others, but when there is an issue in the workplace and management tells you to stop basically "grow up", that is when you know that the company you work for is NOT for the people or hospitable in any way towards their supposed guests or their associates. In terms of work-life balance, what work-life balance? The hours are 24/7, 365 days, and management doesn't really respect the life part of that balance...especially if you are involved in anything outside of hospitality (i.e. school, part-time job, church, family, etc). If you majored in or absolutely LOVE hospitality, then it won't bother you....but otherwise, stay away. :P

review_title: Finance/ Accounts professions - read this review before joining
pros: Marriott was a great start. Having no prior knowledge of the hotel industry, it gave me the necessary tools to begin a career. As someone who has worked both in a customer facing (Front desk & F&B) and back office role (Finance), the company always gave preference to its own while promoting..The learning resources were always available, operating procedures were straightforward and easy to learn, software is the best it can possibly be for the industry. Add that to benefits like free food, uniforms, uniform cleaning, a week long motivation program. Exposure to people from different cultures (a lot of property associates are not local) also helps increase knowledge and your soft skill set.
cons: Marriott India, however, is another story. I worked in India in a back office function, and trust me, if hell had an office it would be in finance. Training is scarce. A lot of employees don't want to admit that they require training for the fear of being singled out. Bosses are terribly, terribly arrogant and use verbal abuse and public shaming to get their way with associates. This combination leads to slipshod property set up and maintenance. Add politics to the mixture and you get a horrifying mixture of nepotism & brown nosing. Working hours are pretty much 24/7. Get used to 14 hour days, no off days and generic torture from your immediate supervisor. The pay is laughable. When I say laughable, I mean hilarious. You are not paid fairly for the work you do and even then are expected to do more. In short, it isn't a professional environment.

review_title: Marriott is not what it use to be...

There is a lot of lip service but very little teamwork, everyone is very much out for themselves.  They do not value their employees and you are very dispensable.  Pay and benefits are mediocre, similar corporations are much more competitive.  

Overall, I'm disappointed in what this company has become.

job_title: Guest Service Representative in Newport News, VA

pros: Working at the Marriott is a great way to get your foot into the luxury hotel stay experience. A business that truly cares about it's guests more than most can even claim, much less do.

review_title: I had a very good work attendance record.  I got along with everyone and was very good with the guests.
pros: When I worked at Fairfield I felt like I was family to everyone.   Even though we didn't always see eye to eye I got along with everyone.  If I had a disagreement with anyone there were never any grudges or hard feelings that couldn't be mended in a short time. It was just like a family.  My way of doing things was to let bygones be bygones  and always approach a situation with a positive attitude.  I never let any negativity get to me and tried to always treat each workday as a new day and a fresh start.
cons: The job was very stressful and it was difficult to turn guests away when there credit card didn't go through or if we had to turn them away or couldn't  give them what they wanted or expected.  It was part of the job to  go by company policies an was hard to disappoint a guest when their request was against the policies that were set by corporate and even in some instances by the fire Marshall.  I really enjoyed making people happy but knew that I had to draw the line even when the guest didn't feel it was reasonable.
