pros: I have worked for both Marriott & for Ritz-Carlton.  Marriott tends to ask you outright to do more and so you get more opportunities.
cons: Ritz-Carlton is hampered by unions.  Therefore, you cannot have any official duties outside the scope of the job for which you were hired.

job_title: Senior Account Executive in Greensboro, NC
pros: Great company to work for.  Most associates within the company are ethical and caring. They offer a great benefits package and many opportunities for growth.
cons: Opportunities for growth may be limited if not available to relocate however this is circumstantial to the city one resides in

pros: Great co workers, great supervisors, always have a team that comes together with the guest in mind.
cons: HR is unprofessional, upper management does nothing to handle very serious issues. Like not receiving pay for all of your hours worked.

job_title: Guest Services Manager in New York, NY
pros: The company has amazing benefits, from hotel discounts to health care coverage and retirement contribution matches. The schedules are sometimes flexible, where if you need a specific day off, you can get it without having to use a PTO day.
cons: Expect to get yelled at by guests daily as well as employees. It becomes taxing after a while. Overnight shifts are a thing. If you want to work in hotels, expect to work one every now and then. The schedule is based on occupancy, so you'll often find yourself doing a turn-around shift.

review_title: Great Benefits, Terrible Work/Life Balance.  Poor working conditions.
pros: Great health care benefits, benefits better than most other jobs.  Generous room discounts (off-peak season).  Friends and family get room discounts too.  Free dry cleaning service of your work uniform.  Free meals (although low quality food) in employee cafeteria.  However on Christmas and Thanksgiving if you have to work they will provide a special high quality meal for you to eat.  Up to 3% match for retirement.  Company has a good philosophy of putting people first.  They try to have company culture and one week out of the year they have an employee appreciation event.
cons:
There is no work/life balance (unless you have worked there for 20 plus years and hold the top seniority position).  You will most-likely work every major holiday.  They will usually deny you a day off to attend your child's high school or college graduation (giving you no other option but to call-off for major milestone moments in your life).  Former co-worker was even denied her wedding date.

Inexperienced management.  They hire people with little or no experience in the industry.  Generally management is uneducated.  People that have no clue how to do your job will be micro-managing you.  

Bad/lazy/burnt-out employees are protected by the union.  Bad employees that were fired by the company were brought back by the union. While this is not the companies fault (because the company does try to get rid of bad employees),  the union protects these bad workers and it makes your job harder for you because you will be dealing with the bad employees that mess up the operation, and you have to pull their weight.

You rarely get lunch breaks and rarely get the ten minute rest period that is required by California state labor laws.  Common to work 8 plus hours non-stop.  Management is insensitive to the fact you haven't eaten all day.  There are days you are so short staffed you cannot even use the restroom and  have no choice but to hold-it until the end of your shift.  While they do pay you for the 'meal-break penalty' you still have to sometimes work all day serving food to people while you are staving and rarely get the opportunity to eat.

Management and supervisors often disappear during peak busy hours and you usually have no support when you need it.  The few good managers eventually leave the company.

review_title: I had a very pleasant experience working for this hotel chain.
pros: Great career opportunities, very competent senior managers who care about their team members. Friendly working environment. By working here you can learn a lot about the structure of the company.
cons: The amount of work can be pretty overwhelming sometimes. You should be prepared for a lot of stress and hard work.

review_title: A great company culture in today's corporate environment, but still some issues to beware of.
pros: Truly great culture when it comes to taking care of their people at all levels, not just the hourly. Decent benefits and hours unless you work on property in operations...but that's just the nature of the business. Low turnover so you get a sense of job security. Great perks like discounted hotel rooms etc. Great opportunities for anyone interested in global markets and emerging economies. They are bringing in more senior leadership from outside the company that is really refreshing and inspiring. I would say the best hotel company to work for...you just really need to love the industry to stay.
cons: There is A LOT of stagnation in the company. While this can be great for job security it makes it a difficult and frustrating environment for talented and ambitious people. You see a lot of hiring decisions being made based on seniority rather then merit...this does not got over well with Gen Y. Pay is really low and education is not valued as much as other industries. It can be a very difficult culture to fit into as most people have been with the company for 15+ years and are still sitting in what most would consider entire level positions. While there are a lot of opportunities for advancement you really have to seek out the right leaders to get you there...way to many leaders subscribe to the seniority view and will try to discourage you from posting to positions if you haven't spent more then two years in your current one...regardless of your talent level.

pros: Great staff to work with, and had a lot of responsibilities. Great resume builder, overall it was a great entry level position.Staff was really great though.
cons: Pay is not impressive, moving up within one geographical area would be difficult. Pay is really the biggest problem, other than that was a great experience.

review_title: Marriott Cork-friendly people and nice envirnoment
pros: There is a really friendly atmospehere and a great mix of people from many different countries. You get a permanent contract and can move between departments. We were promised repeatedly, month after month, that an upgrade was in the works, and we'd communicate that to guests - but then the appointed time would roll around and there would be no remodel. In addition, we started raising the room rates, charging for parking when we never had before, and even started charging for the coffee in the lobby. There was no change in the hotel or services provided to account for these increases in price, so returning guests that had been staying with us for years would get pissed off about it. We were getting yelled at all the time. Management basically just ignored the guest complaints, and as far as I know that particular hotel still has not been remodeled to this day. It made working there very unpleasant toward the end. Hopefully it's better now, though!

pros: Strong network of smart individuals who work hard. Many resources to succeed compared to Hyatt or Hilton. Many beautiful properties in their portfolio, should you want to move. review_title: Potential Rooms Voyagers - be sure to reach out to those who are Voyagers now, or who work at your potential property!!
pros:
Your experience will definitely depend on what property you are at. REACH OUT if possible to those who have been a Voyager at the property you are thinking of working at, or who have worked in the department you are going to. If you have any university alumnae that have experience, REACH. OUT. I made the mistake of not doing so. 

This review is solely on my experience at my property (NYC union property) and for Operations. I know that a Voyager at a different property or a different department  would have a much more positive experience. 

Pros... Good benefits because you're working for a huge company, great hotel discounts. You're empowered to make decisions that most people your age probably wouldn't be able to, since you're basically a manager. You are able to handle and face situations that you might not until way later in your career if you had another job. Huge potential to network and create great connections for the future, especially since hospitality is such a close-knit industry and everyone seems to know each other. This position is definitely a very good way to get your foot in the door and move up. It's just a shame that I had such a negative experience.
cons:
Awesome discounts, sure, but I've used it once or twice. Management seems to discourage any time off, even during dead season, and will make the excuse that you work for a hotel so it's a 24/7 business. 

No work-life balance. You're exhausted after your job, and expected to work at least 50 hours a week. You're lucky if you get a holiday off. No time to even complete the Voyager program or do anything Voyager-related. 

Favoritism is very obvious. Know who to suck up to and when to work hard, and know when you don't necessarily have to work hard. The person who excelled at this would often get weekends off even though she was newer. 

My specific property had a terrible work environment because of the corrupt union employees. They basically run the place, and management is too scared to say anything to them. Management will also turn their back on you when it comes to you vs the union. 

You are basically cheap labor. The pay is terrible, and you are basically a cheaper version of an actual manager. Instead of hiring more legit managers, they will just use you. 

In general, EVERY single one of my colleagues except 3 wanted to quit and were miserable.

job_title: Front Desk Associate in Wallingford, CT
pros:
Marriott is an amazing company to work for. If you had to choose some of the best reasons to work here they would be as follows.
1. Perks: As an employee of Marriott International you have access to discounted rates at any Marriott worldwide for rates as low as $35 per night. You also have a 20% discount on Food/Beverage Items as well as a 30% discount on gift shop items.
2. Support to Move up: Marriott International is all about helping you as a person develop into a higher role (that is if you want it). If you are determined to take the next step, Managers and the whole company as a whole will give you the support and resources that you need to achieve your goals.
3. Sense of Family: It is great to be excited to come into work everyday. Working for Marriott is like a second family. Everyone is treated with respect and fairness, and you often become very close with your co-workers.
There are many other great reasons to work for marriott, but if I had to pick the top 3, those would be it.
cons:
There are not many downsides, but with every company has at least a few. If I had to choose any downsides they would be as follows:
1. Flexibility: You have to be very flexible to work for Marriott, and it is not just Marriott, it is any hotel chain. You are going to work on a rotational schedule. You will have different days off each week and you will be working different shifts throughout the week. That is until you get into Senior Management and then you have a certain schedule, but even Senior Managers have to work 10 hour days and may stay later depending on demand.
2. As with any customer service business there is going to be irate guests. Because you work in an industry where the guest is waited on hand and foot, it may be hard, but you must maintain composure. If you can master this, you will excell. Remember, you are here for the guests, without them, you would not be there.
